Dota, to me, is like having a long, complicated on-off relationship with a childhood sweetheart without really figuring out whether or not she's the love of my life. So we keep trying and trying. 

When we're not together, I miss her. When we're together, we eventually realize that it's not going to work, and then we break up. Rinse and repeat.

She keeps imposing her presence on me, reminding me in subtle ways that she's always there. Or, should I say, I'm the one that keeps coming back? At this point, I don't know anymore.

I hate her and I love her. I hate that I love her. It's complicated.

SUPER SHORT: If you are considering this game, DON'T. Don't start playing it. It is a waste of time, but you only discover it after long time. 

It is like a toxic relationship, that lures you with pretty looks (number of players and esport scene), then waits for you to be fully committed... only to cheat on you.

--------

SUMMARY:
1. It takes hundreds of hours to learn, for casual gamer it can take months or a year to play at a decent level.
2. When you finally get good, you realize that matchmaking is horribly flawed and there are high numbers of cheaters (either people trolling/griefing others or smurfs, people with multiple accounts who pretend they are lower rank/skill level than they really are)
3. Most people I know and spent years playing this, are quitting, not because game sucks (game is great), but because of the inability of devs to make the matches balanced and fun. They seems unable to get rid of cheaters/griefers.

--------

LONG VERSION:

1. Lack of satisfaction: 
So after you invested so many hours, years in the game, you will discover that matches are becoming more and more unsatisfactory. Either you will feel that your wins are unjustified, because some smurf helped you win the game (with minimal effort). Or you lose 5, 6, 10 games in a row in many cases to people with abnormal win rates (probably smurfs).

It is like going to play basketball after work, but instead of nice game you get a semi-pro, try-hard player that scores all throws and never passes to you, while insulting everyone. No matter if you are in winning or losing team, this is really not fun.

2. Cheating spiral: 
What is worse, is that you will notice that people you know will also start smurfing. They will do it because they are trying to escape higher rank smurfs in their games, so they pretend they are lower level, and then it spirals into honest people needing to cheat to enjoy the game.

It is almost impossible to find a winning weekend championship team that doesnt heavily smurf, they all do that (including people I know). And because everyone does it, there is more and more pressure on other people to do it as well. Normal and Turbo modes that should be laid back and casual are now also full of smurfs who faced with imbalanced ranked are moving to those modes to score easy wins, which kills casual fun in those modes as well.

3. It is so easy to be toxic and cheat in dota 2:
What is worse is how easy it is to smurf, have multiple accounts, or grief people and how little punishment you get even if you get caught. You can destroy many games (each game being 9 other people so you can easily destroy fun of 100s of people, before you get a warning, or moved to low priority games (which in two or three hours bring you back). If you want to piss off other people because your life is miserable, then this game is for you, you can destroy fun for hundreds of people before anyone notices or does anything, and even then, you just can easily start from scratch in few hours.

--------

MISSING SOLUTIONS:
1. With all that game data I am surprised that developers cannot create a more automated way to scan and flag suspicious accounts. We all know what XPM/GPM, win rates etc are per hero per mmr bracket, if someone plays too good then moved them higher or flag as potential smurf. 

2. Why MMR is just based on winning the whole game? Why it doesn't reward players for playing well, even if they lose. Then you can get rid or at least minimize mentality that winning is all that counts. Reward someone with positive MMR if they perform better than they usually do, reward placing wards as supports, GPM for cores etc. We already do it through silly challenges, so why not do it for MMR. Give people some fun and recognition. Give them something to try and enjoy even if there is a cheater/griefer in a game.

3. Why there is no paid version (not gimmicky dota+ but a real premium version). I would happily pay extra to play only people who also paid and risk more if they account gets banned or suspended. Also with that extra money you could actually fund some decent support team to review games and accounts. It would be win-win, you get people who committed to the game and you get resources to make the game a better experience. Keep game free for people who cannot afford it or just want to try it, but make a premium tier for people who dont want to deal with emotional kids, smart ass cheaters and general toxicity associated with moba games.




CLOSING WORDS:
It is so sad to see community management in such a poor state, I play dota for nearly 20 years and in terms of quality of games the Dota 1, community approach (ban systems, moderators, leagues) was so much better than the centralized, multimillion system of dota 2. 

Dota is one of the greatest games in video game history, and somehow the current management has managed to make it unfun, frustrating experience. 

It is not like dota was perfect before, but seeing so little progress and in many cases deterioration is disheartening. I love dota but if I could choose to spend my 7 000 hours (really closer to 12k with dota 1) on playing 20 other great games vs just spending it on dota, I would probably do that and have more fun. This is also a smart thing to do for any new players and this is why you should not start playing dota.
Under no circumstance should you ever touch this abominable game.

I didn't play a whole lot, but after coming to this from League of Legends its just not what you expect. I guess this game is more for the nostalgia bros, which is a perfectly fine reason. I know Dota had the concept for this kinda game first, so I give it a medal for that. Plus, despite not interacting with the community at all, my guess is its a lot less toxic than League. Plus, the developers are Valve, so they probably have their heads screwed on right unlike Riot. All that aside, this game was incredibly confusing and not explained very well. No tutorial at all. If I hadn't just come from a different RTS game, it would have been a nightmare. So much to learn and understand, it would probably be ten times easier if I had started playing a long time ago. The things I think league has better are the character design, lore, combat, its more visually appealing, more straightforward, has a tutorial, better map design, easier to understand, and I think they have just fleshed out the concept of this kind of game better. So despite the toxic community and crackhead developers, I would recommend League of Legends over this game.

Disclaimer: Despite my low play time on Steam, I've played pre-Reforged WC3 and early HotS as well as other RTS.

I can only recommend this to three kinds of people:
A- People who are under the age of 21 (You don't work for more than 7 hours; and get months off at a time)
B- People who have played Warcraft 3 a lot
C- Returning players who know what they're getting into (League of Legends and Heroes of the Storm count for this)

-You have a certain "build order" for each character but if you don't know what the numbers mean, you're going to get killed by the guy who does (sometimes as fast as the instant he enters your periphery vision). It's not enough to know about the problem, your hero has to either be able to take care of it or keep someone else's unit alive.

- The HUD is very cluttered compared to Heroes and WC3 itself. A lot of the default settings are actually extremely useful, but attempt to address the problem by throwing suggestions into the player's face and outright making it difficult to browse "normally" (If you have to actively dissuade new players from trying; and make it so hard for those of us who want to; why even have the feature?)

Very fun game overall; but I cannot recommend it to anyone unless they dedicate the time to engage in guides/tutorials.
You also should not play this game unless you know you have at least an hour of spare time (and you will be penalized for leaving early.)

I am a 48 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently downloaded Counter Strike and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Greatest game ever made. I started playing 2 years ago and I was completely overwhelmed by the complexity of the game. I wanted to quit but the sad thing is Dota just makes every other game seem lazy. Dota 2.
Among the best games I've ever played. And somehow it has reached my highest played game. (time wise).

I'm Not Recommending this for one reason and one reason only.

The battle pass is a huge problem.
1. Cash-grab???
- Dota is a free to play game. which is commendable. And i know they have to create income somehow. But this year's battle pass wasn't even half finished when they released it and began selling "levels" to gain the prizes for it. (Many of these prizes are seasonal and expire at the end of the battle pass. Much of the content is unfinished that it's honestly kind of sickening. - it's kind of like they're selling things and then giving you an IOU. It reminds me of the mindset of every early access title I've ever purchased and been disappointed by.
I cant say that this is for sure a cash grab, but it has the bitter bitter taste and look of the cash grabs I've seen in the past.

I've seen different games die from cash grab schemes. If Dota isn't making a profit at this point, let your players know. I guarantee i'd have chipped in more to save games i loved in the past when they started going under. But they never said anything, and before anyone could do anything, they simply shut down.


2. Matchmaking -- It is BROKEN at the moment.
You're getting veteran players matched with brand new people who don't even know how not stand under a tower and get shot to death. That isn't terribly uncommon, but it's much much worse since the battle pass was released.
Here's an example. yesterday i played with 4 other long-time players and we were all against 4 brand new players and 1 other veteran.
It was a blood bath.
And now, for the past few days, every game has been a one-sided crap shoot.
it just isn't fun anymore..
and i never thought I'd quit Dota... but if something doesn't change, I will.

3. The battle pass Cavern Crawl.
It is a good idea in theory but the application of it has horrid results on experiences in matches.
The cavern crawl is basically a challenge to use different heroes in 3 different categories in order to obtain a cosmetic item.
All that is fine and good. But this just causes people to play heroes they don't have any idea how to play. That's not too bad 
 on a normal day when it's just one or two people deciding to try something new. But with the incentive of the cavern crawl, 8 out of 10 people are playing a new hero they dont know how to use, it results in chaos that doesnt usually end up being fun. And this is worse in the first month of the battle pass, but it will continue until it is over.

4. To be continued.

If the game is not fun, why bother?
If it's not balanced, why compete?
If you have no agency on wins or losses, why learn to become better?

It lasted long enough and has a decent monetization system (if you ignore how greedy the battlepasses are... but you can play the game 100% for free, which is better than I can say for most other mobas - no unlocking anything bullshit) But besides that, there's not the necessary components for an enjoyable experience - even when playing with friends. 

The problem stems from balancing issues (understandable given how many characters are in and how often they change stuff to try and keep it "fresh"), and the "skill" based matchmaking system. Much like so many other games of this generation (like CSGO, Overwatch, Apex Predators, etc.), the matchmaking is intentionally designed to condition you, much like an addict, into playing after the "perfect" matches, which fundamentally, you have no control over a win or a loss. It's random. 

Win a few matches in a row? The system puts you in matches where your team mates are considerably worse than the enemy and don't even speak your language, while the enemy team is a 5 stack of cooperating in voice call teammates of much higher rank than you. 
Lose a few games in a row? The game puts you in the opposite situation, where you are destroying the enemy team, to the point where there is no challenge, and you wonder what is going on. 
Either of those, unlike what the more hardcore and perhaps dilusional fanbase will defend, do not contribute to either a pleasant or fun gaming experience, nor do they allow any skill growth.

The fact that the community is inherently extremely toxic, added with the competitive and frustrating nature of the game, lends itself to even friends frequently having attrition and arguments during sessions.

Valve makes (?) great games, and their MOBA was no exception, mechanically, visually and so on, but this game is no longer, in my opinion, worth playing.

I dont know what i like or dislike. All i know is that i like the concept of this game since i played Dota 1.

This game has WAY too steep of a learning curve, everyone's as social as a rock, (meaning no one talks at all in game) and guess what? you leave a match because you had to get lunch? BANNED. Now you can only play in the low priority pool, where you can only choose from 3 random heros, and the matches take YEARS to queue into. Not saying the normal game modes take years to queue into, too.. Matches last TOO long, if you want to play you better be prepared to stay in one match for the next 8 hours of your day. If you leave because you get tired, you get BANNED and put into the low priority pool... Basically ALL heros are underpowered, and then there are like 2 or 3 heros that are actually good. But guess what? Theyll all be taken by the time you move your mouse over the hero's icon. And if you leave because you can't choose a damn hero that wont get one-shot or wont take 5 years to kill another hero, guess what? BANNED. Look, I love Valve as a company. I love all their games. I have 1k hours on TF2 and basically live it. I love playing CSGO. I love the Half Life series. But dota 2 is just not for me, and if your someone who is not willing to invest years to even learn the basics of a game like this, I also don't think this game is for you.

No matter what other game I play. I always keep coming back for more.

First of all, if you come from league, this game is not for you. In league, you face maybe 5-10 seconds of CC at MOST during a teamfight, and thats with a CC heavy composition. In dota, 5 seconds is a basic autoattack stun. Be prepared for the most horrific CC you have ever seen in any game. so how are you supposed to counter a 60 second DOOM ultimate ability for example? A ultimate ability that silences and mutes you for 60 seconds, while dealing damage. You are forced to build an item that counters that ONE ability, and hope you can use that item before he casts an ult on you. Absolultely horrific game design and balance. the power creep of new champions is some of the most horrendous garbage ive ever seen. The variety of items basically allows any champion to do anything, there are items that let you blink large distances, make you immune, refresh all your cooldowns, crowd control the whole team. Its atrociously overwhelming how much nonsense you have to worry about. Playing this game will give you a ruptured blood vessel. I've went through at least 3 keyboards playing this abbhorrent steaming pile of depression. And I dont see myself stopping anytime soon, this game is more addicting than gambling. You sit through a 1 hour match of being TRASHCANNED because one of your teammates fed the horrendously broken carry champion, and yet you still queue again afterwards. Because there is a small glimmer of hope your next team isnt as braindead as the last. Unfortunately when you get up to higher elo, the player pool is so small that if you see a griefer or feeder, you are stuck with that player forever. Theres not enough people in high elo, it's the same drooling roaches. Anyways, this game will cause you severe depression and mental disorders from prolonged play, download at your own risk.

Edit: This became more of a rant and feedback to the community and developers, rather than a review. To anyone reading; this is not a pros and cons list. Enjoy.

Regardless of the hours I've put into this game, I can not recommend it but to one tiny fraction of players, because the issues do not show up clearly or a new players can't even comprehend them early enough. This is a warning from a casual to another. Maybe it's just me getting older and finding better things to do than to listen to a bunch of ungrateful, entitled kids acting out their lack of confidence and false bravado.

The toxicity of this game is mind-boggling. "Boo-hoo"? Anyone who claims, I complain for no reason, must be either one of the toxic little kids or a sad, sweaty troll hating life and everything about it. And saying "filthy casual" indicates the fact; you have no place in the public gaming community. Go play with yourself and your 1337.

Can you enjoy drugs? Yes, you can. Should you? No, you probably shouldn't. Like with this game, the problems don't show up early enough to stop. I did my share of recreational mind-bending and stopped before it got out of hand, but I can't say I stopped this game before I noticed how many hours of my life I wasted on it. Sure I had a lot of good times, and it was a way to connect with my friends since I was the moving type, from country to country in the past 8 years. But looking back now, I realize, and I wish I had spent my time more wisely - on something genuinely productive. In the past 6 months I've cut down to a random game once a week.

Is this game playable, can you enjoy it? Yes, of course, but should you play it? Probably not, if you're not determined to go win the championship one day, or in general make money playing it. Anyone who is not committing them self 100% to this game will not progress beyond a certain point, and the older you get the harder it becomes. After enough years you will probably reach the same conclusion as me. You have to study the game, watch pro-gameplay, read guides, follow meta, follow patches, learn the roles of yourself and others... and mute everyone most of the time, if you want to win in the long run and keep your cool, if you want to get to the top. If you can do all this, then by all means, go at it. This game is so damn difficult for a few reasons, and I guess that is a big part of the charm.

It is definitely up for debate, what the core reason is for the daily number of players playing this game dropping so drastically since 2016. There are plenty of reasons. But apart from the above mentioned; the fact developers are not spending enough time and money eliminating the players from this game who create secondary accounts, boosters, sellers, buyers, but instead lure in more players, new, gullible, clueless little Bambies, with no idea what they're getting into - is a top subject. 

I wouldn't mind a "smurf" in the game, if there was 1 on both teams always, I actually think it could help, if cores would always be from higher ranks, maybe pos 1 and 2, since the game depends on their success, with the help of the rest of course.

"It's not that simple you filthy casual", Yes, no **** Sherlock. But it's what they need to fix asap, I don't care how. 

"It's free to play, you don't even have to pay to play it". Yeah, that's the bait. The flashy skins and the addictive, competitive nature of the game, like chess, is the hook, line and sinker. If you can't see this, then I recommend you go educate yourself a bit.

After years of casual playing, I got to the 3rd tier basically without "trying", but as for anyone who can reflect on their own mistakes and adapt to each game individually, it is possible to rank up with a relatively small amount of effort and even have fun while doing it. What I noticed tho, is that people are only worse here :D
I want to rank down (and eventually I did), not because I want it easier, but because there was more sense of team-effort and unity than in the rank above and the games were simply more fun, even if we lost in the end. 
Maybe we need a second ranked lobby for casuals like myself...

There must be some psychological explanation, to the mindset of players in each rank, what their motive and thought-process is, what they're trying to get out of the game and why they flip out so much, while not even necessarily knowing what is going on, apart from: "it's not my fault we are losing". I had this thought: Maybe people in Crusader (3rd tier), think they are damn pros now, they have ascended from Herald and Guardian - "mein gott I must be a god now, kneel before me peasant, I can play mid Anti-Mage like any other top-tier player and all my supports are trash because I saw a video on youtube from my tiny smartphone while playing whack-a-mole between the sheets." ....But I digress.

Without bragging, this is just for insight, it's not that I wouldn't know my role as a support, for ****s sake I got nearly 8k commendations so I must be doing something right, even when I miss pulling a camp or not being next to my core exactly when needed (remember communication) and yes I was not fast enough to Shallow Grave my cores because, hey, I'm just nub. But people are flaming each other for the smallest things, focusing on the others game so much they lose control of their own. Try to calm someone down, you get reported for not stfu, or they abandon the game. The amount people tilt, is incredible. Nobody keeps it cool. Everyone knows better than the rest, and feel the need to speak their mind, but never feel the need to assess the information they have or make conclusions based on the information at hand. I can't remember who said this but it was a fairly good question; would you run into a pitch-black forest without a flashlight, knowing that somewhere, in there, are monsters who want to kill you? "Oh look some camps to fa........." And then it's my fault they are dead.

Do they need to turn off communication completely for this game to work?? What do you do with kids who can't use their toys and games the way they are meant to be used: take them away. Simple. IF you really think about it, you don't need the chat for anything, since most of the time chat is being used to flame others. You can use the ping wheel, look at the map, draw your plan which lane to push or where to fall back to. You can point-click where you are going. These are great tools, improve them, educate people on using these tools, anything - but please take away team chat, voice and text, to protect everyone. I swear 90% of its use is for toxic bs. Like Pablo Francisco once said: "I love Spaghetti, but it got shit on it!". The game is pure gold but it's ruined by so much crap on top.

And that is why I can not recommend this game.

After reading this review/rant and before posting it I had some reflecting to do, I understand some people will take what I write as a personal attack at them, see it as an old boomers whingeing, an insult and probably feel the need to troll. And this is expected, it's the internet and it breeds people like this. Or society. So have at it.

Like I said, it's hard to say what the core reason is for this game being something you should avoid like the plague. I love the game, but in retrospect; I wish I never started playing it. It's a love and hate relationship. 

This has been my two cents on the matter, my experience with the game and the conclusion I've reached.

I'll allow the comments, so people can prove my point for me.

During my time playing this game, it has changed me. I originally played this game for the fun of trying something new, and ultimately got frustrated and stopped playing. The game in its current state makes me upset for the constant cash grab style that it is for the ability to "be better" at the game. I cannot deny the fun it was doing the compendiums during their times and the battle pass in its early stages, but after so many changes being made to the game. I cannot force myself to play this anymore. 

If you can get past the hatred of the toxic community towards newbies and the constant uneven matchmaking then you can enjoy a well designed base game. It is complex and very strategic but also "RNG-based" at times. 

I have made a many friends on this platform, but after it is all said and done, I can't stand playing this game anymore.

To you who dare brave this sad land of torment, may your soul be purified in the light of a thousand suns, for this darkness shall not cease its wake in its path to attract all those who pass under its gaze. 
I look back at this valley of death and see only the corpses of those who have fallen to its unholy charm; and on their faces are smiles of pleasure in the toxic ooze. Good luck travelers. May your battles be heroic.

Dota 2 is a game but the act of playing is a discipline. Difficulty curve of this game is immense but satisfying. Do not expect to win with ease, ever. This game is a dedicate hard fought war against 5 other players as one among 5. You will see acts, practices, and choices that will define the foundations of your entire game occur over seconds. The complexity alone is immeasurable. 

Dota 2 is a world of its own and if you plan to enter it, know you are stepping into one of the most wild adventures.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well.

Where to begin? Dota 2 is such a horrible balanced game. It's been over 5 years and they still didn't fix the game.

Imagine when you sit in the design room and think about game balance, where the matchmaking is complete garbage and can't come up with a balanced team.

When one hero gets so fed, he can solo the entire team and be basically immortal 1 vs 5.

The gap from dying is so huge you can just give up. But the garbage developers didn't add a forfeit option, so you literally have to sit 60+ minutes every game waiting to lose.

No matter how stacked a hero gets it shouldn't be possible to solo an entire team. It is a team game. Just pick a broken hero and solo feed on the bad players and you have an instant win, and the other team can do nothing to counter it.

And let's not even go into how many trolls there are in this game. They literally love to be cancerous and ruin your games while you try to win 1 vs 5.

Is that fun? No.

battle pass 2022 is an utter joke. Its getting more and more low effort. Valve makes $5M within 24h and all you get is a copy-pasted reskinned battle pass, where half of the stuff that's in there is "coming soon" with no info as to what it's gonna be like. 

They removed a lot of possibilities to grind for levels as well, weeklies now hardly get you anywhere, and because there's no aghs labyrinth or bonus game, you can't get progression through that either. 
It seems to me that valve are trying to see and push the limits as to how much they can milk their players of their money.

I've played this game a lot so I think I have a pretty decent idea of where it all went wrong. This game was good in beta prior to the greedy free-to-play business model, equality of outcome matchmaking system (lobby system is superior), cosmetics (hats), rampant rise in scripting/cheating/smurfing, and paywalls for simple QOL features (dota plus, avoid list). Over the years the game has received less and less developer attention all while players dump more and more money into it. It's not worth playing for veteran players and is definitely not worth playing if you are a new player. The truth is...this game just isn't fun anymore. While this game isn't dead per se, it's undead via the free-to-play business model. Players may dump their money into it but this game is on life support. It's only a matter of time before a new and better MOBA comes out. It's time players vote with their wallets and their feet and stop playing this game. I don't think there is anything that could convince me that this game is going to make a comeback, the developers have had years and years to address issues and have failed miserably. Let it die.

As someone who moved over from League of Legends, I could no recommend this game enough. It was rather quick to pick up and start seeing results. Not having to spend time buying hero's like you have to do within league or other free to play services really has made playing more enjoyable. On top of that having the ability to play support or an offrole and not feeling entirely useless all game was quite refreshing as well.

DOTA 2 is the King of MOBA's. Nothing comes close. In both it's good and bad aspects. It looks great and gameplay is fun and incredibly complex. The heroes are diverse and interesting and there is always something to improve or learn. It's ridiculous such a polished game is free (of pay to win mechanics). Unfortunately the game also requires an insane amount of your time and the learning curve is very steep. This kind of game attracts a special kind of player. And unfortunately you have to play with these hate-filled, unhappy and forever ignorant people. If you are looking to have fun, then Dota is the wrong game. Unless you play with 4 real life friends. But people who play DOTA 2 don't have real life friends.. so.. yeah. Welcome to dopamine driven misery.

See you in hell, Haribo Sugar-Free Gummi Bears

It was my last class of the semester, and the final exam was worth 30% of our grade.
After a late night study session I felt confident, but I had to decide between sleeping in or cooking breakfast. My eyelids chose sleep.
My stomach later regretted this decision, and after several uncomfortable stomach growls, I finally decided to make a quick stop by the campus bookstore and grab a snack before my test. Since the semester was ending and everyone was going home for the summer, a lot of items were on sale, including the snacks and candy that they kept up front. Being in the hungry state that I was in, it felt only logical to pick the largest, yet least expensive candy in order to get more bang for my buck.
And there they sat: two bags of Haribo Sugar-Free Gummi Bears, buy one get one free.
"What a deal!" I thought na√Øvely. I would eat one bag before my test, and one bag afterwards.
As I walked to class, I gleefully chewed on those abominable little bastards, unaware of the utter mayhem that they would soon unleash upon my poor, poor anus.
I sat down at my desk as the professor informed us that, due to issues with cheating in the past, restroom breaks would be prohibited until the completion of the exam.
"I'll give you 10 minutes to use the restroom now; this will be your last chance. Any takers?"
The demon bears hadn't released their unholy necromancy upon my stomach yet, so in my moment of ignorant foolishness, I remained seated, still munching on those miniature bear-shaped bombs.
After the students wise enough to take the professor's offer had returned, the professor handed out the test. I was six questions in when it happened.
It started subtly at first, almost like a slight tingly sensation in my lower abdomen. I thought nothing of it, assuming my intestines were just doing their thang. Little did I know that my intestines were trying desperately to warn me of the horror that was on the horizon.
By question 9 it happened again, but this time it was followed by a sharp pain, as if those infernal hellions had orchestrated an attack upon my colon. I fought to contain the groan that tried escaping my lips. It was at this point I began to panic; something was going horribly long, and I needed to get through this test before it got any worse.
By question 14 my worst fear was upon me; the Satan bears' burning, hot, liquidy dark magic crashed against my anal sphincter like a tidal wave. I was able to close the hatch just in time, but those relentless, toxic bears beat against it like Orcs breaking down the doors of Helm's Deep. I knew I wouldn't be able to so much as shift in my seat without risking a breach.
I kept fighting through my exam, clenching my cheeks with all my might. Beads of sweat began rolling down my neck. Suddenly, a loud, gurgling war cry came from my belly, and the entire class lifted their heads.
At this point, nothing mattered except expelling this ungodly presence from my bowels. With 15 questions left, I promptly wrote C for every answer and ran out of the classroom. My professor yelled something, but I was too preoccupied with the volcanic eruption that needed to take place before I could find sweet, sweet relief.
I burst into the restroom like the Kool-Aid man and, behold, the handicap stall was empty. Sun rays from the adjacent window shone upon it, as if it were a gift from God himself. It took me less than .5 seconds to undo my belt buckle, pull down my pants, and finally relax my weary buttocks upon the toilet seat.
It took absolutely no effort to expel this demon. Almost immediately, the floodgates of hell were opened and the damned, liquified souls of an entire bag's worth of gummi bears cried as they burned through my sphincter and into the watery abyss below. I had never felt such simultaneous relief and anguish in my life.
After 30 more minutes of this, I immediately went home, dug a hole in my backyard, and burned the remaining bag of gummi bears.
I leave with this; do not, I repeat do NOT eat these spawns of Satan. Not only did they cause me to fail my final test, but the anguish I experienced is something I wouldn't wish upon anyone, not even my worst enemy. The only place these god forsaken hell bears belong are buried deep below the Earth's surface.

Great game, I always picture it as modern chess where you only get to control one piece. You have to formulate strategies with your team to work out the best ways to proceed, when your heroes will peak in terms of strength and then in turn when you will push or when you should defend/avoid fights. 

The only downside is people paying high ranking players to increase their MMR and a somewhat generally toxic community. Although you do get some nice, pleasant players sometimes, just generally it's quite toxic. 

In terms of adrenaline rush team fights, heart thumping shocks when someone daggers in to initiate on you and careful strategy planning, it's pretty hard to beat though which keeps me coming back. 

I periodically uninstall this game to stop myself becoming too addicted, pretty sure it contributed towards me not attending or finishing my 1st degree too, you have been warned!!

Don't get me wrong, I am not hating or anything. I was from Dota 1 for like 3-4 years before Dota 2 was released and it didn't caught my attention to adapt the new theme of it.

Dota 2 is a great game, an awesome game. I really should have thought about spending money on a free game but to hell with it I say. Mechanics are well designed, what makes a hero OP is the player behind it and the team that surrounds it. This is a team game people, so team work is a must (unless you are solo queuing, then you have to carry your garbage of a team but it can be the other way around). Monster gamers are real.

Dota 2 has taught me a lot of things, you can only be good at something if you focus on it, learn from mistakes, be aware of your surroundings, trust your instinct, use common sense, trusting on your team to always have your back, believing in your capabilities, always try to be better than you were yesterday, and that..

THE COMEBACKS ARE REAL!!!
This game bought me and my friends together for lan parties and strengthen our bonds. A mere game that brings people together, not just friends but complete strangers too. Dota 2 is a game that will never be forgotten.

All in all, I recommend this game to everyone who wants to experience pain, suffering, and torment because at the end, you will come to a sudden realization that things are always bound to get better.

P.S. Calm down, it's just a game...... YAWA!

Dota 2 is a great game. It is well made, with very deep and complex mechanics and tons of interesting scenarios that can arise. That being said, the game's main downfall is being a very very competitive 5v5 pvp game. This leads to a player base that does not tolerate inexperienced or unskilled players. In a team game, this pretty much ruins it because of abundant toxicity. If you can turn off chat and enjoy the game, great. But I wouldn't suggest anyone get into this game if they aren't already into it. It is better than League though.

This game is SO good and i do not mean that ironically. Little details the develepors added to the game, the graphics, fun you could have with your homeboys from DOTA 2, how interesting and satisfying to see how much you improved on a 1 hard hero and the entire existence of arcade mode is astonishing. Why i do not recommend this game? Because it is 5% beginner friendly in public servers, if you play for 100 hours and learn nothing because of angry russians and filipinos. There is a higher chance of you getting the rank herald rather than every else ranks because you learned nothing for 100 hours in unranked match and played the shittiest 10 rank calibiration matches. And you will be stuck in the rank herald for a long time untill you realize you can get out of herald by carrying your team with an initiator carry. It will take very long to realize this but even if you play initiator carry very good, your bad teammates in herald will ruin the match. There is a suggestion for players under 50 hours in DOTA 2, make a test account where you will learn DOTA 2, and dont spend money on that account(more like an alt account). Then hop on your new account and get a greater rank whenever you feel like ready for the DOTA 2 ranked matchmaking.

Imagine creating an actually fun game, but then for some misterious reason, the people in charge decide to set the camera capture so close (1134 Distance) that you can`t even see what your own hero is doing most of the time.  Since many heroes have long range spells, or a spreat out battle (gank) happens 50% of your concentration goes into managing your camera position; which simply could be  taken out by default by the people in charge.... 

You think this is all ? nope try starting a conversation about this topic in reddit, and see the topic closed by moderators beacause it seems to be sensible topic... (lets see how long this review will stay up...).  And this is my main point, i could somehow life with the rest of the following points. 
But to have the camera capture so close in a strategic teamplaying game with so many heroes with long range spells simply blows my mind and destroyes this game for me.  
(until July2022 there was always a  way around this by enlarging the view via dll.file) which was (rightly) considered a cheat.  for me i didn`t care using it since i knew i would not play dota to earn money with it.  Since July this loophole is now closed. But it was open for as long as Dota2 was up.... so just imgaine the devs now getting so tensed about this topic that you can`t even talk about it ???   why not enlarging the camera view for all the same, even top tier player would love the change !!!

i dont get it: but i get some more points why i would never recommend starting playing dota again: 
- AFK Players:  for some misterious reason some people can stay afk, buy buying an item called shadow amulett, some even wihthout , as i just witnessed. By default if your hero doesn`t move, and gains no experience points for 5 minutes you get an abbandon. this rule always applied to me, but as mentioned some people seem to have  a way around this wich leads me to the next point. 

-Useless Report System: by default you get 5 reports you can send during the game. imagine playing a ranked game, suddenly for whatever reason a player decides to deliberately go afk or hurting your team otherwise by feeding , handing over wards and neutral items to the enemy etc... all you can do is send in a report. you can even send in all 5 if you want. the player (maybe) will get punished if this report by chance will get checked by another player set in as judge for this particular situation. which will happen in very very few cases. Since the availability of judges in contrast to reports is maybe in the average of 1:1000.  but to make you feel better, once in a while you will get a notification saying something like: your report was checked, and the player punished.  (which means, at best he willl get to play 3 low priority games)...

Cheats: as mentioned there seems to be some loophoels in staying afk, at least i withnessed 20 peoples so far not getting an abbandon after not moving an inch (nor gaining xp) over a period of 5 minutes. but there are other cheats, like the "fear" cheat of Shadow Fiend, to mention only one, there are more like no cooldowns on ultimate abilities. And this also is still possible, while for players like me who litterally get nausea playing the game at this close capture view, are beeing punished by not allowing larger camerea option.

-Avoiding player list:  is NOT available if you don`t pay monthly for Dota Plus.... so this means, even if you send in your report for missbehaviour you will end up having the exact same player with his toxic behaviour a few games later and there is NOTHING you can do. if you pay for dota you will get a list of 20 Players (which you can enlarge for credits ((but those expansions get super expensive later))), which you will fill faster than you can extend it. believe me, beeing a player that joins games to win, not tox around, i can speak with quite some experience, you will fill those 20 spots in no time... 

-Matchmaking: beeing a player that joins games to win them and doing all it takes (often more  than the average player, by warding, healing ohter etc.. even as carry) you get a very positive winrate quite fast. The matchmaking algorythm doesn`t like this at all, and you will get punished for it by getting games with toxic fast abbandoning players. and also here there is no way to go arround which leads you to the points i mentioned above. since you can`t to anything as non-paying player, and very little as paying player. therefore even considering dota plus is totally useless. as experienced player the only reason why i would pay for dota would be the "avoid player-list" (but as mentioned , this list is very limited and you will fill it in less than 40 games, 100% guaranteed).

The game is actually very well done. you can choose between a lot of heroes, which creates interesting games. but for mentioned reason. Beeing the super close camera view. and it`s highly addictive nature.

If you are interested in strategic games, Dota 2 game can also be interesting for you; But you should pay attention to these three points:
1. You should definitely go through the training section before playing online and then try to start playing with easy heroes like Axe, Jug, etc. and then go to high level heroes.
2. Be sure to play the part of the game against the robot a lot, because your easiest game in the online game is more difficult than your hardest game against the robot.
3. In the beginning, try to focus on one hero and avoid playing with different heroes.
The above tips were very effective for me, at the end, consider these tips: it is very important to see the game of professional players, read the information of each hero, read the information of the game items, try to find some friends and play the game for Enjoy the game, it will help you not to get bored in the beginning and it will help you to enjoy the game more in the future.

Dota 2 is still one of the most popular games around, and for good reason! The gameplay is incredibly deep and rewarding, and the community is still as passionate as ever. However, there are a few things that could be improved. For one, the matchmaking system could be a lot better. It's often very difficult to find matches that are fair, and as a result, a lot of players get frustrated and quit the game. The other issue is the lack of new content. Sure, there are the occasional new heroes or items, but for the most part, the game feels like it's been in a bit of a stagnation. Hopefully, the developers will add some more fresh and exciting content in the future to keep players engaged.All in all, though, Dota 2 is still a great game and well worth your time. just be prepared to put in a lot of hours to really learn all it has to offer.

While I love this game for the game itself. Others treat the game as a job, and rightfully so, with the amount of time and energy you need to put into learning the game. It can create extremely toxic environments(even I've been a part of doing this) and lowers quality of matches. 

I don't recommend picking it up unless you have the time and energy to truly learn the Meta, Mechanics, Macro-Game, and Micro-Game. Itemization, drafting and team dynamics are stupid important to keep in mind as well, and if you're hardstuck on winning MMR, losses and tilt will make you forget this and the above paragraph happens. You blame your teammates and instaqueue and repeat. 

I'll still play the game myself, as I've put in the time, I understand where I peak and don't care too much for the mmr anymore, and can love the game as it is, but I can't with good conscience recommend Dota to a new player. You should take the time to think yourself on if you have enough time to stress over learning something so diverse, or if you'd rather download the game for the custom games, or just play Bioshock.

Pros:
- Beat people up a wide array of spells and items
- fun game to play with friends
- different classes to suit different play styles, mix and match to your own style
- watch games to learn tips and get coaching
- over 80 characters to chose from
- good learning curve, you'll pick it up quickly and keep learning and experimenting the more you play.

Cons:

Fun and and super competitive! Steep learning curve (with lots of unspoken rules - do some research about this if you want to do well. Find out about roles, positions, when to pick, what to pick etc - or deal with losing a bit more with figuring it out as you go). Subscribe to dota-plus if you want some cool recommendations to help with hero and item choices. The new-player-mode makes it easy enough to practice new heros (which you definitely should be doing). Expect to see some toxic players, just learn where the mute button is early on, keep your cool and you'll have a blast. Much more fun when playing with friends!

Game is fun overall especially if you play with some of your friends.
But the thing is if you want to go up in MMR first of all you have to calibrate to get you rank and get started and most of the times you will get a lower rank than you deserve and you will have to climb your way up.
But that's not it, the problem is when you play extremely well with people with the same rank that you got (which should've been higher) and start winning many games the system will match you with smurfs (because they think you are smurfing while you are just trying to get to the rank that you deserve) and you will lose so much games and then the season ends and you will have the option to re-calibrate your rank and the same thing happens over and over again.
Again, game is fun ,I  personally enjoy it very much and have so many hours but the matchmaking system really needs fixing.

I played the game for quite a few years and I really enjoyed it very much. Until the point where I started noticing that the quality of games gradually went down, with most games nowadays being absolutely uneven, with either team stomping the other, probably due to how the matchmaking algorithm actually works. This further feeds toxicity, which makes you enjoy the game even less, up to a point, where you feel less like you are playing a game and more like you are scrolling through twitter, game by game, either riding the high from a winning streak, or trying to get at least that one win in a day.
I uninstalled and reinstalled the game many times in past two years, with less and less frequency, up to a point where I just stopped and I realized I'm pretty much happier playing other games and the nostalgia isn't worth the hassle.
TL:DR If you intend to play solo and have a good time at the same time, you are quite a few years late to play this game.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

3k hours here. Here is what I learned: 
* Dota is great but it's a bitch to learn. 
* Toxicity in lower MMR kills all the fun. 
* Play with friends that are at your skill level. 
* Better mute all than play along the toxic game. 
* Positive reinforcement goes a long way. 
* If you think you are the best in the game you will become toxic.
* There are better ways to spend your time.
Toxicity in Dota 2 has become normal due to a number of different factors, most of which boil down to inaction from Valve in addressing problems.

Great game, but smurfs and boosters ruined it to unplayable state. I've installed it again after long break, during calibration I saw smurf on enemy team in almost every game, while only once on our team, so of course we kept losing and I was calibrated to Herald III. Then same continued - on average there were more smurfs on enemy team than on ours so MMR just kept dropping despite me playing well, it's just odds of having teammates that are worse than enemy teams for some reason. Maybe it's because I kept getting matched against PARTIES, something should not happen ever because parties play so much more coordinated and have no feeders or clueless people in them, while those who queue alone can have anything in their teams, all of this leading to more losses than wins on average so MMR dropping, so I dropped to Herald I and I still see smurfs on enemy teams, playing difficult heroes perfectly and doing 30-5 or something per match and getting to 30 level while our team is at 15-20. There's just zero chance of winning.
Oh, and chat is 24/7 spammed with 'boost MMR' advertisements.

This game has won the hearts of millions of players. Once a common map to the great Warcraft 3, it has grown into its own label, adored by millions of players around the world. Meet: Dota 2 by Valve Co.
If you have played the map Warcraft, then you do not need much explanation, but if you are in doubts: to pump or not, here's what it looks like - ten people spend some time killing the enemy minions or neutral (creeps) or characters (heroes). With the proceeds you buy artifacts that give you certain attributes (stats) and skills (skills). With the experience you gain, if you level up, you learn the skills (skills) of the character. The main task of your team is to destroy the enemy's main building (enchantment), on the way to which you have to destroy combat towers from level one to four (the difference in power, armor and number of hit points as the level increases).

The Dota 2 Report System doesn't work.
You can get actionably reported for any reason whatsoever.

If you are paired in successive games with 4 petty and spiteful people they can easily report you and get you soft banned. This can easily snowball into more bans and lowering your behavior score which can remove you from the matchmaking pool.
Valve cannot grow the Dota 2 population because of this, and they are a company with bad worth ethic as so many former employees have come forward and stated.

Please remove this bug or exploit or hack I don't even know what it is.
Basically I queued a ranked game today after having a bad day.
When loading the draft screen my mouse disappeared totally. I thought my game bugged out so I tried to relaunch it twice but both time the mouse would disappear every time when the heroes screen would load.
So I wasn't able to select a hero until eventually I lost all of my gold (and everyone lost the max amount of time) and was randomly attributed a hero.
But then I also got assessed an abandon. So the game was made safe to leave and everyone one left and everyone lost their precious time due to some stupid bug or hack or something.
Unfortunately I couldn't restart my computer to see if that could have maybe fixed it because I can't restart it fast enough to not be assessed with an abandon. So we won't ever know.
But I really don't think it was an issue or anything with me at all.
Also when I left the game lobby or more exactly got kicked out (since I couldn't do anything since I had no mouse) then I soon as I got out of the lobby then my mouse cursor came back. Also my cursor was always still there in other applications. In only disappeared in the drafting lobby. I could even see it fade in and out of existence when I alt-tabbed.
Also it's not the cursor was just hidden. I tried clicking on anything because I didn't want to be punished with an abandon. But it was like the mouse was totally missing.
So now I'm being punished for bugs in the game and whatnot and I'm banned for 30 minutes.
I don't even know if I want to play this game anymore. Like I said I've had like the worst day today in a very long time and now the only escape I got to this f'ed life is some game that decides to just punish me even more.
So I can't even escape my horrible reality anymore in one of the few games I even like rn.
So are you trying to let people kill themselves with this kind of behaviors or what?
Please fix this bug. I will change this review to "I recommend this game" if I have some proof it is fixed. Because I do really like this game but this kind of bugs can drive people insane. And it's not ok to punish people for things they are not even responsible off.
Overall I really love DotA2 but right now it's making me want to kill myself so I can't say I would recommend it to anyone anymore.
So one last time, please fix this. It's probably not all that complicated of a bug. Or please at least try.

WARNING to players:

This game has a forced win loss algorithm to keep players addicted, have less people leave, lower queue times in the lower ranks and of course money. Everyone I know who plays has many wins in a row, followed by many losses in a row over and over in an obvious pattern. Do not believe valves lies. There are also a lot of smurfs and boosters. The only way to rank up is to grind out a very long time playing unranked during loss pool, and ranked during win pool. They say the bottom ranks are like less then 5% of their player base but that is an outright lie. A large portion of long time players are stuck there no matter how competent they are. Anyone who denies this is just ignorant. All online competitive games have this. League of Legends devs  and Valorant admit it exists and they even have a name for it. 

This is outright fraud and these companies should be sued for these deceitful practices. The modern gaming industry is nothing but shady these days. Money and greed ruins everything.

Also games average like 40 mins to well over an hour now which is just too much time for 1 game. 

Players are very toxic and very few use a mic or communicate whatsoever and the ones that do are usually lame. 

Just avoid this game and watch it die. These games sound fun in theory and if your casual maybe but if you want to rank up, it isn't one bit fair.

If you can't create a whole 5 man team, you will enjoy all the great things like blaming, flaming, shouting insults (usually in russian), hearing insults of your mom, of your dog, of your dog mom and your mom and your dog in a bed. You will lose many games just because someone stops playing and gives up, usually in combination of all the things said before. You will hate it and you will want to quit. And you will come back. Because the game itself is really, really good.

I played this game a lot since its beggining. I have over 30k hours playing it because for me its the perfect game. Sadly valve is a terrible company that is ruining the game for profit. Game is very poorly optimized, the matchmaking system is a mess. And the report system is absolutely broken. If you have connectivity issues every 15-20 games be prepared for getting a low behaviour score and being muted although it has nothing to do with behaviour and has everything to do with poor optimization of the game. Meanwhile griefers happily play day in day out and you have the same players constantly ruining other peoples games and instead of getting permanently banned they dont get punished as much as someone with a poor connection.

So thank you valve for being such a terrible company and ruining one of the best games ever by pandering to profits and making DotA more and more like LoL.
It takes a lot of time to learn but really fun to play just ignore a lot of toxic players.

Alright, since I'm close to hitting 1k hours I guess I'll finally drop my review in the bucket.

In the League vs DotA debate I have always considered myself a League of Legends player. Not because I think it's better necessarily, but because I just started playing it at the very start and saw no reason to learn something else since I was already entrenched and none of my friends played DotA and didn't want to learn. Despite this, DotA's reputation as League's deeper and more mature counterpart continued to make me curious and after reading reddit and watching some youtube videos, I decided to try it for the first time and bounced off within a week or two. This began a cycle that would repeat. I'd play League for a few months, bounce over to DotA due to frustration with League, and then I'd bounce off DotA again after a week or two because the game's hard lol.

Even so, this game is good enough that I cannot stop myself from coming back. Like a toxic relationship with great sex. I am powerless and at this point have accepted that I'm a DotA player, whether I want to be or not.

Game has been heading downhill for years now. I technically left about 7 years ago with an mmr peak of 6400 having been achieved back in late 2012/early 2013.

The biggest correct criticism of this game is how the developers have for 7+ years now kept pushing the game in the direction of "less uniqueness in any heroes or hero classes and make the game a League of Legends clone" to the point now that every hero and hero mechanic type that USED to be unique and powerful because of a timing window for use is actually useless and can be countered by a huge number of no-brain heroes with automatically-done mechanics. 

They just hit 1 button and your high iq 20 button timing windowed tactic is now worthless. Heroes like Meepo and Broodmother or Nature's Prophet (or any ex-junglers) have been utterly destroyed and basically shouldn't even be in the game because its so easy to counter their much-more-complicated styles with a bunch of 1 button auto-mech abilities and heros.

Player numbers or not, this game peaked increasingly-long ago due to their wrong direction of development and "balancing". The mmr system is still "modified elo" aka "we're too fking stupid to realize this system doesn't even fit this model of game" and until the fix fundamental problems like these with the game, it will never be any good again.

Try something else, if you were looking for fun and a good future of a game, this one ain't it.

For the first time in history of dota 2, a P2W mechanic was introduced as part of Dota Plus and since there was no consequences for Value, this gonna continue to grow. Not the game I started about 5 years ago. So, only playing unranked, turbo and custom games.

Detailed answer (particularly for nerds): 
Avoid list of dota plus is an example. I have not done a global stats to have a better estimation, but you can follow these steps to understand the effectiveness of it:
1. gather large amount of lets say 100 recent games of players in same bracket
2. find matches that same teammate appeared more than twice (ignoring friends)
3. calculate win/loss ratio: now it is expected that you have 50-50 ratio even in this subset which is random enough
4. Add teammates with lower than 25% win/lose ratio to avoid list
5. If matchmaking is working, then you would still end up with new teammates that have below 25% win/lose ratio but this is not the case at least in cases where I checked.

Note that I might be wrong and only the examples I checked are following this pattern, but statistically it is easy to verify given the vast amount of matches available publicly. I will do it in future and publish it.

Remark: probably you have heard of the joke: "forced 50-50 ratio" which means matchmaking is not doing fine and it forces lose/win by doing a full stomp matchmaking rather than a close one. So it means you can manipulate the matchmaking as it is not robust enough.

This is the best MOBA. It has the most depth, is the most interesting to watch, and has the highest quality gameplay. There is no surrender button because there is ALWAYS a way to win. You can be a mechanically good player that clicks a lot or a very chill player with a lot of knowledge and good communication skills. There's demand for both, and you can climb the mmr ladder without being an emotional teenage mid player with good fingers. 

This is the most satisfying game to get good at, but this game requires an intense time investment. And some players invest that time and never get good, some things just don't click.

This game is *so* good but it is painfully mismanaged. The game is getting visibly worse over time and almost all of my veteran friends have left this game. These aren't noob once in a while players either, these were all top 100-500 players that were highly immersed in competitive. Granted, time does pass and people have IRL responsibilities, but I still game, they still game. Just not this game!

1. No love

I am not convinced Icefrog(the game's creator) still works on this game. There seems to be no depth to any of the patches besides funny whacky micro mechanics that take 2 minutes to master. Over the last few years there has been a layering of new micro mechanics but a severe dumbing down of the essential macro gameplay that made this game good and dynamic to begin with. New heroes are cool, but the novelty fades quickly and still doesn't really change the macro play of the game.

The community has enabled Valve to put minimal effort into the game as long as skins and chests come out a few times a year. I do not at all blame Valve for doing this, because this is what the community wants and it generates money, but everyone has to wake up and realize that the more you beg for skins the more Valve is going to neglect gameplay changes for the quick cash.

The map has not substantially changed in over 2 years. It could actually even be more than that, but I don't care to check. Map changes drive creativity, thought, theory crafting, and meta changes! But instead we have a *dry* ooga-booga dual lane meta where players have sunk into lazy repetition(as does happen when patches eventually stagnate). And most people have forgotten how to play the game outside of a dual lane meta. It's actually really disheartening. ‚Äì
Over time this game has become more "win lane win game" because of gradual power creep that has been exacerbated by the dual lane meta. For a very very long time Dota was a game that could be won in many many many different ways, and there were plenty of educated tradeoffs you could make in games. Many of these tradeoffs are not really worth it anymore.

Remember recently when players realized the game was dying so they made a community tutorial and Valve just yoinked it and did double work for the same goal? The community is getting smaller, but they‚Äôre still trying to bring the game back. As I've said, the game is good. But Valve has proven to be "in their own way" and as time passes they seem to be more milking the game for any pennies left than putting TLC into it.

2. Competitive

Did anyone watch the last TI(2021)? Remember how exciting it was to watch VP play because they were being so creative with their drafts? The VP captain said that it was frustrating for their team to play the game in the current meta. I still remember his statement clearly: "One team has tide, the other team has doom, they both stall the game until second Rosh and then hope they win the fight, and if they win that fight they win the game. We don't like that so we tried something different!" I have never heard something like this said since I started watching in 2012. I've heard "patch is stale", but never "the game is a coinflip".

Dota2 shouldn‚Äôt be a ‚Äúcoinflip‚Äù game.

And the state of getting into competitive? This is something that I actually have firsthand experience in, so read what I'm about to say very carefully. Do *not* try to become a pro player. It is not worth it. It does not pay. It is a losing gamble. It will not fulfill you. You will make more money working at Walmart for 1 month. Anything that is not T1 competitive in Dota2 is a barren wasteland. There are no tournaments for T2 players to play in to make money. There are no sponsorships. There is only DPC which pays a painfully small amount for the amount of time + commitment required to play in DPC. 

Where does all the money go? Only the top teams that qualify for TI(16 teams across many countries) get paid, once a year. The top 2 teams win the lottery, everyone else gets a year‚Äôs salary. The last major(non TI event) paid 50k to first place, and mostly T1 teams(and some established T2 teams) play in that. Just remember that the 50k prize is for first place, everyone else gets next to nothing. If you don‚Äôt win 1st out of 16 teams? Well too bad that 10k to one player potentially being their year‚Äôs salary shrinks to 0. There is NO money outside of that going to any teams in T2 and lower. There might be a one-off tournament from time to time but it‚Äôs nowhere near enough money to live on. And why does it have to be a livable amount of money? Because the game is so complex that you need to be playing and learning *constantly* in order to achieve a level of skill viable for competitive.

T1 players have a monopoly on good gameplay, and T2 players generally do not have enough exposure to play quality games and absorb knowledge from T1 players. To any solo ranked players reading this: No, you're solo ranked mmr does not represent your skill in competitive. Competitive is a different beast. If your solo ranked mmr mattered then a lot of really bad top 100 players I know would be playing in TI. There are plenty of Divine players I know that I would rather play with competitively than some top 100 players. Solo ranked is a game of repetition, not skill.

Take a good hard look at the player profile photos in the next DPC you watch. Everyone in T1 looks comfortable, happy, and doing what they love. Everyone in T2 looks ill. It‚Äôs not their fault, it‚Äôs because they make almost nothing and spend most of their time refining their skills ever-so-slightly to still never make it in Dota. This is the cold hard truth. 90% of talented T2 players will not make it to a tournament that pays more than 5k$ to first place. There was a well known T2 player recently that killed himself, a complete and utter tragedy. If I had continued down the road through T2 I might‚Äôve been in a similar situation. There are no rewards. There are no chances. It‚Äôs a losing gamble and you will not win. Do not try to become a pro.

3. Community

The average Dota2 player is an overgrown man-child. Whiney. Aggressive. Certain. There are really cool people that play this game. I‚Äôve made great friends playing. But most of the people I‚Äôve interacted with have wished the most gruesome death upon me because I played the game wrong *in their opinion*. And most players have no idea what they‚Äôre talking about, which makes this especially hilarious. And the only way to get them to shut up is to 1-up them in one way or another.

The Dota2 Reddit, pretty much the largest place where people talk about Dota, does not at all represent the community. Everyone on Reddit puts on a nice face, but when they step into game they are a unique version of *absolutely awful*. It‚Äôs a toxic game. It‚Äôs a toxic community. If you want to excommunicate the toxic guys, you‚Äôll get rid of the entire playerbase. ‚Äì

Conclusion

So the game is good. The community is awful. Valve doesn‚Äôt take care of any competitive players outside of T1. Competitive is dying. Valve doesn‚Äôt really care because the general playerbase doesn‚Äôt care. It‚Äôs getting less fun to watch. Gameplay is stagnating and dumbed down. Based on Valve‚Äôs actions over the last 2 years, nothing will change.

I've been a DOTA player since 2007, I was in grade 6, good 'ol days. But that was DOTA 1, a Warcraft III custom map, this is DOTA 2. The game has grown a lot since then. As a game that I grew up with, I would recommend this, nobody wants to see their childhood game die. As a game in itself, yes, it is still recommendable. You can counter heroes with heroes, counter heroes with items, and so on. There are imbalances, developers takes too long to fix them that some say they're almost non-existent, but the game is  still playable.

You have to set your expectations real. This is a MOBA where competition is beyond comprehension. Expectations per game are consistently high on all ranks, even in low rank games. You'll laugh in irony because teammates will expect you to be mechanically skilled and guess who's trash talking, a player ranked lower than you.
*As I was typing this, my player base rating got lower*

So as a beginner, you have to brace yourself, mute all comms, and focus only on improving. Develop your skill to ignore trolls and trash talkers, don't let them get to you. Some people get off by ruining other's day, yes, people like that exist even in real life, such sickness. I'm not saying everyone in this game is like that but if you see peaceful people in this game. Some are kind even if you are being stomped. Some encourage you when you make mistakes and gives you opportunity to fix them. They are rare, treasure them, and enjoy the game while it lasts.

Left LoL after finding this game around 1 year into playing league with friends in highschool(about 2014). I loved Dota right off the bat, the first thing that stuck out to me was that nothing except cosmetics can be bought or unlocked.

My League friends unfortunately never got it. I had to keep playing League with them, they refused to give the game more than a few hours each. Crushed me, still bitter about that to this day.

My love for Dota turned into a total obsession. I learned as much as I could, and played whenever I had the time. I was so inspired by Fear and Dendi's stories in Free to Play, I wanted to go the distance myself. I saw Dota as the one path for me to turn my boundless enthusiasm for strategy games into freedom from jobs I didn't love and a place I didn't want to live. The one rope I could use to pull upward into the future I wanted for myself. Of course, I decided to become a professional Dota player. 

This wasn't meant to be.

I was working as a busboy at the time and would work my shift and come home at night and play, then work again without any significant breaks. I would go 24-48hrs without sleep regularly to play as much Dota as I could without missing any work. Went to 1 LAN and placed 2nd, that was one of my favorite experiences in my life. Also met people from all over the world and learned words(mostly curses heh) from languages I would have otherwise never encountered, got to practice my Spanish a bit too. I grew so much as a person from the interactions I had in Dota. It shaped me.

Despite my extreme(and overzealous and counterproductive in retrospect) dedication I never got above 3.6k MMR. What happened instead was that I ended up in the mental hospital from playing between 5 and 22 ranked matches a day and not sleeping on top of working my full time job bussing tables(which I worked as hard as I could at as well). When I got to the hospital I was 135lbs(I am 5'11") and hadn't eaten or slept for 6 days, and was in full blown manic psychosis. Maybe if I had been provided for and fully supported during this time(and born without bipolar disorder) by my parents, I could have done it. We'll never know, but that's what happened. What I did was the epitome of the adage: "burning the candle from both ends". I flew too close to the sun and crashed and burned in the flames of psychosis and malnutrition. 

It's been almost 6 years since that episode of mania. Don't worry guys, I'm fine now, I sleep and eat every single day and have never had a recurrence of mania. I use medication to stabilize my mood whenever that pattern fails. Although I still enjoy the game a lot, I really only play turbo on and off since that's what I have time for. Gone are the dreams.

I know I spent a lot of time on this game, and I will regret somewhat my failure to become pro for the rest of my life. At one point it was everything to me. I lived, breathed, and dreamed it. That said, I look back on all that time with nostalgia and fondness. This is a game that will one way or another leave an impression on the rest of your life. You will either give up at less than 50 hours, or you will never forget it. 

How can I not recommend that?
It's a masterpiece.

P.S. 
Here's my dotabuff if you want to see my schedule during that breaking point: https://www.dotabuff.com/players/34646363/activity

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for his birthday from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Hi guys I usually do MASSIVE Reviews, however I have played this game all my life even during school years. 

This is probably the best hardcore competitive game you would ever play similar to CS/Wow/SC2(Starcraft)/ Battlefield. Same level of intensity and even more. The team work in this game is Astonishing. Communicating with your team while simultaneously casting hero spells/magical spells in the right time, rhythm of game-play, and Countering opponents successfully. Synergy is very important in this game. Dota 2 literately relies on TEAM SKILLS and TEAM CONTRIBUTION. 

The workshop is one of the best thing they have brought into the game. Tese amazing 3D artists constantly creating weapons, armour, costume designs and more. 

I can review this forever on 90% positive feedbacks. 


Gameplay 9.5 
Graphics 9.5  <<score Based on 2013-2015
Presentation 9.5 
Content 9.0 
Sounds 9.5
