If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I am a 56 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing Dota 2. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son recently started playing Dota 2. After less than a week, he already had 20 hours of playtime. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account to play with my Son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game since the 90's, so i was quite lost. I asked my Son for help and together we spend hours playing Dota 2. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my Son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. Dota 2 reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The developers (25-30 people for such a massive game) don't give a shit about updating the game. They are literally milking you with dota plus (a 5 dollar monthly sub for features that are hidden behind a pay wall) and releasing +-5 damage patches, yet there are dozens copium inhaling addicts who will continue playing this game because at the end of the day - this is the only game you are good at.

Competetive scene is a complete joke, we went from community tournaments with huge majors to online DPC systems with TI that will be forcefully prolonged for a whole month with the same quantity of games. The only reason esports side of the game still lives on is due to the tournament constantly beating the previous years prizepool, making at least 1 kotaku journalist to give a shit about this game. 
Want a comparison of devs who atleast try? Check Leagues (our favourite competitor) marketing and compare it with Dota's - its a joke, there is a reason why its more popular and its not because the game is easier or harder. 

The game that is a 5v5, does not incentivise players to group up and play together. Normal games are a waste of time where people tryhard regardless of the game mode. Ranked matchmaking is played mostly by solo players since it rewards +30 instead of +20 with party (the extra 10 really is worth isnt it)

There is no learning curve for new players since there is no tutorials and welcoming system + there are no new players to begin with. You will be greeted with people thrown into your game who are way above your level and have more expirience than you, so atleast 1000 hours is required to even understand what is going on. 

I fluently speak russian and english yet I get equaly annoyed by both of these groups of primates. The level of voice communication that you will expirience in this god forsaken game is worth mentioning in the last floor of Hell. The sheer amount of toxicity (not the casual FU, actual pure racism, hate and rage) is just out of this world. People playing this game should actually get clinically checked for basic communication and human interaction responses. You will spend the majority of your gameplay muting 8-9 players per game, and like I said before - playing solo is the only way people play. 

Overall - I had my good memories with the game, I used it as a coping mechanism during my darkest moments in life and I am grateful for those rare moments of pure bliss and ignorance. 
If you are still reading and considering playing this game - please don't. There is a whole steam library worth of great MMO's and single player games that can fill your day,

The most-played game on Steam.
Every day, millions of players worldwide enter battle as one of over a hundred Dota heroes. And no matter if it's their 10th hour of play or 1,000th, there's always something new to discover. With regular updates that ensure a constant evolution of gameplay, features, and heroes, Dota 2 has truly taken on a life of its own.

One Battlefield. Infinite Possibilities.
When it comes to diversity of heroes, abilities, and powerful items, Dota boasts an endless array‚Äîno two games are the same. Any hero can fill multiple roles, and there's an abundance of items to help meet the needs of each game. Dota doesn't provide limitations on how to play, it empowers you to express your own style.

All heroes are free.
Competitive balance is Dota's crown jewel, and to ensure everyone is playing on an even field, the core content of the game‚Äîlike the vast pool of heroes‚Äîis available to all players. Fans can collect cosmetics for heroes and fun add-ons for the world they inhabit, but everything you need to play is already included before you join your first match.

Bring your friends and party up.
Dota is deep, and constantly evolving, but it's never too late to join.
Learn the ropes playing co-op vs. bots. Sharpen your skills in the hero demo mode. Jump into the behavior- and skill-based matchmaking system that ensures you'll
be matched with the right players each game.

This game has a fair number of bugs in it, the community in actual players vs players is toxic. There are many rage quitters, leavers, afk'rs and bots. The only value this game has is in the solo vs bots, and even then, on the unfair mode.. everything you get hit with is always max +50%.

Chaos bolts from the chaos knight, ALWAYS at max rank, STUN FOR 6 FULL SECONDS. Basically your screwed if you get hit with it.

Another problem with the AI bots, is they will always GANK / Gang up on you with their full team, over any other target. If you however pose a threat to them, they will run away. They see you in stealth, they can always attack you if you have any clones. Knowing which of you and your clones, is always the real one. Expect to be the primary target, every time, every match.

I get that its supposed to be unfair, but, to have your entire team of bots, completely do stupid things like having a single one of them, charge into 5.. feeding them intentionally, time and time again. There's stupid, and then there's whoever coded this is really stupid.

The game design is stuck in the past. They care so much about being the evolution of Warcraft Dota, that they fail to evolve the gameplay. Play League of Legend. Hell, play Heroes of the Storm. I fully expect this review to get shit on, but the veterans haven't experienced something better, nor do they care to try. Do yourself a favor and stay away from this dated game. I put over 350 hours into this game, and after trying League, I came back once, only to realize how bad it was.
Edit: In one of my last games, another player said "Go back to League. This game looks better anyways." This speaks volumes about the Dota player base. They secretly know the truth, but are desperate for an excuse to why their game is better: "graphics."

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

A MOBA for the purests. It is better than LoL in aspects as you can deny creeps, keeping the tradition of the original DOTA 1 alive. It's right on par with LoL, but keeping the denying is great. I do think the hero selection and abilities are better, but to be fair that's subjective. Is this better than LoL, it depends if you like challenges and taking it to the highest level of MOBA's where include other elements of MOBA's not in LoL. However, LoL has better match making, but I think the game play is 100% better in DOTA2. 5/5 rating for me. I have LoL as a 5/5 rating too for the mildly simpler game play, though both have a super learning curve. Requires patience and understanding. Highly recommended if you enjoy MOBA's and are coming from LoL looking for something similar, but different.

You like Huey Lewis and the News? Their early work was a little too new wave for my taste. But when Sports came out in '83, I think they really came into their own, commercially and artistically. The whole album has a clear, crisp sound, and a new sheen of consummate professionalism that really gives the songs a big boost. He's been compared to Elvis Costello, but I think Huey has a far more bitter, cynical sense of humour. In '87, Huey released this; Fore!, their most accomplished album. I think their undisputed masterpiece is "Hip To Be Square". A song so catchy, most people probably don't listen to the lyrics. But they should, because it's not just about the pleasures of conformity and the importance of trends. It's also a personal statement about the band itself.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Despicable Me is a computer-animated media franchise centering on Gru, a reformed super-villain (who later becomes a father, husband, and secret agent), and his yellow-colored Minions. It is produced by Illumination and distributed by its parent company Universal Pictures. The franchise began with the 2010 film of the same name, which was followed by two sequels, Despicable Me 2 (2013), Despicable Me 3 (2017), and a future sequel, Despicable Me 4, expected to hit theaters in 2024; and by two spin-off prequels, Minions (2015) and the upcoming Minions: The Rise of Gru (2022). The franchise also includes many short films, a television special, several video games, and a theme park attraction. It is the highest-grossing animated film franchise and the 15th highest-grossing film franchise of all time, having grossed over $3.7 billion globally.

The ‚ÄòNew Player Mode‚Äô and revamped tutorials doesn‚Äôt fix this games core problem with attracting new players‚Ä¶ That is to say, the legendary toxicity of the current player base.

As for me, I did enjoy this game for quite a while, but that ship has sailed. I simply do not have the patience anymore to deal with people with the emotional maturity of a preschooler, who mistakenly believe that losing a game is a death sentence IRL. Thanks, but no thanks.

Over 5000 hours of play. Although it is closer to 10k as I played the original on the WC3 engine back in the day. I am 39, a grizzled veteran of the Dota conflict. My tours of duty are numerous and not very distinguished. 
Can I recommend this game to you?
That depends. My friends and I were chatting, all of them long term Dota addi...players too, and we came to consensus that if we knew what we know now about Dota would we begin playing it? 

The answer is No.  

This is not based on the game itself, it is a good game. It is constantly evolving and the community and Valve take active measures to keep it fresh. The problem is the insane amount of knowledge you have to have in order to play this game well. The learning curve is more like a learning wall, and it is legendary. A wall that you hurtle towards in a vehicle made entirely of ignorance and naivety, with no breaks. 

Sure, you can potter around with Sniper or Axe and have fun messing with bots, but competitively, you will be eviscerated. The fun will leave your body faster than you can produce it. That's right, this game is a fun vacuum. To this day, with decent W/L stats on most of my heroes I am made to feel like an absolute novice. I will have my ass handed to me everyday on multiple occasions.  Have you ever wanted to be told to format your computer? Uninstall Dota and Windows? This is your kinda game. 

Does it hurt? A bit, the mental scarring has lead to a sort of anaesthesia, brain-damage if you will. This is good, because you need to forget quickly; the losses, the team mate on team mate brutality, the ? and tips flying at you EVERY SINGLE GAME. Don't know what ? means, you'll find out and when you do you'll realise you're just as pathetic as me. A slave to your addiction, a pawn in Valve's schemes. Oh, you'll want to stop playing, you'll tell yourself you won't play ever again. But, you will, you'll dance to Valve's tune like a pathetic marionette. Eventually, you'll end up like me, bitter, twisted, brain-damaged. . .

Wait, what was I talking about? Time for another game of Dota.

Sometimes you come across a game and you don't know what the hell is going on. So you play for five hours and it's a pretty fun time. Then you play for twenty and, though you still don't know what's going on, you have some great games and some awful ones, some highs and some lows. You sink more and more time into it until you hit a hundred hours, learning more about the game and more about how much you suck at it. But it's not enough. You want more. You're tired of trash teammates and annoying enemy picks but you push through. You keep playing. You watch some professional players and see how much better they are than you. You get invested and support teams in your region. Another hundred hours goes by. And they keep going by until you hit a thousand - and it's done. You've made it. You've conquered the hill that stood before you and you can now confidently say that you've achieved your goal for the past thousand hours. You are no longer in the dumpster and merely in the trash: it's time to start learning the game for real.

This game might be fun if it weren't for all the over-complex game-play, the smurf accounts, the stigma of playing it, the way matchmaking works, the community, the aesthetics of the game and the controls/key-binds. Oh wait, this game could never be fun in any capacity! This is a completely garbage game that is fueled by the mass hysteria that surrounds it just the Call of Duty crowd. It is incredibly complex, too much so, because to keep the hype going you have to continually add new things to the game because people can't leave well enough alone. If you were to try and understand how to play, good luck getting help from the community. They are some of the worst, all there is to it. Wanna try your luck in matchmaking 'cause you don't need no-one to teach you nuthin'? Well good luck there partner, the matchmaking will repetitively match you with someone who has hundreds, if not literal thousands, of hours more than you. Hypothetically, let's just say the matchmaking "works as intended" for once and you get matched with people leveled such as yourself and - GOTCHA! In my professional estimation, I would say roughly 50% of the people who are "new" players are actually veterans who get tired of the competition and just want to feel good about themselves. Smurfs. Finally, lets say you just want to try to fake some team-play and play in a match with bots........ Well in that case enjoy messing around with the atrocious key-binds until you have something of a control scheme worth playing with because the default one is almost unplayable, at least when playing against anyone who knows what they're doing (almost everyone as a reminder). Finally, after spending the last 5 hours and 41 minutes fiddling around with this 'game', you get to tell your other friends that you've been playing Dota 2 all day! Yea, don't play this thing.

It's me, U Thant. I have a clear definitive history of taking things in matter and making things more "apparent". For that fact and that fact alone, you can trust me. This game is a psychological experiment that tests your mentality and capability and last but not least, your commitment to a game that will give you pleasure and anger. You probably watch Ti and expect something greatness but no. No, arcane isn't LOL likewise, spectating something and playing the game yourself is a totally different circumstance. You will have to crawl through countless varieties of toxicity and grief, endure throw and smurfs. You ever heard of "The great filter", these kinds of things are not one time thing. They exist in every game, every rank, everyday in every universes with different possibilities. Once you are addicted to this game, you can't run away but you can "hide". But you will always ALWAYS come back to this game. That's why dota still exists and is dying at the same time.

Back then, my classmates and I would play CSGO and DOTA 1. We would battle each other out and make fun of mistakes and fails after the game. It was full of joy back then and we eventually became friends. But as more school works pile up, only some of us continued to play. We no longer do lobby battles since we were lacking members. We used to be 15, but only 5 are left. I can still remember the time that when we would play DOTA 2 all night. It was fun despite only some of us are actively playing. Did I mention that we would be together in real life? We played all night as seat mates on cafe's and that would make the occasion even special. And now, after we graduated last year, only I alone, is active. Fifteen to one real quick. It's kinda sad.. I mean, I can't blame them for not playing anymore. We're now adults. We now need to work in order to survive unlike when we were still students. Most of us now have jobs, others have families. It's quite sad and lonely but I guess I still have the gaming fire in me haha. Maybe that's the reason why I still play. Or maybe I just missed the old days. DOTA 2 is a remake of DOTA, which was a custom map on Blizzard's Warcraft 3.  Almost all of the heroes you can play are based on art models directly ripped off from Warcraft 3.  So you have "game creators" who really just took the character models of Warcraft 3 and map style of Warcraft 3 and make it a little higher resolution, then sell it as their own.  In theory the game is quite awesome, and can take awhile to actually learn if you are new.  To make items you must combine several other items and at times even buy recipes.  Unlike the original DOTA where someone on the time has to spend their precious gold to buy a courier (usually the "support"), DOTA 2 gives everyone their own courier from the start, which seems to automatically upgrade itself during gameplay.  The heroes are beyond imbalanced.  Thus even with some 100 heroes to pick from, you will see the exact same heroes over and over.  These usually include Anti Mage, Pudge, Bounty Hunter, Drow, and Meepo.  The imbalance of this game is obvious, as you will think you are doing good at level 11 or so, only to realize the Meepo on the other team is level 25, and has a full inventory.  Many people also play the Troll, who can put his victim in an endless stun deadlock, and kill you while you cannot move, attack, use any abilities or items.  There are also observer wards that you may buy, but take a long time to re-stock.  These observer wards can be planted to remove the fog of war in an area and give everyone on a team vision of that area.  There are also sentry wards used to reveal invisible heroes such as Riki or Bounty Hunter.  If you are on a really bad team then no one wants to buy these, as you have to spend your precious gold on the wards instead of items.  There is a Tome of Experience that spawns every 5 minutes or so, but greedy allies usually buy it immediately, so good luck ever getting it.  The Matchmaking System is HORRIBLE, and can take over an hour to find a match.  Yes, I have actually sat waiting over an hour for a match and still not found one.  The "devs" or people who run this game have an insane banning system setup as well.  If you do the slightest thing wrong -- disconnect from a game, take too long to pick your hero, or even something as simple as write text to your allies such as, "Let's defend here," you may get reported by all of the other players like they are vultures.  In fact, they could report you for being the best player and they are jealous of you, or for no reason at all.  Then you will be communication banned or placed in "Low Priority Matches" which are almost impossible to get out of.  The people who run this game are very biased on who they punish or don't.  All kinds of people who harass, troll, and such are never punished.  Meanwhile you will get sent to Low Priority because you got the most kills and everyone in the game, even the other players on your own team are jealous of you and all report you.  You can also buy skins or cosmetics for this game, and some of them cost over $100.  Yes that's right.  They charge outrageous prices for skins.  Can you imagine being communication banned endlessly, or sent to Low Priority over and over, and then wanting to buy 50$ or 100$ skins?  You'd have to be a masochist for that.  They also have a Battle Pass, which costs money as well, but I WOULD NEVER GIVE THESE PEOPLE A PENNY.

We all have that one game that we just fall in love with so dearly that it becomes more to us than a game.  For me, that is DotA 2.  Every weekend, my friends and I would play the Saturday battlecup (we eventually got pretty good), and they are some of the best experiences of my life.  While this game is very hard to learn and impossible to truly master, the journey is worth it.  DotA is a lot like life.  You have an idea of what you want to do and a plan to get there, but things change and get in the way, and those times, the times things get in the way, are when you can express yourself and show who you are.  That is what happens in every game of DotA. Your plans don't go perfectly, but then you get to adapt and show off who you are through a game that anyone can enjoy.

As someone who's invested well over 160 hours into DOTA 2 (and yes, I'm aware that that is not a lot by the standards of many core players), I have to say that I'm truly discouraged.  I'm not discouraged by the gameplay - far from it.  Rather, it is the extreme toxicity of the playerbase that goes un-moderated that has made me consider leaving the game altogether.  

During my time with DOTA, I have been frequently told by other players to "F*** off" and other worse expletives while trying to cooperate in team style fashion.  Worse, I'm practically a baby compared to the other players that I am playing against in unranked (you have to play 100 hours of unranked before you can play ranked) and I fear trying new characters because I know that, inevitably, someone is going to cuss me out - either over a live mic or over chat - if I perform poorly.

At one point, I even had one player tell me to "Go die.  Literally please go die of cancer or something awful."  I'm really disheartened, because the game that I loved while playing "New Player" mode was quickly one that I grew to hate while playing unranked against players who are certainly better than me (and know so, and want to tell me so over and over again).

There will certainly be some who see this post and say, "Well then you should just GET BETTER and then people will quit being rude to you."  

I disagree wholeheartedly.  I think there are two solutions to fixing this problem of utter toxicity, verbal abuse, and beratement.  

1) Valve needs to ban players (at least for a period) when they are nasty towards other players.
2) More importantly, "ranked" play should be available instantaneously.  This AT LEAST ensures that a player that is newer is playing in some sort of hierarchy that likely matches their skill level.  Ranked play should be based on role type (support vs. carry) and/or character chosen.  This would give older players the versatility to try new characters without having to try them out on professional level players.

Valve, do something about the toxicity and I will gladly come back.  You've got a great game, and I'm sure that there are some great community members out there, but my experience as a new player has been downright shameful and has literally made me throw in the towel.  I may be one person, and some may argue that I take offense too easily, but I don't think so.  I think you've got a serious business problem here that will cause new players to turn away from the game quickly if you don't take serious action.

Valve is lazy.  If you are an American, there are better MOBAs that actually make it fun to play with others.  I have played this on and off for 10 years, recently giving it another try. 

Here are the basic issues:

- Valve tried to make people choose support with their new system.  Well their system doesn't work.
- End game MVP system is arbitrary.  You could carry your team as support.  Guess what, a dumb simple carry like drow or sniper will get the MVP over you.
- If you queue in on English speaking servers, you won't get English speakers
- If you play with a terrible player, you used to be able to vote end with no penalty.  Now you have to waste your time.  This made it way worse as you waste hours here and there.
- If a player throws the game, its still considered a loss.  Pretty easy to not penalize team players by not giving them the loss and filter out bad actors Valve, but you don't.
- Characters are still unbalanced, go check the win loss rates of the noob heroes and you will see.

I had a game with 43 kill assists as Treant that went an hour.  One player threw it at that point by not using their hero.  Another just ran the whole game to get as low death count as possible to the detriment of the team.  These aren't exceptions.  They are archetypes.  So enjoy your 2 v 4, 3 v 5, 4 v 2, etc. variations of what should be a 5 v 5 game.  Those rare 5 v 5 games were why I played and came back but after playing again I realized they were about 1 in 30.  Thats 20ish hours to have one fun hour while wading through the dregs of humanity.

In all of my hours of Dota I've wondered why I play the game.
To conclude this thaught I have decided to post this review based on my personal experience and that which I have seen from several friends playing the game.

So lets get real, for your average player this game will be a no brainer, spells items etc learn and move but for the new bloods I would recomend to learn as much as possible and practice with several different heroes as you progress on your journey with Dota 2.The game will get challenging and will almost always push you past your limits to always improve, from easy teamfights to massive strats, this game will require you to teach yourself how each of these heroes work individually and how they work in a team, the game is completely team driven which means if one messes up the others will have to reap which he/her has sown.

The game will seem hard at first to most and over complicated, I can promise you that, but don't lose hope cause in the end you will grow a liking to it.

From broken mechanics and strats to playing with both insanely good and immensly new players you will always have to work out a way to play with the team.

All out enjoy.
And have a great day further gamers.Hope this helped.

Hello ! My name is Jason and I almost have 3.2k hours in this game omg ... (3183 hours played ) . I am gonna share my experience of myself playing this game . Please enjoy ^^

This is one of the best games I've ever played so far . The complexity of this game is definitely at the top ... From all different kinds of heroes to all different kinds of mechanics are in the game . The best MOBA in my opinion . The unlimited amount of things that you can do in this game with the right team of heroes and players is mesmerizing . I used to play this game casually ever since i was a small boy  but i only started playing this game seriously since last year ( 2021 ) due to Covid arising . i used to spam unrank with my friends and cousins when one day  i decided to try rank for the first time . And just the pure feeling of happiness when i ranked up was extra ordinary and i could not stop . i used to practice and play ranks in the mornings and play unrank with my cousins during the night . i started to get a lot better in this game . i ranked up from uncalibrated  to crusader during my early ranking up phase . 

i got stuck at crusader for a while as my school reopened and i quit playing for a few months . When my school ended i started playing again and i started spamming rank games . i watched youtube videos ( bsj , proguides etc ) , pro games to improve and be a better player . i had promised myself to at least reach legend rank . all of my grind worked as i ranked up to archon . And that was huge for me because for me at that time , archons were really good players . i was stuck at archon for a while again ... half of it was cause i still had room to improve and other half was cuz my school restarted again ... but this time i did not stop playing , instead i played less but i did play . i was improving , i could feel it but something was missing . i was not playing to improve rather i was playing to gain mmr .

 This playstyle got me to archon 5 but yep another rank up block . after a few weeks , my school closed and i started playing this game from morning to night . i had around 51 - 52 % win rate but this was hurting my health both physically and mentally . After all the grind i had one more win required to reach legend . My ultimate goal for dota , when i immediately lost 10 games in a row ... yes 10 .

 i got so mad after it , that i even uninstalled my game . i took a break for a month . when i came back , i promised myself to not care about mmr and only play to improve and after that i started winning like crazy ... its actually insane . my win rate rose up to 65% and i started to understand the game in more depth . i reached legend and kept playing when one time i even hit a 10-win streak taking me to legend 4 . I was really happy but after playing all morning and night for a while  ,

 i realised that all of this is not worth it . This is a great game and since it is a great game , it is also really addicting . I ranked up from the beginning to legend 4 without any recalibaration and i am really happy about it but the thing is , legend 4 is still not a high rank . its average at best in my opinion . I can keep playing and playing this game and rank up to divine but its still not worth it . Lets say hypothetically i even reach immortal playing this game .

 Then what? its still not worth it . yes i will be happy that i reached immortal but even immortal is average in my opinion . The only good 'rank' that i can see are Rank 200 - 1 Immortals . Only when u reach around that rank , its worth it . cause around this rank , you may have a chance to be selected to a pro team ( div 1 or 2 ) which is also very unlikely .. 

Even if you are selected to a team , its not guaranteed that bills will be paid . In order to earn money you have to win and winning is very hard at that level , because everyone is so good already and it also depends on luck . Lets say enemy gets a dd or rosh spawns just in team you lose a team fight , stuff like that ... I realised all of this and yea i have decided to quit playing this game .

 Im already a grown ass man . i turned 17 this year and i have to be serious about my future . if i was insanely good at this game then i would keep playing this game but even though i love this game , i also have to look at myself realistically . It was a fun journey for me .

 One whole year of serious Dota . Solo Adventure and Fun Time with friends and cousins . What a journey for me honestly .. However , One thing i am happy about is i did complete my promise of reaching legend from uncalibrated . i am currently legend 4 and not gonna lie i am happy . Even though its average at best but its a long way for me . Long way where i started from . Now i have to focus on my future , got dreams and a bag to chase . One day when i will finally  accomplish  my dreams , i will come back again and write about it . But till then goodbye Dota .

Some advice that i would like to give to others playing this game or wanting to start this game .
1. Always be kind to others and yourself . This game is really fun but can be really stressful at times as it requires alot of thinking and communication . And some people are just generally toxic and weird ..
but i would suggest to always be chill and if there are some people annoying you , instead of talking to them . simply mute them and focus on how YOU can play the best . Thats the best advice i can give .
Do not ruin games for others and do not let others ruin your game by annoying u , simply mute them :)

2. Watch videos on how to improve on youtube . You can just play this game casually but its never wrong to want to improve . I suggest watching BSJ , Proguides , Gamerzclass , You may also watch some pro games to learn how they play.

3. Never be afraid to take risks . Dont always make the same items or play with the same playstyle or go the same build every game . Try new things , try unique builds etc . 

4 Most improtant advice - TAKE CARE OF YOUR HEALTH !
Stretch after games , during draft - drink alot of water during games , excercise in the morning and evening . and make sure to eat your food . 
Do not neglect these things or u gonna face pain in the future ma boyyyy
.
.
Alright thats all i have to say .
Thank you for reading . Good luck with your jouney :)

DOTA 2 is not bad game, it's just not for everyone.
Like with every competitive online game, the game is not fun to play if you don't meet high skill requirements.
If you are new or casual player, you will often be placed in team with significantly more skilled players that might be able to carry you despite your lack of skills and obviously they will not be happy about that.
You will feel bad for ruining the game for your team because you were not good enough and it will be more and more difficult for you to enjoy the game.

It was fun to play at the very beginning and I liked the game, however once I've moved from new player mode to unranked play, majority of the battles were poorly matched, too stressful to play and even though I had few good battles, it's difficult to feel happy about one match where I made good contribution to the team when the number of battles where I was outmatched is significantly higher.

I can't recommend the game unless you are very good at MOBA or you don't mind playing only practice mode vs bots.

The matchmaking is dogshit. It will pair you against people far outside your skill level, and there's no way to surrender. Leaving early penalizes you. Games are anywhere from thirty to fifty minutes. You will lose.

Your teammates are dogshit. They speak russian or portuguese and will flame you if you make a single mistake, and then spam ping you as fast as they can click on their shitty 258 kb internet connection until you mute them.

After you mute them, they will teleport to your lane and try to gank. But that gank is not actually a gank, it's feeding the enemy team in disguise to make your lane have a massive disadvantage as well. They will ping you for this too.

The enemy team will be constantly spamming voice emotes after every kill, even though the score is three to forty two. If you complain in chat, they will make fun of you. If you try to make a play and die for it, they will tip you to mock you.

If you try to farm your jungle, it will have fifteen observer wards and thirty two sentries. Don't ask how this is possible, the enemy team only speaks russian anyway. Your team has 4 observers and 10 sentries stocked in shop because you have five carries and nobody wants to buy them.

If you try to farm lane, you will get hit with a rod of atos into a stun into a stun into a stun into a stun into a stun into a stun into a stun into a stun into a stun into a stun into a stun into a stun, and you will die. Somewhere along the line you got hit with Bounty Hunter's track ability, so you give more gold to the enemy team. Your jungle Legion Commander spam pings you for this.

At twenty two minutes, your team has no more low ground towers. You sit in your highground while the enemy farms the entire jungle and gets six slotted, while you clutch your shadow blade and two wraith bands and pray to a god that isn't listening they don't get Roshan. Despite a ward catching them going into Roshan, your support Nyx Assassin who only has tranquils and a dagon 2 scans Roshan, and then spam pings it. When the enemy Wraith King gets the aegis, Nyx dies to him trying to pop it. He does 20% of his health. He also doesn't press mana burn. He spam pings you for this.

They finally siege your high ground, and you get two kills. They have to back off because they dove your fountain and you can finally buy your farming item: Maelstrom. You walk into mid, push a tier one, and they all buy back. In the time it takes you to turn around because Dota has such slow turning, you get hit by three stuns, a Lion ult, a Lina ult, and then get spam pinged by your off lane Anti Mage who has a ring of health and a quelling blade.

You have buyback. You press it to try and play the game. The enemy Phantom Assassin dives fountain and kills you in one hit. The enemy team sits around and waits for their mega creeps that they spent the last 10 minutes hitting barracks for to end while they spam voice emotes and taunts. Your Ancient explodes after you respawn and die one last time. The final score is 10 to 82. You have six kills. Your team blames you in broken english for feeding.

You queue up again.

This isn't me. Every time I log onto my pc I see another few hours spent in this game. "why you playing dota" "caught in 4k" my friends say. I have no control here. Through god knows what virus this shitty League of Legends ripoff has wormed its way into my steam library and has been playing itself ever since. What a sick joke. They could've just hijacked my computer and ransomed my files, or turned it into a remote bitcoin miner, or some godforsaken proxy for Nigerian scam-mongerers. Instead, they do this. Degrade me and ruin what little sanity I have left. I have to live with this. 86 hours spent playing DOTA 2. That will never go away. A permanent blot on my reputation as a human being. Nothing will ever make this better. Its driving me mad. I cant sleep at night any more. I toss and turn in a paranoid agony with the thought that tomorrow I will wake up and my playtime will be even longer. I've started sleepwalking, waking up in strange places with no recollection of how I got there. Sometimes when it gets quiet I can almost hear whispers "just install it" "give it a go" "how bad could it be?". Maybe I'm just hearing things, but with each day - and every new unaccounted hour logged into this game, the voices get louder. This game is an abomination and will haunt me for the rest of my life. Pray for me, I'm already dead.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

As Someone who studied this game in his early college years, I am proud to say I put in work learning a couple of characters. That being said, "THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE." If you're a casual gamer that likes shoot 'em ups and easy progression, you may be better off with another MOBA because this one is the godfather of them all. Not only does it require your basic understanding of how to play these types of games, but each character is so unique that you'll end up reading guides and watching youtube videos just to get considered "decent" on your favorite hero. Take for instance my example, out of the almost 500 hours I put into this game, about 400 playable hours was focused on Bounty Hunter. During my peak, I would end the average game with about a 5:1 K/D which isn't bad but isn't top tier either. Seems like quality > quantity right? However, I promise you that if you aren't studying this game, you're going to end up getting called trash in the comments. Take it from me, DOTA 2 is insanely fun, but requires a ton of dedication.

I used to have a lot of fun with Dota 2, and while I think Dota is a great game at high-levels of play, I cannot recommend it to players because the matchmaking suffers from the same problem as every other team-based game; you are at the complete mercy of your team and any player who throws. Everyone's ranked journey begins at low MMR; but at low MMR, every game is decided from the actions of a troll: a win is achieved when there is a troll on the enemy team, and a loss is achieved when a troll is on your team. Of course, this is not always the case, but the average player will have the average game decided by a troll the majority of the time.
The mechanic of the game and its complexity makes it unique.

Never have I seen a more dynamic strategy game. You CANNOT go into a game with a fully premeditated strategy and expect to execute it flawlessly: While there is a lot you can predetermine based on the heroes involved in the match there is far too much that is based on how your allies and enemies play that will force you to change your plan as you go.

Every Hero also feels strangely unique despite usually sharing a few mechanics with other heroes. Honestly a really well designed game where you have never really lost the game (Unless your team is horribly discoordinated which definitely does happen) and every hero is perfectly viable (Although some are much harder to use than others and are often not worth using if you're concerned with efficiency).

I love Dota 2, but I could never recommend this game for new players. The community is filled with some of the most toxic people imaginable. And the sad fact is, this game stopped being fun years ago. The people cling onto it because of the memorizes and good times they've had on this game but never seem to enjoy it the way they used to. 

Since you have such older, veteran players, new players are criticized, ridiculed, and thrown several racial slurs. And because theses veteran players keep coming back instead of moving on, they act pompous and almost as if they have some form of seniority in the game (which they do) and can't take any form of criticism. Rub someone the wrong way and that person will go out of their way for the next 30 mins to an hour just to antagonize others.

I highly do not recommend this game to new players. I don't care if you like the Netflix Dota Dragonsblood, go watch Arcane instead, they did it better anyways.

This game saved my life.

I am 38.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

I respect DOTA 2 for being an excellent game but there are things that make this unplayable for me. 1) Comeback mechanics - in a competitive game (e-sport really) there is no place for comeback mechanics. If a team plays well they deserve to get an advantage. By giving advantages to the losing team, DOTA 2 is essentially invalidated as a sport. It becomes casual like Mario Cart, where the player in first will get weak bananas and the player who is last gets 3 red shells. DOTA 2 is still valid as a game, but not as a sport. 2) Neutral items - add random and un-required complexity to a game that was already infinitely complex. 3) Toxicity - the community is highly toxic even in unranked games. You can mute voice and text chat but then the teamwork elements of the game suffer. Human nature is to blame others for our shortcomings and with the anonymity of the internet DOTA 2 is rampant with unpleasantness. There are infinite ways to play DOTA and there will always be someone who takes exception to your decision making. It is a shame because as I said at the start, I have respect for DOTA 2 as a game.

One of the best online games of the century. The game doesn't have a good story mode but it is meant to be a multiplayer game. It is a 2d/3d game which involves strategy, teamwork and competitiveness. It's got a huge community since the game is free. The community is not that bad but not good either, often cursing each other for teammates faults but it's how they get along to win. The community is filled with players all over the world , some may speak English some may not which you need to get adjusted to(it's fun to learn words from another language). Gameplay is just awesome, the ability effects are brilliant and can't believe it's such a small size game. The game constantly gives you updates which may involve bug fixes and new features. 
The only thing which is not free is the cosmetics although you do get them in form of drops. All the 30 plus playable characters have brilliant effects, unique dialogues and abilities which set them apart. Another awesome feature is ranked gameplay, which brings seriousness to the game and helps your team to thrive towards victory. If you have not played this game yet you have missed out on something amazing. Getting used to the game at first can be difficult but it's better later on.

1. No matter how you master your role either you are a carry or a support If your team does not want to win you almost never will.

3. Sometimes when everything seems fine, you almost won the game but no "This guy" decided to press buy back and destroy all his items because you have another teammate who is  long-tongued.

Please if you want to play tha game it is fine, do whatever you want but do that in Allpick not at the Ranked games(people want to gain MMR and play serious DOTA2 without being distracted by the other ruiners.

After 1310...hours of my life spent on this game... I should firstly probably admit I have a gaming problem...But that's a separate issue to writing this review. 
This online battle arena is one of the most popular versions for a reason,

That reason is probably in part, because it's free to play.
However the battle arena offers you the ability to pick from over 100 different heroes, and fight on an equal footing with your team of 4 other Heroes against 5 adversaries. The mission is simple, to destroy the enemies main tower. In order to do this you are required to battle your way through the enemy on 3 different approaches/ lanes and destroy anywhere from 3-9 towers.

In order to do this, you can buy items from a shop and level up your abilities. Doing this faster than the enemy is the way to win, and the only way to do it faster than the enemy is to kill more things. This naturally means you are in a race with the other team, and time is precious; everything including your death could mean you fall behind in the race. 




Because games typically last around 30 mins, games are intense, and people get passionate (Expletive*) off at the end if they lose. For those that know, this is what fuels the game it's ridiculously toxic community. And for those dregs of the community, including yourself (should you be rude or you just disconnect in a bunch of games) , you may end in a horrible mode called single draft- low priority. For the dregs of that community. This is a combination of players who aren't team players or have disconnected the game. There's not enough players here to be matched according to skill, so be prepared to get your ass kicked loads, especially if you're new to the game..You will be forced to play every hero, and you will have no idea how to play them. 

I should probably mention this is a team game, and the most successful teams stick to the roles: support/ carry. Generally speaking supports try to help their carries level faster, and their carries are responsible for bringing the late game hammer and smashing down towers. Within the 2 overarching roles there are different roles, initiator, nuker, durable, escape, etc... and heroes can be played in different ways to do fulfil these positions in order to win team fights and destroy towers, 

Good game, but be prepared to get very frustrated with the game.

Rules and Guidelines For Steam: Discussions, Reviews, and User Generated Content
These guidelines apply to all places in the Steam Store and Community where users can post content. This includes, but is not limited to, discussions, comments, guides, product reviews, screenshots, artwork, videos, tags, and Steam Workshop.

When providing feedback, posting information, or discussing a product in Steam, whether it‚Äôs negative or positive, please make sure you are being relevant, constructive and polite. Developers take feedback from all kinds of sources into account, even though they may not have the time to respond to every post or question.

Please note that Administrators/Moderators reserve the right to change/edit/delete/move/merge any content at any time if they feel it is inappropriate, abusive, or incorrectly categorized.

All users are subject to the Steam Subscriber Agreement and Steam Online Conduct.

General Rules
Do not do any of the following:

Flame or insult other members
Bypass any filters
Abuse or encourage abuse of the Post Reporting System
Post personally identifiable information (i.e. name, address, email, phone number, etc.)
Bump threads
Derail a thread's topic
Post links to phishing sites
Post spam (i.e. +1, 10char, rickrolls) or Re-post Closed, Modified, Deleted Content
Repetitively post in the incorrect forum (example: trade requests belong in trading forum)
Openly argue with a moderator
Manipulation of the User Review system or voting/rating systems
Content Rules
Do not post any content on Steam containing the following:

Porn, inappropriate or offensive content, warez or leaked content or anything else not safe for work
Discussion of piracy including, but not limited to:
Cracks
Key generators
Console emulators
Cheating, hacking, game exploits
Threats of violence or harassment, even as a joke
Posted copyright material such as magazine scans
Soliciting, begging, auctioning, raffling, selling, advertising, referrals
Racism, discrimination
Abusive language, including swearing
Drugs and alcohol
Religious, political, and other "prone to huge arguments" threads
No Backseat Moderating
Let the moderators do the moderating. Backseat moderating is when people who are not moderators try to enforce the forum rules. If you see a person breaking the rules, take advantage of the Report () button or simply ignore the offensive post(s), thread, or review.

Report Posts to Moderators
Should you observe a fellow Community member breaking these rules please report the post or item by clicking the

I remember when Dota 2 first came out, when everyone was still playing Dota1, and many friends didn't want to switch to Dota 2. However, under the amway of friends, after trying a game of Dota2, I could no longer extricate myself. More and more humanized game operations, rich game experience, fine graphics, exquisite game character models, and exquisite dubbing, there are always so many places to surprise you.

The charm of dota2 is not only the game, but also that it has an unparalleled international invitational tournament. TI series of competitions, in addition to TI1 is not watched live, other competitions, basically stay up late to watch live broadcasts. The most memorable is TI2, . As an iG brain fan, seeing iG's performance on TI2, the ship fat hands left the keyboard, raised his arms to mock the opposite, and finally held up the champion shield; saw that the big mother had been expressionless, walked out of the battle room, and was picked up by puppey's father; the moment he saw Shi Fo yyf smile, his heart was really extremely excited. TI3, the Chinese team collectively withered, but had to be impressed by the strategy and tactics of team A, and the final match between team A and Navi was really applauded. TI4, the Chinese team made a comeback, the big Mu Golden Immortal blocked the killing, the Buddha blocked the state of killing the Buddha, people were impressed. TI5, this is the year of newcomers, Sumail, ZAI, RTZ, maybe, CTY, leprechauns, this TI basically began to update.

IF you can get past the intense learning curve, this game is great. It is a slower paced moba with long fights and teamwork. Unlike a particular moba *cough *cough *league of legends, this game encourages you to work together with your team to win. If you like creating strategies to win a game and executing them this is the moba for you. That said there is still some micro to pay attention to such as last hitting and denying creeps, but the overall gameplay is largely focused on macro. If you want a moba that will test your ability to make plays and out plan your opponents this is the Moba for you.

That said, if you want something fast paced and quick fights, while the fights in dota don't last minutes at a time they  aren't over in a flash. The average game time of a dota match ive found is anywhere between 30-40 minutes, occasionally going to 50 minutes if the game is especially close. The game can feel slow at times and if you don't know where to be and what to do it can feel like there are spans of time in which you can't do anything. If you aren't interested in putting in many, many hours in learning and you are not interested in having anyone teach you the game I do not recommend trying to learn it.

This game goes out of its way to waste your time and is highly unwelcoming to newer players who want to learn.

1) games may be enjoyable at higher ranks, but this game is more enjoyable playing with bots as teammates than playing with real people at the lower ranks. I don't mind people not knowing how to play as everyone is learning, but the toxicity in chat is unbearable to the point where you just want to turn chat off. At that point, why play with other people at all? Better yet, why play this game at all?

2) games are way too long, especially at lower ranks, meaning that its hard to practice and focus on certain aspects of the game without sitting around in a 45-60 minute game. 

3) no give up option means you are sitting there waiting for an additional 10-15 minutes for the other team to end it. Sure there are the occasional comebacks, but its not worth the time wasted sitting around in the other 90 percent of losing games when I would like to hop into the next game to practice certain mechanics like say early game CS.

Will not try any other mobas again in the future.

dota and the genre it created is a bit of a mixed bag when it comes to multiplayer games imo
on the one hand it feels infinitely complicated with infinite room to strategize and theorize, on the other the skill factor can often feel limited with these autoattack RPG games, like you would boot up a game saying "i can't wait to make some plays" but then you really don't think there was a single play you could make that game. And the flaming is so ubiquitous no matter where if it be herald 1 equivalent normals or streamed top ranked games people will accuse each other of being "bad" presuming anyone cares or that it matters. it's honestly one of the most annoying things if you do try to improve or compete, since it actually is a very difficult game and to have people(often of very dubious credentials or merit) trying to make you feel bad for every mistake when there are so many to make ought to be highly annoying indeed! 
so I think it would help everyone to remember that you are playing a team-game with completely random people at the end of the day and to allay ones expectations appropriately, and i would recommend to stop playing when you do not find it fun.

Love it or hate it. This game is here to stay until we grow old. Played since 2005, during the 6.x series (still a noob till today). Was really not interested to play the sequel (Dota 2) at first but in 2014 (for love of the game) I tried playing again, felt left out for a few days, but kept plaing. Stopped for a year, back again in 2016 when TNC made noise in TI beating the crowd favorite OG in the lower bracket of main event who had Miracle in the roster also. Didn't want to stop but pandemic happened and I can't play because my low level pc was damaged during a flash flood back in 2018, would have loved to purchase battle pass that got 3 arcanas to give but no got no pc (purchased two bp in past TIs) watched almost all the games in TI 10 as long as I can (as I did in most major tournaments in the past) no playing or logging in (but kept playing in piso nets in my area) logged back again in 2021 (got a new pc, this time a better one, no gpu but good enough for dota not to freeze, it got ssd and acceptable ram) even with this new pc, I haven't really got the luxury to play for long hours since I'm also enrolled in culinary school. Currently following the ESL One Stockholm major.

For those who didn't tl;dr, thanks a lot ;)

Great game. Requires a lot of intellect and teamwork. 
It is like chess but on steroids. 
Love the fact that it requires so much thinking. 
I learn about life through this game. How to manage a team. How to motivate. 
How to apply pressure on opponent at the same time. 
If you want to click and don't use brain, this is not for you. 

1) Play normal if you want to relax after work. 
2) Play ranked if you want a challenge. 
Some servers a bit toxic. So beware, be ready to mute the negative team mates.

I can't imagine being a new player in the dota scene at this point, there's simply too much to learn and not enough easily-accessible resources for it. That said, if you're looking for a moba with more depth than League but doesn't deviate from the traditional formula too much this game is worth a try. The learning curve really isn't so bad if you are willing to take some time to mess around in bot matches or have a stack of friends who are willing to coach you, and you can now request community coaches as well.

Valve has done a good job pushing major updates every few months to shake up the meta and moment-to-moment gameplay which is probably the biggest reason why people still enjoy the game. The most significant shortfall is that there are not enough new players joining and/or staying, almost everyone in even the middling skill brackets has been playing for ~10 years. While that may show how much dedication the game's following has it's not a great indicator for the community mindset or overall quality.

Nobody reads reviews so here is easy japanese sweets recipe:

üëâ Ingredients

‚úÖ For the Filling:
2/3 cup water
1/2 cup sugar
1/4¬†cup dried anko powder, or 1 1/4 cups pre-made¬†anko, divided
Katakuriko, potato starch,¬†or¬†cornstarch,¬†for dusting

‚úÖ For the Mochi:
1 cup shiratama-ko (glutinous rice flour)
2/3 cup water
1/4 cup sugar

üëâ Make the Filling

1. Gather the ingredients.
2. Heat 2/3 cup of water and 1/2 cup of sugar in a small pot.
3. Add 1/4 cup of anko powder and stir well.
4. Cool anko filling.
5. Make 12 small anko balls and set aside.

üëâ Make the Mochi

1. Gather the ingredients.
2. Put shiratama-ko in a heat-resistant bowl.
3. Mix water and sugar in a separate small small bowl.
4. Gradually pour water-sugar mixture into shiratama-ko, stirring well.
5. Put bowl in microwave and heat dough for about 2 minutes. Stir the dough.
6. Heat dough in the microwave again, until dough inflates. Stir mochi quickly.
7. Dust a flat pan, as well as your hands, with some katakuri-ko starch. 
8. Remove hot mochi from bowl to the pan by hand. The mochi will be hot and sticky, so please be careful not to burn your hands.
9. Dust hands with more katakuri-ko starch and divide mochi into 12 pieces by hands.
10. Make 12 flat and round mochi pieces.
11. Put a piece of anko filling in the center of the mochi and wrap the anko by stretching mochi.
12. Round the daifuku.
13. Repeat process to make more pieces.

For a little bit of context, I picked up a key when the game was in closed beta back in 2011-2012, played one game against bots then quit because my laptop was too old to run it properly and also because I had no idea what was going on.

I still kept an eye on this game because its mechanics and depth allowed to do some really cool stuff.

I finally decided to get back to it very recently, but this time with a little bit of knowledge. I started playing against bots to try out some heroes but the broken AI made it a bit difficult.

Once I felt ready I jumped into normal queue and... boy what a mess.
The matchmaking is bonkers. As a new player, I get matched with/against veterans with 5k games and fully upgraded relics who expect you to be absolutely perfect in every aspect. Every game is a stomp, be it a defeat or a victory.

After a couple games, I got a conduct report (!) which showed that I had been reported twice despite never misbehaving. Basically, I got reported for being new which is insane.

I'm required to play 100 hours to queue for ranked games, but I don't think I'll have the patience to go this far because now that I think about it, I didn't enjoy any of the normal games I've played so far. I just wish I hadn't wasted all this time watching videos and reading the wiki.

TL;DR Stay the hell away from this game if you haven't played it for 10 years already as it is extremely frustrating and punishing for new players.

I've been playing this game for 6669 hours now... and well this game has not gotten old. The amount of trolls and salt in this game have not decreased since I first started this game and in fact I can assure you it's increasing by the day. Overall this game is worth the time and is a good place to go to when you're trying to escape from your real life problems.

[b] What can you expect as a new player [/b]

- This game has an extreme complexity depth, not only will you need to spend time to learn what each hero does.but also what each item does, laning, rotation, map layout + hidden spots, warding, last hitting, denys and hero combos.
- Be prepared to be scolded / reported and screamed at for the entire duration of the game by your team if you are new to the game and not pulling your on weight.
- If the level gap between you and your opponents is too large, be prepared to be killed in 1/2 hits.
- Veterans will abuse broken mechanics.
- Every patch will almost (100%) introduce something broken, be prepared to relearn each hero every patch.

This game turned me into a hardened gladiator. 

  I used to be archon, then my poor naive childlike mind was shattered by the toxic community, and soon I grew addicted to the downward spiral of a troll. Every spiteful natured denizen of the desolate hellscape that is ranked matchmaking that trolled my games by going afk or screaming racial slurs at me, usually in a foreign language drained me mentally. 

  Every time my support bought out our wards to plant in base turned me into the very monster that I feared would consume me one day, and I fear I may never be able to love again. Please heed my warning, there is no ranked season reset. No second chances, No alt accounts.
It doesn't matter if you're trying your best, if little Billy decides he wants to first time Primal Beast in ranked and feed 21 kills because they wanted to get drunk turn the game into an even bigger gamble with the mmr of the 4 other people on their team on the line for maximum dopamine points as the pay-off, and bragging rights in the form of "I was so fucked up and ruined the game for 9 other people and won anyways! I'm so good ;^)"

The mentality you must adapt if you want to climb in this game is; If you fuck up, it's your fault, if you get unlucky, you need to improve more, if your mental is weak, you should play a different game, because you will be ruined

The most you can hope for is to get a positive k/d/a every game, because winning is sometimes out of your hands.

I have to update my review of this game. My favourite game ever but the matchmaking has gotten worse and worse in the last 12 months that I've cut my hours down to almost 0 in the last 8 months from nearly spending every spare minute I had playing. It really is a shame because they worked very hard getting the toxicity out (still there but not as often), leavers etc but now it seems the matchmaking is all over the place not the mention the sheer amount of smurfs ruining the game.

I'm not against new players just if 1 team has a new player, the other should too but it has been the opposite. 1 team with a new player, the other team gets significantly better experienced players, completely unbalancing the game and wasting time for everyone, and the new player learning absolutely nothing.

I will continue to return every few months to see if it has improved but at the moment would not recommend this game to new players.

If you told me when I started playing dota 2 at 18 years old that I would be reviewing this game after 8 years and 13'000 hours, I would have laughed at you.
Let me put that into perspective: 541 Days and 16 Hours. Of dota 2.

I'm almost 26 now, and I don't really know what to think of this game. This game has had a large impact on my life. I was "addicted" to the experience, in ranked and matchmaking. I've learned a lot about myself and others. I've learned a lot about staying in charge of my emotions. I've also learned that emotions can easily lose you a game before its come to its conclusion. I've learned how to react instinctively to changing pixel colours.

But I've also relatively learned nothing.

Not to depress anyone reading this, but when I put all of this into perspective, thinking about what could have been, I could easily imagine how much better my life would be if I never started playing this game. Socially, I would have a stronger network. My education and eventual career would probably have had more longevity (I have played professionally as a dota 2 player, but grew a lack of interest in competing). But I can never be sure how drastic these differences are. Would the pros outweigh the cons? I have certainly met and interacted with a large group of people, because of dota2, at events, tournaments etc. Any dota 2 player that has sunk 2000 hours or so has probably had these thoughts: "what if I just did ... instead" or "what if I just played on a more casual level". The issue is, that dota feels more rewarding than other things, and that's a trap I fell into.

It is with a heavy heart that I admit that I don't think I can bring myself to play anymore. Took a long 8 years for me to grow out of this perfect fit, which is why I must review dota2 positively.

Thank you for all that you have done for me. Farewell friend.

Dota is an interesting ever changing game, but its nice that after all this time playing it there's always been one thing I can rely on. Bigots, racists, sexists, and assholes love to use the in game chat function, and just muting people isn't a robust option when they're also trying to call the shots and get other people to go in/dogpile you in chat. I've had a lot of fun in dota, but this game has driven me to tears at times, and many of my friends treat their own experience with Dota as an unhealthy addiction to something that continually brings them harm. Cannot recommend.

It really represents the peak of the genre and is a popular game for a reason.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

DOTA 2 FROM THE BEGINNER'S SIDE
REVIEW IN ENGLISH:
I started playing Dota 2 only recently, but I still played 200+ hours and I can express a beginner's opinion about this game.
It's worth starting with what this game is (below is a brief introduction). Dota is a team tactical and strategic game with elements of a computer role-playing game in which each player controls one hero, and, if the hero has the appropriate abilities, a certain number of additional creatures. During the gameplay, over time and depending on the success of his actions, the player gains experience by discovering new abilities of his hero, and the money he spends on buying various items. The main task of the game for each of the two teams is to destroy the enemy camp protected by towers.
In short, you choose one of hundreds of heroes, land with your team of five people on the map, pump your hero and break the towers, barracks and then the throne of the enemy, after which the game ends.
Despite the monotonous gameplay, Dota is a very interesting game, which leads to the question - why? Dota is made by its heroes. Each hero has his own abilities, features and style of play, and in each game both allied and enemy heroes are completely different.
In my review, I want to consider all the advantages and disadvantages of this game.
Positive aspects:
-MOBA genre (Multiplayer Online Battle Arena) is a very interesting genre of games. It is important not only reaction and knowledge of the game, but also strategic thinking. The game will definitely appeal to all fans of strategies, because to win, you need to think through a game plan, items to buy, actions and style of play depending on the selected characters.
-Variety of heroes. This has been mentioned more than once, and even here it is worth noting. There is everything here - from magicians to fish, and everything is interesting in its own way. At the moment, there are about 120 heroes in the game.
-Variety of game modes. If you get tired of playing the same scenario (in our case, Allpick, where you can choose any hero), you can try yourself in other game modes. For example, Single Draft. Here you are offered a choice of only 3 randomly selected heroes from different attributes - strength, dexterity or intelligence. There is also a section of the game library where you can play according to scenarios created by the players themselves. I think Dota 1x6 is the best, I advise everyone to play it someday.
Now about the negative sides:
- Complexity. Yes, this is the main disadvantage of Dota. No matter how hard the developers tried - and by means of fairly affordable training, and with the help of manuals, and much more - dota still remained and remains a very difficult game. Many people decide to abandon the game because of its complexity, but I assure you, you should not do this. Check out the manuals on other sites, play with bots, master the basic mechanics and very soon you will be able to enjoy the game in peace.
- Balance. After playing a lot of games, I realized that the balance between dota heroes is very poorly developed. Regardless of the items, knowledge and skills, some heroes will always be stronger than others, and it is very sad that the balance does not improve from update to update. The developers are actively working on this, and I hope that soon this problem will disappear from the game forever.
- A significant part of the community. Most of the community at Dota is not the best. The game has voice and text chat, in which some players can call you names, criticize and even send you. In fact, if you play with high decency, there will be few such players, for example, I have met only 2-3 of them.
That's it. I hope this review was useful. If so, you can support me with a like and a reward, I will be very pleased to know that I helped someone)
Good luck in mastering the game, bye!
