If you told me when I started playing dota 2 at 18 years old that I would be reviewing this game after 8 years and 13'000 hours, I would have laughed at you.
Let me put that into perspective: [b] 541 Days and 16 Hours. [/b] Of dota 2. 

I'm almost 26 now, and I don't really know what to think of this game. This game has had a large impact on my life. I was "addicted" to the experience, in ranked and matchmaking. I've learned a lot about myself and others. I've learned a lot about staying in charge of my emotions. I've also learned that emotions can easily lose you a game before its come to its conclusion. I've learned how to react instinctively to changing pixel colours.

But I've also relatively learned nothing.

Not to depress anyone reading this, but when I put all of this into perspective, thinking about what could have been, I could easily imagine how much better my life would be if I never started playing this game. Socially, I would have a stronger network. My education and eventual career would probably have had more longevity (I have played professionally as a dota 2 player, but grew a lack of interest in competing). But I can never be sure how drastic these differences are. Would the pros outweigh the cons? I have certainly met and interacted with a large group of people, [b] because [/b] of dota2, at events, tournaments etc. Any dota 2 player that has sunk 2000 hours or so has probably had these thoughts: "what if I just did ... instead" or "what if I just played on a more casual level". The issue is, that dota [b] feels [/b] more rewarding than other things, and that's a trap I fell into.

It is with a heavy heart that I admit that I don't think I can bring myself to play anymore. Took a long 8 years for me to grow out of this perfect fit, which is why I must review dota2 positively.

Thank you for all that you [b] have [/b] done for me. Farewell friend.

I like when they said, "The most-played game on Steam.
Every day, millions of players worldwide enter battle as one of over a hundred Dota heroes. And no matter if it's their 10th hour of play or 1,000th, there's always something new to discover. With regular updates that ensure a constant evolution of gameplay, features, and heroes, Dota 2 has truly taken on a life of its own.

One Battlefield. Infinite Possibilities.
When it comes to diversity of heroes, abilities, and powerful items, Dota boasts an endless array‚Äîno two games are the same. Any hero can fill multiple roles, and there's an abundance of items to help meet the needs of each game. Dota doesn't provide limitations on how to play, it empowers you to express your own style.

All heroes are free.
Competitive balance is Dota's crown jewel, and to ensure everyone is playing on an even field, the core content of the game‚Äîlike the vast pool of heroes‚Äîis available to all players. Fans can collect cosmetics for heroes and fun add-ons for the world they inhabit, but everything you need to play is already included before you join your first match.

Bring your friends and party up.
Dota is deep, and constantly evolving, but it's never too late to join.
Learn the ropes playing co-op vs. bots. Sharpen your skills in the hero demo mode. Jump into the behavior- and skill-based matchmaking system that ensures you'll
be matched with the right players each game." - Valve

[b]Follow my instructions to ALWAYS win in this game![/b]

[u]The Winning Hero selection:[/u]
[b]Hard Support:[/b] Sniper
[b]Soft Support:[/b] Juggernaut
[b]Mid Lane:[/b] Tinker
[b]Safe Lane:[/b] Treant Protector
[b]Off Lane:[/b] Phantom Assassin

How to play Support: 
NEVER buy any wards! If you buy wards, your mates who are playing carry will be super mad! They will probably throw the game if you place too many wards on the map, especially the "blue" ones that you have to spend your hard earned coins on! Instead, focus on farming as much as possible. Hit the creeps and let your other mate in the lane know that you will mute them if they warn you not to do it!

How to play Safe Lane carry: 
Run away from Creeps! They are out there to hunt you down and steal your HP. If you see creeps hitting the tower, make sure you run the other way because towers have self-defense capabilities. It is far more important for you to go jungle early on before you even hit lvl 5 because you need the neutral "shovel" item to get your early potions and gimmicks. Also, don't steal farm from your Hard Support mate.

How to play Mid lane: 
If you are mid, your task is NOT to help the other two lanes, but actually hit the tower in the middle with brute force. Doesn't matter if you die a couple of times, the most important task is to take that tower down. Ignore the enemy hero and focus on your objective. Also ignore any calls for something the players in this game call "ganking" - this isn't your job.

How to play Off Lane: 
Off lane is probably the hardest role to play. The amount of hate you will get is not even funny. So make sure you pick the right hero. Don't forget my recommendation: Phantom Assassin. She is absolutely the best. You will get ez kills and won't even have to bother about stunning the opponent - why stun when you can actually spill their guts inside out? Tell your soft support hero to gtfo from the lane as soon as possible, they're just milking your hard-earned XP by standing there.

With all this said, I am sure you will find Dota 2 community to be very respectful and friendly most of the times. Sometimes here and there you might run into a slightly unfriendly person but that's all just them being grumpy and unhappy with life - the good thing is: Now you have this guide to make that experience much less frequent as you will be killing it!

Enjoy!!!

Dota is like doing hard drugs. It sucks you in and makes you feel like a god at times. At others, it spits you out and you hate everything and everyone and your soul gets a little chipped every time. In one moment you may have just double-killed the bot lane under their tower and still walked away with all 20 stick charges. In another, you might have to hold your headphones six inches off your ears so you don't go deaf from your team's screeching off one minor misplay. If you thought the bonds of friendship would protect you through a Dota game, you were wrong. You'll get better, but you'll never get good. Every person that plays this game is teetering on the edge of insanity, and all they need is for you to mess up one pull before they're pushed overboard. And they say they aren't, but they are, aren't they? You'll get better, but you'll never get good.

This game is the Paroxysm of toxicity. 

I am 29, I played COD back when my mom was getting f*k by every 12 years old after every game, I've played LoL (wich is close second in toxicity) for years, I played pretty much every MMORPG in existence with all the trash talk that comes with it, I play apex alot with the raging coms etc... what I am saying is that I am not new to toxicity in games i've experienced it for years, and honestly, i don't mind it, its part of the game and I actually enjoy-find it funny to an extent. I was there when this game was born, back in WC3 and I have good memories of it.

But Dota 2 is something else, it is rotten.

So what is so bad about it?

1- 90% of games you will get thrash talkers in your game, Not the '' ahah i fk ur mom last night'' kind, no, the F*** Ret*** , mass pinging voice chat insulting type.

2-At any point of getting sh** on by some random guy cause; you missed a last hit, or didnt help him 1v5 when you knew you would both die or anything of the sort, IF you lash back out you will most likely get mass reported and banned for 20mins or more. So you can take insults but don't you dare talk back.

3-In ranked, ppl don't give a flying dog butt. They will pick a hard carry when they are support and steal last hits from you.  They will insult and ping spam you even if you are right and are doing your job.

4- You WILL get banned, Bad words after being insulted? Jungling because your support picked a hard carry and is stealing creeps? Just doing poorly cause you are new at a hero? Last hittign a creep as a support when you were trying to deny? Buying the ''wrong'' item? People report you for pretty much EVERY thing you do even when you are doing your best and not say ANYTHING. To the point where you will get scared out of playing.

5- People don't speak english. I am french, This is a team game, can we all speak english or select another server please? Dota is FILLED with what you will come to know as ''peruvians'' if you never met them yet you will, trust me.

6- DONOT, i repeat, DO NOT get off your seat while you are playing DOTA2, dog wants in? too bad, daughter crying? She better man up. your house is on fire? You better finish that game first boy, cause trust me, you'll be banned for griefing-leaving-afking 5 min before your house has burnt down.

In my last 20 games I think I've had 1 or 2 friendly players. 

Do not waste your time with this game my friends, ESPECIALLY if you are new, you will get banned and insulted into another another dimension,

[b] DotA 2 is not for those who give up easily and are not willing to learn the necessary mechanics. [/b] This game is too complicated to learn everything overnight, by a week, or by a month. Even people like us, who have played this game for more than a decade, learn something every now and then. The game is so dynamic that some things that you knew a month ago can become obsolete in the next six months or so.

This game isn't easy, yet, it's also not that hard for anyone to master at least a portion of it. Most people who say that this game is easy can't even reach the Immortal rank. The challenge is surreal for those who want to improve and excel. Individual skills matter a lot, but you also have to be a team player. Add a little bit of luck, and you'll get wins.

What can I say about the game that has taken up more hours in my life than anything else? Dota is a mixed bag of awesome and awful. some of the best nights of gaming are because of it, and some of the worst.


Is it fun? absolutely* 

*you must get a party because public matches are ultra toxic

I've met some of my closest friends who I enjoy gaming with, I've been to weddings because of it, I've traveled the world and spend time with people who I met through Dota. That aspect is fantastic.

Gameplay is fun and short enough that if you need something to entertain you for a few hours or even 1, you can do that.

so what's the problem? 
The player community  is one of the most toxic I have ever been around. finding the  good people I did in this game is like finding another castaway lost at sea. you are both so relieved to have found another person amidst the awful that it gives you shared trauma,
Rampant racism, sexism, homophobia, toxic attitudes are in practically every game. 
Valve does very little to address this, so a small kid will be exposed to horrible things.
use the mute button often, and block players like you're breathing, and it may help, but probably not.

That said, once you do find some castaways who are fun to play with, it'll make it bearable, and your shared trauma will unite you for life.

TLDR: A convoluted mess of a MOBA. Maybe that's your thing, definitely not mine. It's #2 to League for a reason. Final Score: 6/10

I thought I would give this game a try since League of Legends has turned into a dash-fest, but Dota 2 turned out to be a bland, generic, convoluted mess of a game.

Pros:
-It's very pretty. 
-Some interesting ability ideas.
-The courier system is an interesting idea...with a few drawbacks.

Cons:
--CC everywhere. More roots, polymorphs, stuns, blinds, disarms than you can shake a stick at. You'll be lucky to be able to control your character at all. I thought Divinity Original Sin 2 had too many status effects, but this game is close behind it on the chart.

--Killing your own minions to "deny" the enemy gold? Seriously? What a ridiculous concept that takes the player out of the game. Can you imagine a battle where a commander starts murdering their own troops? More proof that DOTA just doesn't care about theme or immersion. Extra micro that becomes a chore.

--Generic and bland heroes (seriously, not even giving them names and instead calling them generic titles? Talk about a lack of creativity).

--Convoluted gameplay that is unnecessarily...messy. I don't fear complex games. I can sit down and play any Grand Strategy (Stellaris, Hoi4, EU4) for hours. But this, this is adding complexity without adding depth. Ten million tooltips and tiny details here and there. Do I need to know every effect of an ability for EVERY LEVEL? I can see putting the bonuses for leveling up said skill there, but why show previous level stats at all? Why are there multiple shops (especially since you can just send your courier there)? Why are there so many map capturables? Why can't characters see up on a ledge that looks perhaps half their height? 

--Listen, I don't mind a change of pace in the MOBA format. But I also don't want to spend an hour playing a single MOBA game. It's literally a point and click game genre when you break it down. People want quick fun, not a shallow game pretending to be as complex and fascinating as a 4X.

--The courier system adds unnecessary micro. Players in a MOBA should not be able to click off their hero at any time, nor have a need to. It's a MOBA not a RTS.

--The abilities are almost all click-target abilities that auto-hit. There's basically no skill involved. And since most abilities stun you for ridiculous periods of time, that means an enemy team can stun and trap you with basically zero effort.

--The eating trees thing is a little silly. They could just have made items that heal over time or something. Why destroy the trees too? 

--Too many holdovers from DOTA all-stars on Warcraft 3. I get it, it's a "sequel", but at least try to come up with some unique and new stuff.

Conclusion: It's impossible to not compare DOTA 2 and League of Legends. They are the top two MOBA games in the world, although League leads by nearly double the player base. DOTA 2 fans constantly complain about League of Legends hogging the spotlight of MOBA games. I was willing to give DOTA 2 a try since I can't stand League any more. Yet, League has twice the players of Dota 2 for a good reason: It has personality and is fun.

I won't claim League is remotely balanced or as complex as DOTA 2. It's a dash-fest mess that can be very frustrating. But at least I came away from League feeling like I had an interesting time rather than staring at a creatively-bankrupt game with pretty graphics (cough cough DOTA 2). I'll take my Vi, Jinx, Viktor heroes any day over generic Dragon Rider, Ice Mage, Assassin and Sniper, or whatever other stupid names and ideas DOTA 2 has for heroes. I don't even know what the world is called in DOTA 2. It has zero personality and zero effort. League's world is fascinating and varied with great lore and interesting heroes. 

Want a perfect example of how generic DOTA is compared to League? Just look at their animated shows. DOTA's show = "Dragon's Blood", a mediocre, generic fantasy show with forgettable characters. Not bad, but not great. League's show = Freaking "Arcane", considered by many to be one of the greatest animated series of all time (swept its Annie nominations). Yes, comparing their shows is a bit of a red herring, but it is connected to the world the games are trying to sell you. You develop a connection to League heroes. You never can develop that kind of connection to characters that Valve doesn't even bother to name properly.

Valve just copy-pasted the vast majority of their abilities and heroes from DOTA All-Stars on Warcraft 3 rather than coming up with new stuff (League is quite guilty of copy-pasting as well, but they copy-paste their own damn heroes, which might be worse, tbh).

My rant is over. DOTA 2 isn't horrible and is probably better for you if you want a long, unnecessarily complex MOBA to play. Some people prefer that. Fair enough. Personally, I like my MOBAs to be quick and fun. Not gonna go back to League, since it is a mess. Might play Smite or something instead.


Final Score: 6/10

If you are experienced in playing DOTA then I guess this game can be fun for you, however if you are new and starting solo, unless you are willing to put in hundreds of hours just in learning basics forget it. 

In my opinion every game has a learning curve however  this game has simply too complicated points that should not be that complicated but intuitive. For instance the shop. You cannot buy items in game that you want, receiving strange messages like you are not in range of the shop when you are right on top of it, or not being able to purchase what you want even if you have the gold for it, the confusion of the shop itself etc.

Evidently if you played this game from this start this is a non issue, however if you go solo now and you think you will just pick it up as you go along playing without any help from a friend, you are probably in for a stressful failure. 

In terms of design graphics and overall map movement and so forth, the game scores high in my opinion. It certainly would have the potential to have a much larger audience. The mechanics seem hard at start but certainly that part you can pick up, just in compassion with say League of Legends (in case you are coming from that game) you will find it impossible to select the correct items as the learning curve for that alone including how to purchase the items when you want and have the gold for them it is far too complicated and not intuitive at all. Plus it appears to have somekind of pool of items that can be shared which ofcourse going solo, learning that alone and coordenating that with randoms is near impossible. 

Say you have a mage and you can figure out what you want to buy, like intelligence, mana that sort of thing, but you get all kinds of stress just to buy the items themselves. It is frustrating as hell.

Again, I am not saying you cannot go on and learn it but if you think, Ok I know moba this is another moba game Ill pick it up easy, you wont. 

The champions are another issue, if you do not know the champions the icons on champion select are so tiny that even if you train a couple of champions, to identify that champion on the list of tiny tumbnails is already stressful. 

There is a mode for new players where you play against bots or whatever but there again all the shop rules and some purchase things are different, even to place a ward the map is too damm large in terms of gaps of hiding and trees so if you need cooperation for it. 

Even if your team is getting stumped and it is evident that you gone beyond the point of recovering, the game can take forever, with some experienced players plaguing normals with the solo aim to stump and get a million kills.

Again the question will be, are you willing to spend 1000 hours on it to have a game which is enjoyable, including watching a bunch of videos and so forth? If the answer is yes, then go for it. If the answer is no go play something else.

"You learn how to learn, how to lose and most importantly you learn about you."

Alright.... so here is my dota 2 review after playing almost 6000 hours over the span of 3 years.

1. general thoughts and how i started:
I was 15 when a friend recommended dota 2 to me. Back then i wouldnt ever have imagined how much time this game would take from me. At some point i was playing 12+ hours a day for weeks. Now im approaching my 19th birthday and im kind of conflicted on what kind of impact this game had on my life. I learned a lot about myself and generally speaking matured a lot regarding interacting with other humans. Dota isnt just a game, Dota is something else, something i have never experienced even when i was addicted to a mmorpg when i was 9-13. You learn how to learn, how to improve, how to win and how to lose. The most important thing dota teached me was how emotions impact your performance, and that saying "nothing" is sometimes the best thing to do. In real life no one really teaches you stuff like that since people are kind of used to dealing with emotional ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

2. Did i waste my youth?:
So this sounds a bit depressing but this is a thought that i had sometimes. but realisticially speaking, knowing myself, im really unsure of how much my life wouldve been different if i never started dota. I asume i wouldve been a bit further regarding social contacts but career/school-wise i highly doubt that it wouldve made a big difference. You gotta be realistic when thinking about stuff like this. Im not a very social guy. I dont like to put work into stuff i dont care about. The thoughts "lets learn music" or "lets study" wouldnt have EVER crossed my mind when i was 15. Im pretty sure if i wouldnt have started with dota i wouldve just been gooning around the city and abuse drugs, since thats a lot of fun to me. Back then i actually never even thought about working on something to improve, that whole dimension of "improving" wasnt even there for me. I just went to school got home and did fun stuff sometimes. Thats it. No goals. No aspiration, nothing. Dota changed that.

3. time invested into dota2:
EVERY dota player that has spent more than 1000 hours into this game has had that thought of "oh man i shouldve learned something with this time.... i couldve been amazing now.." at some point. But everyone is disregarding the fact that grinding dota is something VERY EASY and comfortable to do, unlike studying or learning an instrument. Just think about what kind of game dota 2 is that spending 1000s of hours is something you do with pleasure. It's kind of insane thinking about it. Once i started studying more for school again i realized how much ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• time 100 hours is. I garantue you that you will be a top student if youd put 20 hours a week into studying outside of school. But the big difference is that dota is just so much more fun and REWARDING.

REWARDING: dota 2 is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• REWARDING. you learn a new hero -> BAMM MMR. you start understanding how to farm -> M . M . R

YOUR RANK GOES ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• UP. IT FEELS AMAZING. at school you get an A and you smile for about 10 minutes and then youre back to being miserable. theres no punishment for being mediocre. At least thats how i feel right now and im graduating this year(grades are OK(kinda good, not great)).

ReasoN I WROTE THIS: im downloading dota right now because my laptop is REALLY ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up adn deletes files something, so i needed something to do



CONCLUSION: AMAZING GAME, EATS ALL YOUR TIME, YOU WILL HAVE FUN(if you are competetive)

This is what I have to say about modern DOTA.

If you are starting a new account your best bet in to get good with bots, you will learn good builds with the 2 free months of DOTA PLUS, and learn some basics before you face people. Once you start facing people the trouble in modern DOTA 2 begins. Any USA server you will not find a game before 11 am EST, even when you can find a game expect at least half your games to be full of intentional leavers or feeders. Your chat privelages are completely based on a "behavior" score.  I personally claimed 6 commends and less than 3 reports in my first 15 games on this account. My chat privelages were removed when my first behavior score report came through and was below 3000. Once this happens to new players don't expect to ask your teammates questions about builds, or heroes to play, or strats, it seems that aspect of DOTA has been lost anyway.

You will find many people with starting accounts are also muted. The people who are not muted either are also new accounts or people with similar behavior score. Every once in a while the unmuted players will contribute to help you. Mostly though they will either troll about how they are dominating or more likely tell you how bad you are and threaten to report you. The first sentance that shows in chat before every unranked game is telling people to be understanding and patient with new players. It seems nobody takes this sentence serious. 

Don't get me wrong this review is very biased. I had one account in high standing in this game and played for years, after release,  without problems. When i took a couple years without playing, then came back to the game, I showed up extremely rusty and trying to figure out a completely new META. On this new account I have played just as bad as when I was rusty. Years ago you would get mass reported for feeding, even when you argued to the people reporting that you were rusty and trying to get back into the game. It falls into the category of unintentional feeding, like any new player can fall victim too.

This games ranking system is very much based off the Indian caste system. I wonder if that is what they are trying to apply to the entire community of the game. There seems to be two different sets of rules in this game. Those based on the EULA you accept before playing each game and those based on the "communities" reports. When you give the community the ability to essentially cancel culture peoples investment into this game it causes problems imo. Most of these reports are completely illegitamate or with little cause.

I've been playing this game since 2014.

The years when MOBA games were big were certainly great times. After doing your homework, you'd fire up your PC, meet your friends on TeamSpeak and play some games. Some had their favorite hero picks and kept playing the same hero over and over trying to perfect their strats while other tried many different heroes on different positions with different items.
Everything seemed to be viable.

You'd meet players from the whole continent. I've met people coming from nothern countries such as sweden or norway; people coming from spain or malta, as well as people coming from russia.
While everyone grew up in a different culture and speaking a different language, everyone had the same goal: 
Have fun with a good round of dota.

Having fun didn't necessarily mean easy sailing winning every game. No, the game was supposed to be balanced (in terms of the skill level each player possesed) and most of the time a toe to toe race. That's how the game has been.

Sadly, those days are over.

These days a game of DotA looks like this: 

You come home from uni lectures, start a game with two of your friends of similar rank. After waiting up to 15 minutes to find a match you find yourself in either of four scenarios:
- Everyone has a similar rank like you and your friends; Outcome: you have a balanced-out game.
- The enemy team is generally lower ranked; Outcome: you stomp the game.
- The enemy team is lower ranked but there is this one player, that supposedly started playing two weeks ago and has miraculously already mastered DotA. Outcome: you get stomped.
- The enemy team is higher ranked, where one or more players of high rank (in my case they're legend - divine) play with their low rank (guardian - crusader) friends. Outcome: Surprise, surprise, the high ranking player solo stomps the game.

At this point, the game is already determined to some degree before even picking a single hero.


The scale are then further tipped in the draft, that is seemingly dominated by the same heroes: Tiny, Primal Beast, Huskar, Pudge, Sniper or Axe. It feels nearly impossible to get a game without these heroes being in it. Other options are just not viable anymore because they don't like to fight early or they don't farm as fast as a Luna or Medusa.


Your fate is now further sealed in the first ~15 minutes of the game, it seems. Either team is getting crushed on lane without having the chance to recover because there is a fucking Tiny with 500 damage at minute 15 destroying your base in two hits.

In the end you sit in front of your PC - 15 minutes into the game - that you'll loose this game. You're not allowed to give up or you'll get punished. Instead you're supposed to defend your base until the enemy team finally decides to grant you the coup de grace. 

*TL;DR / Summary*:
The game used to be fun, but is now stuck in a very static meta and a matchmaking system that gets regularly abused either by smurfs or high ranking players playing with their low ranking players.

The outcome of a game is now determined within the first 15 minutes while your stuck another 20 minutes either sieging or defending.

Also, if you are a beginner, don't bother picking up this game. It is dying and is only held up by people seeking distraction during corona lockdown and people creating smurf accounts.

the most important question is, is it fun?

No if you're playing solo then this game can really give you a bad time, talking to you SEA server.

Dota 2 is a highly complex game that requires an elevated thought process which is sadly not inherent to many of the kids who play this game today. For this reason the game has often been wrongly classified as toxic. Dota 2 however is not toxic. Rather it is a game filled with a group of passionate players who find it quite frustrating when they are matched with players who refuse to take the time to learn the basics of the game and the hero roles.
For this reason I strongly suggest that the game developers ban the solo queue option from the game thus allowing players play collectively as a team thus improving the game-play experience.

DotA 2 is like a good game of chess that has done acid and decided to invite all of its 'friends' over to brutalize and torment the other team. However, instead of tormenting the other team these 'friends' just decide to rail on one another until each 'friend' has to quietly put themselves into offline mode before playing any game on steam.

Honestly though, contrary to popular opinion DotA is a very fun game. It is just not a fun game for stupid people or people that are not willing to take some time to learn the game. This game will not spoonfeed you on how to play, nor will it easily allow you to catch up if you make mistakes. Like in the real world if you make mistakes in battle you will suffer.

A few tips: 
Try to keep a level head, and bonus points for a positive attitude. Your team will appreciate it a lot, and they will be more willing to work with you.
Pay attention to the map, your surroundings, and your enemies items. 
Read your abilities carefully, read the patch notes, read the items abilities.
Practice heroes in demo mode (this is different from bot practice or private lobby.)
Get yourself a mic. Effective communication is one of your biggest utilities.
If a hero that is in your lane goes missing call missing immediately. Better safe than sorry.
Buy wards. Wards might typically be a supports 'job', but they will save your life and get you kills, which will easily make up for the gold cost. Also, your team will appreciate you that much more, which will result in them being much more likely to try to help you out and listen to you.
Use your scan. I find that this tool is way overlooked. At least in my bracket. It's up every 5 minutes, and it can only help (if not to tell you where someone is; it will tell you where they are not.)
Nobody is good at DotA. There is always someone much better than you are. So do your best and try not to talk trash. 
Treat this as a chance to develop team communication skills
Deny creeps as much as you can, but not at the sacrifice of missing a last hit.
Buy smoke before a gank or a Rosh kill. They are a cheap invaluable tool.
Verbally tell whomever you are around if you are planning on leaving them or TPing out. 
Experiment with different items when you are fighting different types of heroes.
I say this last one with caution because it can hinder your ability to play the game normally, but try Turbo when you first start out. It will allow you to learn heroes more quickly.
Okay, actually this is my last point. Try to have fun. It is just a game.

Low Priority queue is actually the fucking stupidest, worst punishment I've ever seen in a video game.

This game has one of the most autistic, rude, awful communities I've ever seen. A bunch of basement dwellers that think spamming KEKW and being a 4channer is a replacement for having a personality. I played league for over a decade before switching to DOTA2. Smite I've played for a long time but it just was badly designed and balanced I gave up. There's really no other competition for mobas

It's a legit way better balanced and designed game than any of its competition. But the community is also thirty times more toxic/infuriating than LoL or Smite. At least those game let you surrender a match everyone agrees is over. This one you have to suffer and waste another 30 minutes to play out a game you have no hope of winning because your team refuses to communicate and your 2 cores are a cumulative 2/30. So you get to be target practice for a team that refuses to end the game because they want to boost their egos and K/D's. Refusing to participate or sitting in spawn gets you put in "low priority queue" as mentioned above. Which is a punishment that rewards good players that are toxic above players who are mechanically bad but committed the same crimes.

Low Priority queue is a system that puts you in longer queues (upwards of 10 minutes for a game) limits you to one mode (single pick, where you get s choice of one of three characters you probably won't know how to play if you're a new player) and the punishment isn't based on behavior or number of games, or a flat time, it's based on number of wins. win a lot of games and it's a minor inconvenience, if you aren't good at the game (like me) you'll never get out and be stuck for months. Good players learn nothing for their trouble and bad players are overly punished for doing the exact same thing the other players did. 

Since people are already being punished, no one cares in low priority queue. I've had people openly admit to feeding while being disgusting and burping on the mic because they lack social awareness. I've had people autolock characters that make no sense for the comp. I've had teammates and enemies alike just walk into the enemy team on cooldown. People still ragequit and even if it's a 4 vs 5 you're not allowed to leave in low priority queue, and the wins only count if all players are present so you're doing it for nothing at that point. It's the worst punishment I've ever seen. It teaches misbehaving players all the wrong lessons and it's a system that's been in place for years.Once you're stuck, if you're not good at the game you're just stuck in there for months and can't get out. I actually really really enjoy the depth of the game mechanically but I've been stuck in low prio queue for months now. Because I left some unwinnable games that went on for almost an hour.

So for those of you stepping in, the game is absurdly hard, the community sucks, and if you leave like three games EVER because there's no surrender system and people don't like ending games when they're ahead because THEY'RE having fun, the game gets even WORSE. and no one will have any sympathy for you, simply spamming "haha you suck lmao KEKW get good" while the other team runs a train on you for not knowing how to play.

after spending roughly 5000 hours in this game and literally playing it since it was a warcraft 3 custom map I will write a very biased review of what I came to believe was a game concept. I will briefly sum up a few good qualities of the game as well as the not so great features.

THE GOOD: 
1. Dota2 is an amazingly diverse game, given the fact that there are approx 120 different heroes. You can make insane combinations of skills just based on hero picks into a visual ecstasy that will give you a good laugh and nice memories.
2. The learning curve is mega hard and to become somewhat effective you will lose at least a few hundred games. The game allows you to practice with AI bots that are fairly well designed, but once you realize their behaviour/programming pattern,they become way too easy to beat even on hardest difficulty. These AI matches will give you a great foothold on the mechanics of the game to build your skill upon.
3. Dota2 is progressing and new heroes/items are being added continually. As well as nearly quarterly special game modes, this allows for a somewhat enjoyable experience.

THE BAD:
1. Matchmaking abuse is a thing that you will see on a daily basis. You get smurf players (accounts of players who have lot more experience in the game get paired with much lower). This can not be evaded as people are getting banned and suspended left and right. However, losing because 1 of your 3 lanes gets facerolled is not enjoyable at all and you can do very little about it.
2. Matchmaking pairs - the algorithm for matchmaking was probably designed by a guy who is drunk and high for the most part of his life and at this point the company just does not want to fire him. I can only speak from experience but let me tell you that being paired with people who have 200 matches as someone with 4000 games is nowhere near pleasant and happens way too often. 
3. In game communication is close to impossible unless you are lucky with who you get paired with. Most of the time you just mute everyone and try to play the game as intended. Let me tell you I have said and wrote some nasty shit in there that would result in violence for sure.

THE UGLY:
1. People. Simple as that.

SUMMARY: try this game. kill things when their life is low. shout in the mic why are you getting ganked without anyone saying anything. smoke gank their team and destroy one of the towers. sneak in the roshan pit for that sweet sweet aegis. get shit on by a smurf tinker (insert any current overpowered meta hero) mid. uninstall. play something else for a few weeks. install dota again and spend more of your time. CONGRATULATIONS! The cycle is complete.

Just like any other game like this it draws you in and slowly sucks away your free time. Lots of fun, like league of legends except items/builds matter 100x more. Fun champions. Like any game of this kind the community is toxic. Also if you can't speak spanish you probably won't be able to communicate with 75% of the playerbase. Games are not server based, language based, or location based. You can meet a lot of fun people but it also causes lots of issues. I've had games where I've played with a Russian player, a Chinese player, a Columbian player, and one other English speaker on my team. Other than the other random english speaker not a single one of us could communicate with each other. It also led to our main carry d/cing every 4 minutes because their connection was not strong enough to play with people so far away. Our team got destroyed. In a game that has no forfeit function (which in many ways is a positive thing) games like this can drag on with most being ~40 minutes but can vary from 25-60+ minutes. As you can imagine being trapped in a game like that ends up with you just waiting for the enemy team to destroy your base. Until they fix it so people with similar connections play with each other the game is just going to feel like an incomplete League of Legends knock off.

Been playing for 9 years. I used to play WC3 Dota, then I switched to LoL then when Dota 2 came out I switched to it and stayed. The one main contrast that appeals to me about Dota 2 is that the hero roles aren't fixed. You can play any hero anywhere and make it work as long as you know how to farm gold and exp. You can play melee against ranged and still win the lane which is impossible in some games. The item builds aren't streamlined either. You can build a lot of wacky and fun items and be creative. Also, supports are not useless either and when played properly can create a huge impact and not be completely dependent on the carry or core. One time my carry abandoned and I built carry items on my support and won the game. It's as you mentioned. Freedom is the main appeal of the game. At first, it may seem daunting and confusing but when you start getting the hang of it you really start enjoying the amount of space the game gives to apply your own unique strategy every game.

If you want to play a free game that pulls you in, with an amazing e-Sports scene and you have hours of time a day to spare, this is the game for you. If you are trying to leave gaming and may start thinking you're addicted, then STAY AWAY! This is one of the best games I've played in my life and I can't stop coming back, even though I now have a job, wife and kid now. If you like ranked gameplay, the players at the bottom ranks can be a bit toxic, but as you climb, the players are nicer. The strategy and skill required can be demanding, but there are plenty of coaches and video tutorials on how to get better on the web. The graphics, game design, music and voice dialogues are great. Again, highly addictive gameplay, different game modes, huge community, but big time eater. Approach with caution! :)

This game is broken and imbalanced. I'm not talking about the champions, but the map. Just like League of legends, the map does not rotate to fit whatever side you are on, so when you are on the top (dire) side of the map, you have a significant sight disadvantage. Allowing the map to rotate 45 degrees or 90 degrees would solve this problem, but valve will not do it. Same with LOL. Many players who think they are smart will defend this choice (even though it would be harmless to implement as an option) saying that you should just more your camera appropriately. But the camera sees a trapezoid area since it is at an angle. No matter what position you have your camera set to, you will always see more area at the top of the screen than on the lower, and enemy players can are more likely to catch you off guard when approaching from below. In addition, the HUD takes up a significant portion of the bottom of the screen, further exacerbating the problem. The result is a near 60/40 win ration between sides favoring the radiant (lower) side. If your team loses the coin toss and you are placed at the top of the map on the dire side, you are playing at a significant disadvantage.

Many modern MOBAs recognize this problem and correct for it. Heroes of the Storm has symmetrical maps where players sides are on the left and the right, not bottom left vs top right. And Pokemon Unite literally flips the map so that you as a player always spawn on the left side of the map and always fight players to the right. 

It would be simple to program an option into the game to rotate the map. People can actually use cheats to accomplish this, so it would be simple to add the code in the options to allow players to do this, but for some reason they wont do it. I once met a former Riot employee who said that the reason riot wont fix this issue is out of a stubborn pride, and that mentioning it in meetings is basically forbidden. I have a feeling that Valve is the same way. Instead, you just eye rolls from valve and pretentious players saying "learn to position the camera right bro, I did it, see how amazing I am?" Fine if that is your approach, you do you. But allow us the option to flip the map. If you want to play handicapped, that's your choice. At least give us the choice to play our way. 

If you think radiant and dire side are actually even, then why not put your money where you mouth is and give us the option to always spawn on the radiant side? If there is no advantage, it wont harm anyone will it? But you know the radiant has an advantage and players would always choose radiant to get the edge on the enemy players. 

Its literally no skin off your nose to implement a map rotate option, the possibility is already in there in the code, so just let us do it. 

Until then, I wont be playing this game, which is a shame. I want to play this game. I would even be willing to spend alot of money on skins and dota plus, but not until its an even playing field. I don't like playing games that are unfair. Simple as that.

Abaddon, the Lord of Avernus

The Font of Avernus is the source of a family's strength, a crack in primal stones from which vapors of prophetic power have issued for generations. Each newborn of the cavernous House Avernus is bathed in the black mist, and by this baptism they are given an innate connection to the mystic energies of the land. They grow up believing themselves fierce protectors of their lineal traditions, the customs of the realm‚Äîbut what they really are protecting is the Font itself. And the motives of the mist are unclear.

When the infant Abaddon was bathed in the Font, they say something went awry. In the child's eyes there flared a light of comprehension that startled all present and set the sacerdotes to whispering. He was raised with every expectation of following the path all scions of Avernus took‚Äîto train in war, that in times of need he might lead the family's army in defense of the ancestral lands. But Abaddon was always one apart. Where others trained with weapons, he bent himself to meditation in the presence of the mist. He drank deep from the vapors that welled from the Font, learning to blend his spirit with the potency that flowed from far beneath the House; he became a creature of the black mist.

There was bitterness within the House Avernus‚Äîelders and young alike accusing him of neglecting his responsibilities. But all such accusations stopped when Abaddon rode into battle, and they saw how the powers of the mist had given him mastery over life and death beyond those of any lord the House had ever known.

I played all 3 of the major MOBA's (league, dota and smite), and I do not recommend DOTA because the game is simply too unnecessarily complex its ridiculous... And no this is not a "too hard" complaint, Chess is a hard game yet it isn't nearly as complex as DOTA. You don't need to add a thousand of different mechanics, active items, couriers and what not to make the game hard... According to all known laws
of aviation,

  
there is no way a bee
should be able to fly.

  
Its wings are too small to get
its fat little body off the ground.

  
The bee, of course, flies anyway

  
because bees don't care
what humans think is impossible.

  
Yellow, black. Yellow, black.
Yellow, black. Yellow, black.

  
Ooh, black and yellow!
Let's shake it up a little.

  
Barry! Breakfast is ready!

  
Ooming!

  
Hang on a second.

  
Hello?

  
- Barry?
- Adam?

  
- Oan you believe this is happening?
- I can't. I'll pick you up.

  
Looking sharp.

  
Use the stairs. Your father
paid good money for those.

  
Sorry. I'm excited.

  
Here's the graduate.
We're very proud of you, son.

  
A perfect report card, all B's.

  
Very proud.

  
Ma! I got a thing going here.

  
- You got lint on your fuzz.
- Ow! That's me!

  
- Wave to us! We'll be in row 118,000.
- Bye!

  
Barry, I told you,
stop flying in the house!

  
- Hey, Adam.
- Hey, Barry.

  
- Is that fuzz gel?
- A little. Special day, graduation.

  
Never thought I'd make it.

  
Three days grade school,
three days high school.

  
Those were awkward.

  
Three days college. I'm glad I took
a day and hitchhiked around the hive.

  
You did come back different.

  
- Hi, Barry.
- Artie, growing a mustache? Looks good.

  
- Hear about Frankie?
- Yeah.

  
- You going to the funeral?
- No, I'm not going.

  
Everybody knows,
sting someone, you die.

  
Don't waste it on a squirrel.
Such a hothead.

  
I guess he could have
just gotten out of the way.

  
I love this incorporating
an amusement park into our day.

  
That's why we don't need vacations.

  
Boy, quite a bit of pomp...
under the circumstances.

  
- Well, Adam, today we are men.
- We are!

  
- Bee-men.
- Amen!

  
Hallelujah!

  
Students, faculty, distinguished bees,

  
please welcome Dean Buzzwell.

  
Welcome, New Hive Oity
graduating class of...

  
...9:15.

  
That concludes our ceremonies.

  
And begins your career
at Honex Industries!

  
Will we pick ourjob today?

  
I heard it's just orientation.

  
Heads up! Here we go.

  
Keep your hands and antennas
inside the tram at all times.

  
- Wonder what it'll be like?
- A little scary.

  
Welcome to Honex,
a division of Honesco

  
and a part of the Hexagon Group.

  
This is it!

  
Wow.

  
Wow.

  
We know that you, as a bee,
have worked your whole life

  
to get to the point where you
can work for your whole life.

  
Honey begins when our valiant Pollen
Jocks bring the nectar to the hive.

  
Our top-secret formula

  
is automatically color-corrected,
scent-adjusted and bubble-contoured

  
into this soothing sweet syrup

  
with its distinctive
golden glow you know as...

  
Honey!

  
- That girl was hot.
- She's my cousin!

  
- She is?
- Yes, we're all cousins.

  
- Right. You're right.
- At Honex, we constantly strive

  
to improve every aspect
of bee existence.

  
These bees are stress-testing
a new helmet technology.

  
- What do you think he makes?
- Not enough.

  
Here we have our latest advancement,
the Krelman.

  
- What does that do?
- Oatches that little strand of honey

  
that hangs after you pour it.
Saves us millions.

  
Oan anyone work on the Krelman?

  
Of course. Most bee jobs are
small ones. But bees know

  
that every small job,
if it's done well, means a lot.

  
But choose carefully

  
because you'll stay in the job
you pick for the rest of your life.

  
The same job the rest of your life?
I didn't know that.

  
What's the difference?

  
You'll be happy to know that bees,
as a species, haven't had one day off

  
in 27 million years.

  
So you'll just work us to death?

  
We'll sure try.

  
Wow! That blew my mind!

  
"What's the difference?"
How can you say that?

  
One job forever?
That's an insane choice to have to make.

  
I'm relieved. Now we only have
to make one decision in life.

  
But, Adam, how could they
never have told us that?

  
Why would you question anything?
We're bees.

  
We're the most perfectly
functioning society on Earth.

  
You ever think maybe things
work a little too well here?

  
Like what? Give me one example.

  
I don't know. But you know
what I'm talking about.

  
Please clear the gate.
Royal Nectar Force on approach.

  
Wait a second. Oheck it out.

  
- Hey, those are Pollen Jocks!
- Wow.

  
I've never seen them this close.

  
They know what it's like
outside the hive.

  
Yeah, but some don't come back.

  
- Hey, Jocks!
- Hi, Jocks!

  
You guys did great!

  
You're monsters!
You're sky freaks! I love it! I love it!

  
- I wonder where they were.
- I don't know.

  
Their day's not planned.

  
Outside the hive, flying who knows
where, doing who knows what.

  
You can'tjust decide to be a Pollen
Jock. You have to be bred for that.

  
Right.

  
Look. That's more pollen
than you and I will see in a lifetime.

  
It's just a status symbol.
Bees make too much of it.

  
Perhaps. Unless you're wearing it
and the ladies see you wearing it.

  
Those ladies?
Aren't they our cousins too?

  
Distant. Distant.

  
Look at these two.

  
- Oouple of Hive Harrys.
- Let's have fun with them.

  
It must be dangerous
being a Pollen Jock.

  
Yeah. Once a bear pinned me
against a mushroom!

  
He had a paw on my throat,
and with the other, he was slapping me!

  
- Oh, my!
- I never thought I'd knock him out.

  
What were you doing during this?

  
Trying to alert the authorities.

  
I can autograph that.

  
A little gusty out there today,
wasn't it, comrades?

  
Yeah. Gusty.

  
We're hitting a sunflower patch
six miles from here tomorrow.

  
- Six miles, huh?
- Barry!

  
A puddle jump for us,
but maybe you're not up for it.

  
- Maybe I am.
- You are not!

  
We're going 0900 at J-Gate.

  
What do you think, buzzy-boy?
Are you bee enough?

  
I might be. It all depends
on what 0900 means.

  
Hey, Honex!

  
Dad, you surprised me.

  
You decide what you're interested in?

  
- Well, there's a lot of choices.
- But you only get one.

  
Do you ever get bored
doing the same job every day?

  
Son, let me tell you about stirring.

  
You grab that stick, and you just
move it around, and you stir it around.

  
You get yourself into a rhythm.
It's a beautiful thing.

  
You know, Dad,
the more I think about it,

  
maybe the honey field
just isn't right for me.

  
You were thinking of what,
making balloon animals?

  
That's a bad job
for a guy with a stinger.

  
Janet, your son's not sure
he wants to go into honey!

  
- Barry, you are so funny sometimes.
- I'm not trying to be funny.

  
You're not funny! You're going
into honey. Our son, the stirrer!

  
- You're gonna be a stirrer?
- No one's listening to me!

  
Wait till you see the sticks I have.

  
I could say anything right now.
I'm gonna get an ant tattoo!

  
Let's open some honey and celebrate!

  
Maybe I'll pierce my thorax.
Shave my antennae.

  
Shack up with a grasshopper. Get
a gold tooth and call everybody "dawg"!

  
I'm so proud.

  
- We're starting work today!
- Today's the day.

  
Oome on! All the good jobs
will be gone.

  
Yeah, right.

  
Pollen counting, stunt bee, pouring,
stirrer, front desk, hair removal...

  
- Is it still available?
- Hang on. Two left!

  
One of them's yours! Oongratulations!
Step to the side.

  
- What'd you get?
- Picking crud out. Stellar!

  
Wow!

  
Oouple of newbies?

  
Yes, sir! Our first day! We are ready!

  
Make your choice.

  
- You want to go first?
- No, you go.

  
Oh, my. What's available?

  
Restroom attendant's open,
not for the reason you think.

  
- Any chance of getting the Krelman?
- Sure, you're on.

  
I'm sorry, the Krelman just closed out.

  
Wax monkey's always open.

  
The Krelman opened up again.

  
What happened?

  
A bee died. Makes an opening. See?
He's dead. Another dead one.

  
Deady. Deadified. Two more dead.

  
Dead from the neck up.
Dead from the neck down. That's life!

  
Oh, this is so hard!

  
Heating, cooling

Dota 2 is the epitomy of rage fueled gaming. 
You might come into this game, being all happy and adventurous-like. And your first couple of games might be fun. 

THEN BOOM. Out of nowhere, smurfs, degenerates that won't play the game and of course the infamous manchild. 
"I didn't get to play exactly like i want to, so now i'm angry, and even though i'm feeding it's everyone elses fault" 

Despite all this, it will have you coming back for more,  you will convince yourself that next game will be different. 
You'll be hopeful until you hit the final stage: Despair Enjoyer mode. You've become numb at this point, all you can think about is the next game. It will take your sleep away, your joy of life. 

The only thing you'll start looking forward to is breaking your damn loss spree, encountering human beings and neither are likely to happen. 

10/10 game tbh

This game will ruin any ambitions you have in real life. This game will consume all your energy, money and happiness. You might start as a casual player, enjoying the fun parts of the game. But the more you play, the more you descend into this pit of pure mental torture. This game will make even the most calm person into a raging toxic human being in some point of playing. The sheer toxicity this game causes even suppasses neurosis of the traditional road rage.
You're better off hot railing meth than playing this godforsaken game.
For every moment of fun and accomplishment you get 5 moments of desperation in this addicting hell hole.

Now when it comes to skins. The marketing and hype for skins is absolutely incredible. Valve did a good job creating a platform, where having expensive items that do jack'all is considered that of a higher social status, somehow similar to buying expensive branded clothes. Of course a lot of people don't care about skins. But let me tell you. Once you start getting into the game more. You start seeing yourself improving as you go on. And you will absolutely spend money on skins rather than buying a new game or something different on steam. It's an ego trap. Everyone thinks they are on a road to becoming the best player, which gives them a justification for spending money on useless ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and for the more mentaly unstable individuals... Gamble with those items, so that they get stuck in this loop of wanting to return to their base value by gambling more. Creating gambling addicts disguised as videogame players- What is even more damaging, is the fact that valve doesn't enforce the ratings of their games, even to the extent of microtransactions. Making teenagers without developed rational thinking fall down the rabbit hole on the same basis as non-consentable sexual conduct would have.

Dota 2 is often compared to League of Legends but let me tell you : They are both completly different games. Where League of Legends is easy to play, hard to master, Dota 2 is on its side,  is hard to play, hard to master. It is far from impossible and, I'm not going to lie, I really enjoyed spending time learning the tremendous amount of mechanics that this game has to offer and I still has so much to discover!

The game is insanely beautiful and believe me, if you put your heart in it, you'll feel the same amazing feeling of wonder and discovery that I felt playing both League of Legends and Dota 2. To be honnest,, watching Dota 2 videos feels like someone explaining you the rules of a strategic board game and once I manage to apply these strategies, the game suddenly feels way more attractive and exciting.

I've only played 10 hours and I'm willing to spend more. For those of you who fear that they won't be able to learn by themselve, there is an amazing and supportive community and an excellent tutorial that guides you perfectly and allows you to play a game with someone giving advice in real time.

I would overall highly recomment this game but warn you on one thing. DO NOT INSTALL DOTA JUST TO TRY IT AND QUIT AFTER BEING LOST IN A GAME. Just watch a beginner's guide on youtube first, and install the game if you are looking for a good non toxic MOBA, and over everything, if you want to discover the amazing content this game has to offer.
In other words, if you expect the game to fully guide you on your first game, you'll quit. Just try to know about the game a little bit more before jumping in.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Don't waste your time as I did with this game. It will take you nowhere.

The matchmaking is not designed to give you fair match ups, but to make you play more. It does not matter how good you perform, you will eventually get paired for consecutive times with a team that is way below your skill and knowledge and you will go down in mmr again. This review is for new players who are considering installing this game.
From a player who has played this game for 5820 hrs, Dota2 is the number one free-to-play online game for me until now and I hope it always be.

Starting with the pros, anybody could be good at this game without spending any money as there is no cost for buying heroes, only some of them, which require more complex skills, will be unlocked when you reach the number of games played required(last checked 25 games of any heroes). Speaking of free to play, you might have questions about Dotaplus. Does having it make you play better than other players? Overall, it is like a shortcut for new players because it provides guides for picking heroes and building items. However, players could alternatively learn these things by experience or other free platforms. There are a lot of youtube channels or websites that provide FREE educational knowledge for this game. Hence, I disagree as the only Dotaplus function which is really useful for me is the option to avoid players. 

Moreover, all heroes are well-designed to be played in various ways,  making this game flexible. One hero could be played in 2-3 different roles depending on the trend of the current patch. In terms of item building, there is no fixed pattern for buying items. You will learn to analyze the game and build items according to the situation and your strategy. By experimenting with them, anyone could be the innovator of the meta(most effective tactics available). 

Ultimately, for those who like beautiful cosmetics. There are tons of cool skins and limited cosmetic items you can get from seasonal events. And the fact that heroes' cosmetics could be customized part by part, you can make your own set of costumes. Besides the hero's skin, there are many magnificent creep(minion or whatever you want to call it) skins, terrain, towers,  weather effects, HUD, and even announcer packs you can customize. And some of them are at a low price. And again, having these things doesn't affect your skill play. 

However, there are some cons as well, namely, the toxic parts of the community. You may meet some players who have toxic attitudes which could affect your play. It would be great if you have good immunity and a positive mental attitude against these players. 

Furthermore, Dota2 seems to be super complicated for beginners especially those who never experienced MOBA(massive online battle arena) games before. It takes time to go through the basics. So it is recommended to finish all the tutorials before entering normal matches. It might sound boring, but trust me, the more you learn, the more fun this game will become.

This game gives me a lot of things. As the servers open internationally, my English and typing skill are improved. I met a Thai friend who is in Norway last year and we have been playing together until now. This game also brought me a good community on Facebook which I can feel free to ask anything even it's not about Dota2. To conclude, I have no regret playing this game.

Game itself is great but for a complete novice to Dota the overwatch system just doesn't work. I never cheat and never deliberately disrupt play but have frequently been reported for these. Main problem is once inexperience has been punished by restricting your game options there is only the Single Draft available to play. This provides a choice of 3 random heroes to play, from well over 100, which pretty much ensures that you are again playing a hero for the first time, performing like the novice you are with that hero and slipping behind in the play. Once you are a level of two behind you are likely to be constantly targeted for easy kills, build up a hill death rate and then be accused of feeding again. Surely it would be better if a player is thought to be playing badly they should be restricted to the beginners option. The single draft is the worst possible solution.

While my hours here in Dota 2 show a low number, I played at least 6900+ hours of DotA.  This is a one of the most fun multiplayer games ever made. It is also a game with the worst community ever. I recommend it for the gameplay, but I also wouldn't recommend it because of the community.

Also, Dota plus should be part of the game, not behind the paywall.

Honestly, after over a thousand hours, you'd think this game would be considered fun.

But the community is as toxic as it gets. Just horrible horrible people that the first thing they say in a match is a complaint. The matches where you find cool enjoyable people that even if you lose, make the match fun and nice to have played, are rare and far in between.

Here is the thing, you need some sort of communication to play this game efficiently. But there's no point in communicating if all it is going to do is make you fucking mad and want to kill someone. I've played this thing on and off over the years and when I think I should give it a try, 'cause maybe, just maybe the community evolved and started behaving better. No. That doesn't happen. It's a game full of people complaining, yelling and calling people names on the microphone. Idiots saying EZ after a 1 hour long match. People whining "Where is the team?!" when they are moving on their own solo in the enemy jungle. 

I can't stress this enough. If you want to get into this game, just don't. Forget all about it. Go watch the e-sports scene or something. 

Just don't play this game that only breeds toxicity. The community here is fundamentally broken by a game design that supports toxic behavior.

As inferior as League of Legends is, at least their Honor system made an improvement towards rewarding players that behave well and aren't toxic. Meanwhile in dota, we get a report system that does almost nothing. Because you get minor punishments for being toxic and zero rewards for being a good fun person.

I had a girlfriend before I played this game, but after I downloaded this game, I received a phone call from her saying she found a new person and was leaving me. I was devastated. So I started grinding on this game 24/7. It became natural for me. I couldn't put this game down. I sold my brother on eBay just for money to buy skins. Eventually I played so much till my fingers fell off. Then my hands fell off. My arms and legs came off next. Next thing I knew, I was just a human chicken nugget. I still play this game every single day for a minimum of 25 hours a day and play with my tongue on my keyboard and my belly button on the mouse. I was basically twerking every time I moved my mouse. I am thankful for these amazing memories, but sadly, sacrifices need to be made in order to get your rewards.

There is no such thing as a good player, only good characters. Nobody will ever be able to prove me otherwise because it's an intentional design choice to give gaming's biggest rejects something to play.

Do you really think Riki pickers can beat Cuphead? Do you really think Bloodseaker pickers can beat Dark Souls? Do you really think Wraithking pickers can control the spray of an AK in CSGO? No, I didn't think so. These people can't do shit. That's exactly why they're stuck playing MOBAS. They know the moment they play a real game of skill they'll be outed as a fake gamer, no different from a mom playing candy crush on her Ipad.

The heros that take skill to play are there to bring in all the people that just can't believe the reality of the truth. Pick the easier hero and win. That's it. That's every single game you'll ever play of this all the way to the top level. Don't believe me? Go on dotabuff and look up who has the top win-rates. Go on. Oh is it the easiest heros in the entire game that have the highest win-rate? How could that be if the game is truly based on skill?

The moment you pick your hero the game is already over. If the entire team doesn't counter-pick AND play perfectly, well gg there goes the next 45 minutes. You can lie to yourself and pretend its about last hits in lane and ward control and stacking / pulling and teamwork but you know deep down it's bullshit. If the moron using the brain-dead hero isn't literally afk none of that matters. They simply farm faster, push harder and kill easier. Why play anything else? It's easy and its free so why wouldn't you disgrace your family and country by taking the easy way out every time you're presented the opportunity? If you're at a distinct disadvantage before the game even begins you know you have a terrible competitive experience. If the pick / ban stage is more important than the game itself, no wonder auto battlers are becoming so popular. It's a natural evolution of "I'm terrible at everything so I'll only play games that cater to my defect."

It's like playing chess but one of the players can simply choose to start with more pieces. If you don't retaliate by using more pieces yourself then you lose.

I've wasted so much time on MOBAS and now my eyes are open. It's pointless. All of it. Those games will NEVER be about who's the better player. That doesn't matter and never has! It's about picking what's overpowered and easy. People that are total failures in life with no skill need something to play too and I realize that now. If they didn't have something just for them they would be on the street gagging on cock for heroin money so they can have "one last hit".
trash game, I regret playing this game for more than 10 years

I recommend this game for people who can enjoy it despite the generally terrible and horrifyingly toxic community. If you can ignore the griefing and the racial slurs or death threats in the all chat, this game is very fun to play. I wouldn't recommend this game for parents to buy for their children solely due to the environment they'd be subjected to. I personally wouldn't want my children/teen to read or hear (yes, there is open voice chat, for some reason) most of what the people say in game. Luckily I am not someone who is affected by it, but I had someone tell me to commit s*icide in-game today, totally unprovoked by anyone. No one was bothering him, as a matter of fact we were winning, and this behavior still continues. It doesn't happen in every match, but the bad definitely outweighs the good. There is some nice players in Dota 2, but the most of it, is NOT beginner friendly/supportive. Many people are mean and not understanding at all that you are new and/or may need some help. Even if you are new and do not need help, you will still receive bad treatment. If you are a veteran Dota player, you will still experience this. Like I said, it does indeed have it's wonderful fan-base, if you can find them. This game is not meant for people who cannot enjoy the game when these issues are taking place constantly. Also, PARENTS, please take time to read into reviews on online games and don't subject your child to the horrors that can be the gaming community. If you are a parent reading this, thinking about getting the game because your kid asked you for it, don't buy it for them until you think they're mature enough to handle the awful nature of humans. With all that being said I love the game, I just wish the people that played it were at peace with themselves.

Every day, millions of players worldwide enter battle as one of over a hundred Dota heroes. And no matter if it's their 10th hour of play or 1,000th, there's always something new to discover. With regular updates that ensure a constant evolution of gameplay, features, and heroes, Dota 2 has truly taken on a life of its own.

One Battlefield. Infinite Possibilities.
When it comes to diversity of heroes, abilities, and powerful items, Dota boasts an endless array‚Äîno two games are the same. Any hero can fill multiple roles, and there's an abundance of items to help meet the needs of each game. Dota doesn't provide limitations on how to play, it empowers you to express your own style.

All heroes are free.
Competitive balance is Dota's crown jewel, and to ensure everyone is playing on an even field, the core content of the game‚Äîlike the vast pool of heroes‚Äîis available to all players. Fans can collect cosmetics for heroes and fun add-ons for the world they inhabit, but everything you need to play is already included before you join your first match.

Bring your friends and party up.
Dota is deep, and constantly evolving, but it's never too late to join.
Learn the ropes playing co-op vs. bots. Sharpen your skills in the hero demo mode. Jump into the behavior- and skill-based matchmaking system that ensures you'll
be matched with the right players each game.

POSTED: 12 MARCH
This review is for new players who are considering installing this game.
From a player who has played this game for 5820 hrs, Dota2 is the number one free-to-play online game for me until now and I hope it always be.

Starting with the pros, anybody could be good at this game without spending any money as there is no cost for buying heroes, only some of them, which require more complex skills, will be unlocked when you reach the number of games played required(last checked 25 games of any heroes). Speaking of free to play, you might have questions about Dotaplus. Does having it make you play better than other players? Overall, it is like a shortcut for new players because it provides guides for picking heroes and building items. However, players could alternatively learn these things by experience or other free platforms. There are a lot of youtube channels or websites that provide FREE educational knowledge for this game. Hence, I disagree as the only Dotaplus function which is really useful for me is the option to avoid players.

Moreover, all heroes are well-designed to be played in various ways, making this game flexible. One hero could be played in 2-3 different roles depending on the trend of the current patch. In terms of item building, there is no fixed pattern for buying items. You will learn to analyze the game and build items according to the situation and your strategy. By experimenting with them, anyone could be the innovator of the meta(most effective tactics available).

Ultimately, for those who like beautiful cosmetics. There are tons of cool skins and limited cosmetic items you can get from seasonal events. And the fact that heroes' cosmetics could be customized part by part, you can make your own set of costumes. Besides the hero's skin, there are many magnificent creep(minion or whatever you want to call it) skins, terrain, towers, weather effects, HUD, and even announcer packs you can customize. And some of them are at a low price. And again, having these things doesn't affect your skill play.

However, there are some cons as well, namely, the toxic parts of the community. You may meet some players who have toxic attitudes which could affect your play. It would be great if you have good immunity and a positive mental attitude against these players.

Furthermore, Dota2 seems to be super complicated for beginners especially those who never experienced MOBA(massive online battle arena) games before. It takes time to go through the basics. So it is recommended to finish all the tutorials before entering normal matches. It might sound boring, but trust me, the more you learn, the more fun this game will become.

This game gives me a lot of things. As the servers open internationally, my English and typing skill are improved. I met a Thai friend who is in Norway last year and we have been playing together until now. This game also brought me a good community on Facebook which I can feel free to ask anything even it's not about Dota2. To conclude, I have no regret playing this game.

Over time, DOTA 2 has proven itself better than LOL.  Valve has worked hard on getting the experience as low drag and friction free as possible and the integration of the Steam marketplace is very tight even though it's in an external browser.
Hero customization is a big component of this game's appeal for me.  The number and type of customizations will keep me busy for a while. 
I played this game years ago and left because I liked LOL more.  Today the situation has reversed itself.  As a complete novice I like the DOTA 2 heroes and customization.  The gameplay and default controls are spot on. Also, starting this game from a publisher client that I keep running all day long is a huge plus.
Try DOTA 2 again if you left like me.  You'll come back.

Tough learning curve but great gameplay, on top of the visuals and sound design (including amazing voice acting). I always come back to Dota 2 periodically, no other game makes me love spending hours reading patch notes this much.

The playerbase however has as many friendly players as it has toxic ones, I recommend keeping a cool head and being nice even when you or your team are doing poorly. If some players are really making you mad, muting them is usually the best course of action. Furthermore, I recommend you to not start a new game right after finishing one, give yourself time to cool down as games of Dota can be very taxing emotionally, in both a good and bad sense.

My main gripe with the game is some aspects of its monetization, as years after years the Battle Passes feel like they require more and more money. I remember when the first arcanas could be bought cash for like $30. Now if you want that snazzy cosmetic for your favourite hero you need an overlevelled Battle Pass worth enough money to instead buy a few AAA games on Steam (or you know, things other than video games, it really is that much money).

But beyond the cosmetics, the gameplay itself is free, and even without a Dota+ subscription (that offers some quality of life that should be in the base game in my opinion), it really is enjoyable.

Also the lore is quite interesting.

It's a bit hard to rate this game, because the core gamemode, the performance, the entire client, test mode, the console, et cetera are superb. If I was rating patch 7.00 or around that era, I would definitely recommend, but the game is a lot more stale now to me. It's not *because* of the introduction of neutral items, but around that patch changes have gradually just been annoying or unimpactful. 

The game's biggest downside has been the matchmaking as long as I have been around, but you can't exactly leave a negative review on humanity. I come back every patch for a little to see if it sparks my interest again and it hasn't since 2019. I think it has gone further in the direction of other mainstream MOBAs and generally the changes have been unpleasant as I alluded to earlier. 

If you're getting into the game now, you probably missed the fun days. It's just an unhealthy pastime now that can sometimes give a modicum of satisfaction for all the stress it heaps onto you during a session. If you've been around a while you probably have 5k hours and understand the nuances of these changes better than I do.
