This game is essentially impossible to get into right now.
There is no new/returning player queue, except for one that tries to find players within a minute and if it doesn't, you'll just play a botgame, which is not only extremely boring, but also can't teach you how to play a game with real players.
Everyone hates you for not knowing the metagame and they'll let you know they're frustrated they had to play with you.
Guides are assuming your supports aren't actively trying to steal your farm after you've missed a single creep kill. Guides are assuming you're not the only one ever warding, while being the main carry.
And the enemy midlaner is going to be a russian smurf with 5000 hours on Invoker or Phantom Assassin every second game.

Well, the only way to get into the game is watch a hundred hours worth of the latest tournament to know the pick/ban metagame and play for maybe 500h in close proximity.

Also the community is worse than any other game's that I've ever seen. Better to turn voice chat down or off, so you don't get your ears hurt by screaming teammates.

Dota is a very team orientated game. If you dont play well with others, maybe give it a miss. 3 lanes, towers in each and an ancient. Death of the ancient (D-o-t-a). Destroy the ancient win the game. Fairly simple.

What make this game additive; If you curious about learning, team work, tactics and wit, all this plus an always updating meta leaving you with a very balanced game. Theres no pay to win, every game starts at the same, with 110 hero +. A 5V5 MATCH ,Leaving you with a new experience every single game.

Beside a balanced meta, there a very fluid comeback mechanic and regardless if yout losing, if you pull together as a team. get a little sneak you can turn the tables at any point (or throw it all away). And thats why its an incredible game. 

In terms of learning, there are a few techniques technically to understand. Learning about items across the different tiers in the game, early, mid, late. and how these items synergize with your own hero, your team and your enemies. I used to pick a hero, read there abilities and just have sooo much fun. I think its a game that requires a lot of acceptance, change flexibility. Every game is different and you need to think differently. 
The best players understand that. Some dont and you will lose.

Its always good to have some friends, as they will teach you alot, and just have a blast ! Give ti a shot its rather simple. take it a game/ hero at a time.

7.31 update it is obvious that the designer's goal tends to simplify hero skills to adapt to new players. Taking the techies as an example, it was originally a hero with relatively high learning cost. Self explosion death means weighing the pros and cons. The techies's use of remote-control bomb to kill people is required to control the whole map, map resource points, player psychology and important time nodes, Heroes have a deep understanding of their own damage calculation and a series of other skills. Now it's simple and rough to directly remove this skill. It's just to experience with new players, which makes old players sick. Although I am often defeated by the techies who the enemy can play, I don't feel that the game experience is poor, because this is the game experience that the techies on the opposite side deserves through learning. Our team doesn't have a good coping strategy because of experience. If we want a good game experience, the way is for the team to learn the strategy to deal with the techies, or an old player to tell his teammates how to deal with it through communication, Conversely, I can master the hero of the techies through learning, so I don't need the designer to delete this skill in order to save the player experience defeated by the powerful techies!!!!!!! If it is not for this reason to delete skills, but to let players experience the fun brought by new skills to players, please separate the skills of the techies in version 7.31 and become a new hero!!!!!!!!

Freezes on linux with an AMD Ryzen 9 3900 & NVIDIA RTX 2060 SUPER!

Tried several drivers, different distros, caching or not caching shaders, gamemode enabled or disabled, nothing works...

I used to love this game but this fk around has me so frustrated I've begun to hate the game (or more like the devs who clearly don't care about linux users).

Searching for fixes is such a headache, which is just a bunch of people giving loose theories that don't solve anything.

I'll have to go play something waaaay more resource intensive yet doesn't freeze. ü§¨

If you're looking to get into Dota 2, my recommendation is don't. If it were a couple years ago I'd say something about how it's one of those "hate to love it" games where you say it's bad but can't stop playing it and I'd say it's worth giving a try. But nowadays this game is slowly dying. Updates are few and far between, with less content and lazier content. Their promoting this big "Primal Beast" update but it only changes about 10% of the roster in any meaningful way and the new hero is just ripped assets from an event minigame. The game gets stale due to lack of meaningful updates and Valve's shown that they care a lot more about how much money they can squeeze out of the player base than the game's longevity. 

TLDR: The game's slowly dying out with fewer and lazier content updates. Most updates are just ways for valve to get more of your money with in game purchases.

I never thought I would get addicted to a ""click to move"" type of game, but oh boy, Dota 2 has some insane depth and replayability.
Each match is different! Community may be harsh and idiotic sometimes, but try to not let that stopping you from playing and enjoying it! It really is the best Free to Play game.
It requires you to learn many little things, skills, items, timings etc. You must play for at least 100 hours to get a grip of it, and about 1000h to know a bit of everything. So patience and skill is required!
With all the hours played I still learn new things and new interactions in the gameplay every day. This game is so deep and gives you such a variety of experiences! Still completely free of charge, try it for oyurself but give it several attempts, don't give up on the first lost match!
With continuous support from Valve and heavy gampleay impacting updates, you are always required to re-learn and adapt. Gameplay is always balanced and thoughtful. Absolutely no pay2win involved, all just cosmetics.

The hardest, most frustrating, most rewarding game on the planet. You and 9 other people, hundreds of abilities/items, infinite possible situations, games can go from 15 minutes to 2 hours.

If your friends play it and are trying to get you into it, you too can have fun, after a tiny commitment of 100+ hours before you stop getting yelled at.

As someone that's played both, League of Legends has the superior new player experience and a more "mobile game" feel to it, but doesn't have anywhere near the depth of DotA. Everything in League is constantly balanced to make each role feel fun and rewarding. In DotA, everything is unfair and overpowered, and it's on you to prove that your team is more unfair than theirs. Hour-long games end in a moment because of a single misclick.

If you read all that and still think it sounds fun, go for it.

I was a complete noob, picking Riki and Slark every game.

And then, DOTA Plus came into my life! The computer told me to pick Juggernaut, and to go mid-lane against a Shadow Fiend. I was skeptical, certain that I couldn't possibly out-harass someone with three razes, but then DOTA plus suggested I use Blade Fury!

The three razes wiffed against my spin-to-win, and I was about to run back, but then DOTA Plus gently took control of my mouse, moving it unbidden of my will! He ran forward, not drawing creep aggro while laying down magic damage onto the SF.

Then DOTA Plus alerted me that the enemy Ogre Magi was missing, and got me to safety. After this, DOTA Plus opened all chat, and taunted the SF about having to share XP with the Ogre. They began fighting in a language I didn't understand, but thankfully DOTA Plus comes with machine language learning too, and began flaming them in their native tongue!

Not only that, but DOTA Plus suggested that I could have another cup of water, and informed me that it would handle the last-hits for the next minute and a half. On my time away from the computer, my eyes wandered out of my window, and locked onto a woman my age, with beautiful eyes. The connection was instant, but I had DOTA to play.

However, when I returned to my computer, DOTA Plus told me "Go to her, go to her, tell her you love her, and NEVER let go! Life is too short!" Then DOTA Plus got a rampage on my behalf under the enemy Tier 3. Clearly, I wasn't needed here.

I have been married for five years now, and now I am climbing to Divine 5 while brushing up on fulfilling hobbies, like learning the violin and writing my novel manuscript. Thank you DOTA Plus, you have saved my life, and made me a happy and fulfilled human being.

For me MOBA is failing as genre little by little. 
You can play it if you like the game and want to make money (as a professional) but as a regular player I find it very unwelcome place (same as League of Legends and any other MOBA)

The concept of playing 5vs5 requires you to engage 4 friends to play comfortably. If you play solo, the problem will be communication. People are different and in competitive game when you need to form a team extremely fast it fails in 80%. 

The game itself is unfair. I understand why but the fact is the fact. You simply cannot balance 100+ heroes with 4+ spells, additional sub upgrades for skills, items, map, etc. It's simply too much. 

The way the roles are defined also needs work. People always relie on carry and humiliate supports for their uselessness. 
Apart from LOL where every role can carry the game, here you only have a carry type of heroes and the whole game will relies on them which pushes people in solo queue to train only carry type heroes.

Welcome to Dota2, The place where you can hone your mental ability and friendship. Especially when you are a solo player.
The community in this game is on the level of transcendent (monkey). Communication in game is very vital, especially from your teammate. The common keyword from your teammate will be something like "g" "b" "noob" "fuck off" "useless" etc.

If you are a Carry, be careful of your support! Especially the one with the god-like ability "Hook" or something that they can hide and bam! use skill on the enemy(ies) from afar. These people will stay in the dark jungle, waiting forever for the "right" moment to spam their skill, which often missed. After they left you on your own in the lane and you die because the enemies keep fucking you with all their skill, they will start teleporting to the other lane. When your score hit "0-3" or more, the commication between teammate will suddenly improve. the words like "useless carry" or "noob" is commonly said to you despite the fact that it's him who left you alone to die in the first place. If you are lucky and somehow win the game, your teammate will keep praising you at the end of the game with words like, "you are lucky" or something similar. BUT.... if you lose the game. no matter whose fault it is, the words coming from your teammate will be "noob carry" or "useless". This is where you can hone your mental ability to the max! Brace yourself.

There are great things about this game, the well design roles of heroes and the system that forced you to coordinate with your teammate in order to devise a strategy to crush your enemies. Everything is perfect, except the part that the human is the one who control those awesome heroes.

TLDR; don't ever let your child touch this game. let them stay away from the transcendent monkey community.

I really enjoy Dota 2. Moba's are probably my favorite genre of games and coming from Smite and League of legends, Dota is definitely my favorite. 

The mechanics of how you move and how spells work are mainly unique and that is what draws me to this game. Every character is a new learning process and keeps you engaged with countless possibilities of what you can do with that character.

The skill gap is insane. Which isn't a horrible thing. It gives sort of a longevity vision that one day you could be on that level. Knowing what's happening every moment and how to correctly respond. That reason alone makes me come back no matter getting absolutely stomped or getting carried. There's always something to learn or something new to try.

My only complaint. The community. Okay, I understand that if you are playing a game that you have thousands of hours in that it can be annoying getting someone new. Someone that doesn't just understand how the game fully works just yet. But that doesn't give you the reason to be flat out horrible to someone. So many people try to gatekeep this game that trying to get my friends to try and enjoy this game is hard. I get trash talk and banter between teams but there is a line and i think there should be more harsh punishment for crossing it. If you are playing UNRANKED expecting a RANKED team comp with everyone playing like they are in the finals of TI. You are part of the problem. Yes you can say "just mute all and play the game" but this is a team communication game. Even some of the slightest, smallest bits of information can make all the difference in a match. 

I don't have nearly enough experience or time in this game to represent it but these are my opinions from sinking 500 hours into it. It's a great game and I'm not gonna stop playing no matter who I encounter or however many times I lose. It is just sad to see such a beautiful game with a pretty gnarly community.

Depression is a mental state of low mood and aversion to activity. Classified medically as a mental and behavioral disorder, the experience of depression affects a person's thoughts, behavior, motivation, feelings, and sense of well-being. The core symptom of depression is said to be anhedonia, which refers to loss of interest or a loss of feeling of pleasure in certain activities that usually bring joy to people. Depressed mood is a symptom of some mood disorders such as major depressive disorder or dysthymia; it is a normal temporary reaction to life events, such as the loss of a loved one; and it is also a symptom of some physical diseases and a side effect of some drugs and medical treatments. It may feature sadness, difficulty in thinking and concentration and a significant increase or decrease in appetite and time spent sleeping. People experiencing depression may have feelings of dejection, hopelessness and suicidal thoughts. It can either be short term or long term.

If Dendi Was Bad - A Lengthy Shitpost

So imagine you're at a fair with your father. You must be a child cause he's been dead for a decade. You're hungry. He smiles and gives you some cotton candy. You've never tried it before. You're reluctant. He urges you to give it a go. You put it in your mouth. It's heaven clothed in a pink robe. It's a cloud of joy wrapped in the sugar, blood and tears of your screaming pinoy enemies. The taste, the texture, it's so fresh. And you're young and its sweet. You love it. That combination of sticky substance and light fluffiness, it enraptures you. You eat and eat and before you know it its gone. 

Your father laughs and you grin at him, errant pink strands caught between your teeth. You know you shouldn't. Your dentist tells you tooth decay is the leading cause of erectile dysfunction in support players who have decided to ruin your game because they don't approve of your hero pick. You mute your dentist. Cotton candy is lovely. Throughout the day you get more and more. The day is great. It is the last time you'll go to the fair with him. 

Your father is sick. Your mother has started drinking. Dancing takes the pain away but even that has started to lose its shine. You sneak a drink from your mother's bottle of vodka, the one she thinks no one knows about. She hides it under the sink. You can't read the label but the liquid seems to speak to you from inside the glass. –ì–ª—É–ø–∞—è, –ø–æ—á–µ–º—É —É —Ç–µ–±—è –Ω–µ—Ç –ø—ã–ª–∏ –∑–∞ BH. It can't be that bad, she cries less loudly after she drinks. It stings as it goes down, harsh and prickly. You can feel it in the back of your mouth. You choke and sputter. It hurts, but not as much as the fishing trip you and your father just shared. You take another drink. It starts to work. You know it does, you can barely feel the Spectre of your father's diagnosis hanging over you. Haunt is a great skill, personal risk is for scrubs. You keep drinking. 

He's gone now. Your mother tries her best, she's cleaned up. She knows that no matter what she feels she wants to make sure that you'll get through it. You love her for it but the Vodka does things for you she never could. And you have a new escape. It's called Dota. It was free. You bathe the void of your father's loss with temporary triumph. Monster kill, godlike. They tip you in impotent rage. Your team flames them. They flame each other. You stand atop their quivering, lifeless bodies as they wait to respawn. You howl your victory at the screen. It helps, for a time. You forget he's gone when you make others disappear. You feel good, like a craftsman at his forge. Death isn't random and impersonal but controlled and handed out to the deserving. It's odd but you think you can understand better the grim nature of the reaper. His quiet pride at a job efficiently performed. Their offlane feeds for the 10th time, he's given up, his team are in the depths of despair and voicing as much over all chat. You smile at their vitriol, as sweet as cotton candy. The work is never done. Control over others at the click of a button. Satisfaction on tap. It won't last.  

More time passes. You get good enough to play for the pros. You aren't good enough to stay. You reached your peak somewhere down the line. Other's didn't. Your abilities faded, for your opponents it surged. Easy victories give way to hard fought wins. Hard fought wins become tight affairs. Tight affairs become demoralizing losses. Demoralizing losses spiral into a string of red. Your mother has started crying again but you long ago ceased to care. Only the work matters, sweet very rarely, harsh all too often. You hit the bottle. 

You have seen the depths of hell. It is not a cosmic place, a locale made by a divine hand. It is man made, only man could devise such a human portal into suffering. So sweet and tempting, so harsh and filled with light. They enter willingly and stay reluctantly. A perfect trap, an exquisite torture device. The lord of fallen angels watches with envy. Who can tolerate this den of toxicity, this mire of spite and hate. Mistakes are forever, perfection fleeting. Consistent victory a mere mirage, only tilting is eternal. The trench stretches into the vast horizon of infinity. 9.3k MMR average but doesn't know how to pull a camp. Alien species secretly harvest the emotion generated to fuel their empires. You can only survive by ignoring everyone, what do they know anyway? Who are they to preach to the reaper? You've learnt how to insult someone's mother in Japanese. You think on the void. You try to forget your father. You press accept. 

Your time is done. You know it. They know it. You struggle to reach the peaks of your youth. The perpetrator becomes the victim. You've plummeted from such heights but still you refuse to relinquish your struggle. You can now conduct a hateful argument in 10 different languages but you can't tell the French girl at the 7/11 you like her. You can tell when a game is lost before the teams have even spawned at fountain. You can phrase opinions as if they were facts like a pro. You can seethe fruitlessly with the best of them. You type furiously as your throne explodes as their Techies spams voicelines. At surface level all you can feel is rage. Deeper down you see your own madness reflected in his. One broken by his inability, the other enshrining his own as if it will last forever. You know better. It doesn't help. What would your father say? You shudder. Better not to think on it. Better to dwell on better times. You lean back in your chair, and take another swig. So you take yourself away. Past victories. Gone glory. Some sweet to dull out the harsh. But even those days blur. You can barely remember them now they seem so distant. You have to go further. So imagine, if you would, that you're at the fair with your father...

TLDR - Go on, try it. You'll never forget.

When you start this game you will be 10 times worse than the lowest setting bots (Passive). 

You hop on unranked and get laughed at by many people who feel you are truly less than them, with few who tell you you're doing good for your first day playing. People tell you to ask for guides and to ask specific questions on your build so they can help you instead of make fun of you.

You watch 2 hours of Alexander Coccia (Funny guy, great beginner guide) and you start to understand the very basics of the game that you thought you wouldn't need to know. Feeling the tips of these videos and understanding more about gaining exp, you feel a sudden urge to hop back on and attempt to utilise your new-found knowledge.

You hop back into unranked solo, get queue'd with people who are over level 300 in the battlepass and somehow do worse as you feed your lane while attempting to deny and last hit creeps as your support camps behind tower and calls you a bot, saying just don't get hooked by pudge and watching you get 2v1'd.

After a few more games and some DATOHLEONG vids, you realise that to be mediocre in the game you need an extensive knowledge of the matchups of over 100 characters, as well as a sincere desire to be viewed as less than a human for playing unranked and not bots- 
so you say screw it and go back to csgo

From a veteran LoL players perspective:

Been playing the MOBA genre for a long time. I played LoL for years before trying out Dota, making it to Plat 1 back during Season 8. 

Thought I'd give Dota a try after LoL lost some of its integrity, I put 100 hours in for the ranked queue, and then played another 50 or so before writing this review.

First, nothing is really balanced in this game. You'll die to stuff that you literally had to ability to counter. You also can't surrender, and this is honestly the worst part of Dota. You're stuck in a game dieing over and over for 45 minutes. It just is not fun at that point. Atleast you can FF at 20 in league.

I won't lie and say I did not have fun, but this is one of those games where losing feels 500% worse than winning feels good. Yeah, close games are fun, and it's cool to battle it out with your friends, but most games are not like that. Usually, it's a stomp in either direction, and the worst part is that it is often UNPREVENTABLE. 

You can't stop your team from dieing, getting caught out, building the wrong items, or ganking your lane and dieing. So, even if you play well, you still have to deal with the 8/0 laner in mid that has posted a tent up next to your lane. 

It's just like every moba-you have to try to last hit creeps, its super snowbally, and it simply is not fun to lose. League of Legends is better because there's actually some semblance of balance in it. Yes, champions can get fed and high level, but nothing compared to Dota. I don't think I have ever, except in bot games in League, seen a champion that is literally double my level. Can't say the same for Dota-as a matter of fact, it's common for people to sit 50-75% above your level, especially as support. 

Really, the mechanics in this game just are not fun. Some hero's are ABSURDLY unpowered compared to others, and honestly there is so much un-fun playing against people. Stun for 5 seconds, root for 5 seconds, stun for another 5, silence for 10 seconds,....whats even the point? I can't even play my hero because of this kind of BS.

Your barracks also don't respawn like inhibis do in league, and mega creeps basically make the game unwinnable. XP denial by last hitting is a super annoying mechanic to an already absurdly tedious part of the game. This is the other thing-last hitting SUCKS in dota. attack animations are extremely different between hero's, and misclicking on friendly creeps or heros makes your hero stop, often resulting in a death.

Pulling creep wave onto monster camps is also just a un-fun mechanic that makes losing even worse. Yeah, in league they can freeze wave, but eventually it will push. In Dota, you literally will not get the gold or xp for a wave when that is like the ONE thing that actually enables consistent progression.

The hero kits are also just not thoughtful either. Atleast in League it feels like champions abilities synergise. Dota just slaps together some abilities and calls it good. 

Ranked role queue also doesn't make any sense. I have to play 100 hours to even try ranked, and when I do I'm forced to select a support role. What the hell is the point of role queue when to even play I'm forced to queue for a position I never play?? 

MOBA's are toxic, as most online games are. Still, Moba's attract a certain group of people that flame in unique ways. I was no stranger to this, coming from League, but the difference in dota is that you get flamed for playing even slightly out of line with your roll. For example, I read a long article about LoL players getting into Dota, and how there was less rigidity in role's than League, but I found the opposite to be true. Your position in game mineaswell be a genetic trait. 

Buyback is also a generally annoying feature because it often punishes the winning team. Atleast in League when you ace the enemy team you can push objectives.

But if I had to pick one thing about this game that really seals the deal for my uninstall, it's the developers complete disregard for a balanced experience. There's heros that teleport all over the map, turn invisible every 5 seconds, literally become immortal every 20 seconds, become immune to everything your hero does,  and ultimately create a feeling of helplessness. 

That's why I quit this game.  I have over a thousand hours on LoL and Rocket League. Over 300 on GTA online, 500+ on Call of Duty, thousands on runescape, and over 500 on Age of Empires. Yes, in every single one of those games, there's really annoying stuff that can make gameplay unfun, but Dota makes me feel helpless to it. It's like when I play this game, I anticipate not having fun because of the presence of certain hero's. 

I know there's plenty of people with tons of hours on this game who can devise counter play for every fathomable situation, but ask yourself this. Is it fun to play around the enemy's global silence that prevents you from using any abilities for 5 seconds, in addition to their 3 five seconds stun, as well as their hero that literally can't die? 

To me, no. When 80% of the hero's in this game have straight up cancerous kits, I don't want to play. Why would I want to? What's the point? I can play very well all game, only to be stunned for 10 seconds from the other f*** side of the map, and then exploded to zero HP. What is the counterplay to that?? Heck, there's been games where the enemy team is so fed that my team can't even fight them in the spawn where we are getting healed and they are taking constant damage.

tl;dr DOTA is a game that will make you feel helpless and forced to learn and play around mechanics that are not fun. The most fun part of the game is mid game fighting where both teams are on a semi-even playing field. This is where people get creative with their positioning, items, invisibility, and hero strengths and weaknesses. The sad part is that 90-99% of the game experience is not that. Instead, it's doing tedious things like killing creeps and farming, tiptoeing around broken hero's that are ungodly fed, sitting under tower sweatily trying to last hit and regen hp, along with playing a walking simulator. 

Do yourself a favor and play something else. 1-5% of this game is fun. The rest is honestly terrible.

after 500hrs playing dota : 

The game is great, but this game community is toxic and it gets hard with new players, the game does not do anything for new players to learn the game, it just forces them to pay for skins and battle passes.

Do you see players with accounts since 2013, or do you see players with more than 7,000 hours played, compared to players with 200 games played, and the only reason for this is that the "mmr" number of these two players is equal.

I do not call it balanced ranking system.

Players have to play at the level they are at, not just with a "MMR" number, their level of play is determined, and it is very easy for people with a higher level of play to play at a lower MMR, and it is very difficult for newplayers (people who are less than 1000 hours of play) to improve their game skills or so-called "rank up" themselves. In my opinion, "rank up" now means only increasing the number based on winning and losing games and the level of skill of the players will not improve.

As a (previous and current) League player, I must say Dota 2 is indeed a better MOBA game.  Perhaps the only drawback is that it's too addictive...

Edit: League and DotA 2 are two different games and it is not fair to claim that one is better than the other, and let's just say that I love both games equally.  DotA 2 is better at its versatility, in a sense that the game can be much more variable and unpredictable with the active skills of the items and there's always a chance for a comeback whereas this is less likely in League especially when a team is really behind.  DotA 2 focuses on its game mechanics, for instance every hero could initiate a fight with the purchase of a blink dagger, whereas League focuses on the more trivial parts like farming and positioning and each champion has a comparatively more unique characteristic and playstyle.  

Anyway, my point is that it is barely possible for one to claim one game is better than the other.  Both games are great and fun!

Hands down Dota2 has the greatest depth, gameplay variety, most different game experiences from one game to another.

+ It has the most hyped moments, the most impressive plays, the funniest fails, 
+ It is more friendly to a wide range of ages, whether your strong points are quick and mechanically complicated plays or whether you are not as quick but you have patience and you are strategic, methodical.
+ The game graphics support its "meaty" gameplay feel, ultimate abilities have a huge impact.
+ There are a lot of heroes and they are wildly different and unique.
+ All the heroes are free there is no paywall, no real pay to win, it's only pay to look fancy and sparkly.
+ The items are also unique and impactful, these are not straight power-ups, these are solutions to problems your team faces or will face  (Dota also provides in game ability to follow other player-created builds that work out very well 90% of the games)
+ Huge modding scene.
+ Watching replays of your own games or anyone else's games or watching pro matches or just watching high-ranked player matches is super easily accessible.
+ there are multiple alternative game mods you can play, they offer a unique way of playing and  secretly help you learn the game better
+/- The game is receiving updates, some are negatively received other ones are very welcomed, the changes specifically after longer periods of not playing- can be very refreshing but they can also make you feel fallen out of the loop.

- Patience is required, if you have non you will suffer till you learn it.
- If you don't already play MOBA games- you will have to be able to overcome your worst version of yourself to succeed or just to be able to have fun with the games whether you win or lose.
- Your fuckups will be painfully apparent to you and to anyone else who is watching, you will occasionally singlehandedly lose the whole game.
- People will be critical of your mistakes, tho that is hardly a rare thing in competitive team games/sports.
- it takes couple thousand hours to start to feel that you are somewhat competent at the game on the upside- you are never bored.
- Anyone can and will make mistakes in this game.

Playing Dota 1 since 4.67 patch and Dota 2 for 7 years range in my lifespan was not positive experience. The community is very toxic and matchmaking was very unbalanced at the time when I was playing. Every match the teammates start flaming each other or one another, which later results in loss. Report system was not working properly and most of players were not getting banned. Over many of years playing of Dota 2 there were constant updates that were messing up the champions (making others broken and others weak, or reverse).

There were various items for champions and it was very overwhelming to buy each champion items  or farm every battle. They are basically worth pennies now and all purchases I have made are worthless now. 

Ranking system is very unbalanced when you are high rank, highest I got was 5400 at the time of playing and there were only a few high rank players that were playing as a group and making the matchmaking was very slow to find. It took about +15 minutes of waiting.

After quiting this game and watching the Dota 2 series movie coming into realization that there are other players who have the same struggle as me. I have quit playing Dota 2, have not played for about 5 years. I do not reject, and am being happy to quit this toxic community and addiction of the game I had. 

Be happy outside, build new friends and play other games! Thank you for reading.

TLDR this is like being in middle school thinking you might like to play football, and then getting dropped into an arena football league with a bunch of angry bastards who want to humiliate you and make you quit. It's not worth the grief, play pretty much anything else.

Are you already really good at this game? No? Then go find something else to do. It is filled with small angry people who have no patience for anyone who isn't professional. They will offer you lots of helpful advice, such as:
"YOU BOUGHT THAT ITEM?!?! WITH THAT CHARACTER!!! ARE YOU AN IDIOT?" 
"Why do you keep dying?"
"SMFH... Worst player I've ever seen"
"You should delete this game and die"

And that's after you actually start getting positive KD spreads. Players love to look in your inventory and scrutinize your decisions, ping the hell out of you when you fail to save their ass, or they just don't like what you're doing. But don't worry, they won't offer you helpful, actionable advice, just yell at you like children. 

Also, Valve can fuck off with its reporting system. There's no appeal function, so for example, when my power dipped during an ice storm and I lost my connection, but was able to get back into the game a few minutes later, it still counted that as an "abandon" and I got stuck in "low priority" purgatory. When you're in low priority, you have to win three matches to get out, which is terrible if you're not very good, because everyone else is there for abandoning games, so they will just leave if things aren't going well. I think in took me over 10 matches to get out of it. Again, for losing my connection, but making it back into the match before it ended. That was almost 10 hours spent wondering why I was wasting my time. "It'll get better..." I told myself. 

And I did get better, but god forbid you want to try a new character and you don't absolutely dunk it on your first try. Players will eat your face. And, the savvy ones have figured out that they can complain about you in game unlimited times and trigger the overwatch system, resulting in a complete, unquestioned 4 hour ban. Now, it will ultimately be reversed when an actual human watches the recording of the game and realizes you didn't do anything, but if I have time to play video James now... then I probably don't have time in four hours, meaning one asshat can ruin your plans to play, just because they think you play like shit. It's complete and utter nonsense. 

The fact that you can't play ranked games until you've played for 100 hours is insane. So instead of playing against other people who might ostensibly be around your same skill level when your getting started, you just get paired up with any ole body. So you get to be all the fish in the barrel. And most of the people in there have logged thousands of hours on this game, and they cannot fathom anyone not having done the same. There's a "beginner mode" where they let you choose out of the 10 most boring characters and then have you play against bots with names to make you think you're playing with and against real people. I played there, not realizing that, until I was pretty consistently getting mvp, and then decided to graduate and realized that the bots played nothing like real people, and that being mvp there still means your garbage in the regular game. 

I would like Valve to refund the hours of my life I wasted on this horrible game. It was better as a custom map for WC3. I wish there was an "absolutely not" option for the recommendation.

I used to play this game religiously during the dota 1 days,came back again years later in the mid of 2019 after randomly installing it out of boredom during the pandemic, here's a few words I can share regarding the game from my experience in the past 2 years as well as it being a parting letter in a way.  

Playing again after a long time I didn't really spend much time on the game intitially then after 2-3 months the same person that use to skip riding bus for the half hour playing time of cyber cafe came back again.

This game will cripple all your ambitions outside of dota,seeing yourself slowly deteriorating mentally and physically day by day, by the time you noticed all your mannerism and your outlook for others would change maybe that was always within who knows, mentally killing at least 100 people by your 1000th hour and several more as your in-game time increases.

 Maybe I'm not ranking up cause of my hero pool, maybe it's my mentality, maybe maybe maybe it's the server that I'm playing in full of DIVERSE personalities,maybe it's all of the above and if I can work it out MAYBE I'll make it out and win the big million.

I've never been more passionate and absolutely hate a thing at the same time in my entire life, The only thing I regret would be not achieving immortal as a parting gift (divine 2), Ironically the only thing I regret would be not playing more.

The saying "there's always a good and a bad side to everything". Dota is the epitome of that saying. Best vedio game of all time no doubt. 

In conclusion I would absolutely recommend the game 10/10.

I don't think that I will state anything new in this review, since it was reviewed by many people who played this game better then I do, and understand this game better then me. But I must state some things. From my experience, this game is probably the hardest game I ever played. First you need to understand it completely to be able to play as efficient as possible. If you don't do that, you will always be a lower bracket toxic player cause you don't know why your teammates did something, and you blame them for your loss even though they are not a guilty party here. You are.

Second - I tried to play competitive Dota, didn't get very far, played some small tournaments, but boy, the actual team play is another level of game play here. If you synced with your teammates and you have them on Teamspeak or any other software to help you communicate with a headset, your knowledge and understanding of the game will rise exponentially. A completely new level of this game. And I love that part. Sure, you will still lose the games, and other teams may play better then you, but you will learn so much here.

3rd. Even if you don't have a team, communication is everything. If you don't speak English, don't go to English language servers. If you don't speak Russian, don't go to the Russian server. It is as simple as that. You will not find glory elsewhere if you didn't find it in your own language area. You need to learn to communicate everything inside the game. Be it public game, or teamplay. It is critical to winning anything. 

And finally, my closing word. Don't be toxic, ever, towards anybody in this game. It will get you nowhere. You need to be polite, well mannered, everybody wants to win a game, help them out, rather then complaining all the time and being negative. If others are toxic towards you, mute them and play to your best knowledge of the game ever. Watch what team is doing. Don't jungle your next item if your team is fighting a fight. Go out, help the team, take down the tower, then maybe go back to the jungle. Or even better, take out the Roshan. Feel what team needs.

Good Luck and Goodspeed to anybody who is still playing this game. I had enough. 5000 hours was more then enough, I need my chill now, I am off to play the Euro Truck SImulator 2, but for those about to rock, we salute you.

During the beginning stages of Dota 2 I didn't consider it an amazing game but it's definitely one of the more progressive and continually evolving. Anyhow, over the last couple (+/-) years, they introduced the Arcade games, which I looooooooove, becoming a reason to return to this game regularly. The one thing I cannnnnnnot stand is their failed punishment system for supposed abandonment of games. It's not uncommon for the game to glitch out or for a slight connection lapse to result in a failed "Accept" attempt. You're literally penalising people for your own system's errors, as well as unintentional mistakes and not even offering a method to rescind it. For example, an option to quickly dispute why you couldn't click accept which an automated system replies to. Just ridiculous, especially when your hyped before another shitty day of work or right after a hard shift for example. Literally I give it a 3 out of 5 for A, not tackling a long standing issue and B, making it the consumer's problem doubly so by awarding penalties when none was earnt.

[h1] 9/10 [/h1]
Looking back now, my first exposure to Dota was Dota 1 6.78 b version. At the time, I didn't know much about Dota at all, but its fun-filled gameplay still fascinated me at the time. July 15, 2014, was the first time I came into contact with Dota 2. Compared with Dota 1, Dota 2 not only optimized a lot in UI, model, operation, and experience, but the version update after that has also kept Dota 2 alive. Looking back now, the period from 2014 to 2016 was probably my favorite time for Dota 2. At that time, there was no clear role positioning, and I mostly knew little about the game. In the end, it took more than 2,000 hours, and I only got about the rank of archon 4, which was 2800MMR at that time. The 7.0 version update is the biggest change for DOTA. The newly added talent tree system and various game updates even made many people call this game Dota 3 at that time. While the game keeps getting better, my interest in Dota 2 has been dwindling ever since. The changes are too big, and I don't have much time to understand these changes. Many times I will find that my understanding of heroes and items is still stuck in the previous version. Around 2019, I temporarily gave up on Dota 2.

Around November 2020, I tried Dota 2 again. With my original understanding of the game, I won Legend IV in the positioning match on this account, 3700MMR. But as I continued to play, I found that the game environment of this game started to get worse and worse. Many Legend and even Ancient players don't even know some basic game operations and awareness, they will make some incredible operations in the ranked match. And there is no longer that kind of tolerance between players. Players who don't understand the content of the game won't listen to other people's advice at all, and even give up on themselves. I'm used to the verbal abuse between teams. After a game is over, many opponents like to type slightly insulting words like Noob, GG EZ, which makes people feel that the game environment full of competitive style in the past is no longer. In addition, although Legend is not a very high rank, I not only find that the matching queue time required here is getting longer and longer, usually, 5-15 minutes or even longer, and this rank has a lot of players who lack understanding of the game also surprised me. After all, the rank of Legend IV can already be in the top 30% of this game, and the rank below this, which I have experienced before, the current rank between 1000MMR and 3000MMR is even more difficult for me to imagine. Undoubtedly, either this is the irrationality of the positioning mechanism itself or the overall decline of the player's level.

These are all my opinions. I also finally decided to give up Dota 2 again, and I'm afraid I won't be coming back. For new players, the learning cost of Dota 2 is too high. At the same time, it only takes 100 hours to play the ranked game in the game, which makes many new players go directly to the ranked game after 100 hours of games, which will destroy the game environment in the ranked match. And now the overall game environment is also full of maliciousness for new players. Many players do not even have a tolerant attitude towards new players in ordinary matchmaking modes, and the content of Dota 2's tutorials is too little. 

I really like Dota 2, and I really agree that it's a masterpiece. But why is Dota 2's user base and word of mouth declining compared to League of Legends now? I think it does have a lot of problems, and those problems are more focused on the game environment. I personally think that this game takes a certain amount of time as a learning cost for new players and Dota old players, and the current game environment is often too harsh. If you want to try it, you must be mentally prepared.

Finally, farewell to you, Dota 2, and thank you for being with me for the 9 years I've read. I will never, never forget you.

100% do not waste your time playing this game. Once the game selects you into a bracket it's nearly impossible to get out of it.  You can improve and play for hours, but the algorithm is built to ensure you a 50% win rate.  As soon as you begin to go above that 50% win rate you will be thrown into a queue that positions you with players that are drastically losing their games in an effort to 1. help their probability of a 50% win rate and 2. bring your win rate back to 50%. Unless you are a smurf that is able to solo carry a game you will not be able to improve your status and this is why the game has such a problem with smurfs.  People create smurf accounts for that very reason. There is no winning in this game regardless of improvement so save yourself the time and don't melt your brain trying to get good at a game that is against you doing so.

The greatest sin this game commits is being too complex and too team based. The average retard you will get on your team is just not mentally fit enough to play the game properly. Wheras other MOBAs have dumbed down their gameplay to a point where it is barely a MOBA DOTA has retained many of the niche mechanics and game play depths when it first started. I imagined when DOTA 1 was around this was not an issue as it was more niche and players were dedicated and also discovering many new mechanics. Today in DOTA 2 this hardcore complexity means that you will often have players who do not understand the game even after dumping hours into it. They will play with bad tempo, bad picks and bad item builds. After playing a 25 games of the latest league season on a new account I saw perhaps one or two bad builds but these were newer level players and unranked matches and no game throwing picks. In 25 games of RANKED DOTA 2 I saw numerous bad builds and picks that were game throwing. Nyx offlane with echo saber, skull basher, and deso. Medusa rushing a swift blink as a first major item. 3 Silencer offlanes. DK offlane rushing a malestrom. The list goes on. It genuinely seems like the game is too complex for the average play to play to have this many examples of awful builds and choices and this is only in builds this is not to mention that many other macro and micro mistakes players will make and mechanical mistakes. The game requires you to rely on 4 randoms to help you complete tasks that a team of pro players that have known each other for years sometimes struggle to execute. There are many heroes and mechanics that simply cannot be pulled off in a pub or in a ranked match. The more you invest into the game the less you get out of it as you find numerous retards around you taking away any work you put in.

Well, what is there to say about Dota... It requires a lot of time to get the basics down, but it's well worth the time. It never gets boring! Be sure to groupe up with friends and allways, ALLWAYS have voice chat, even while playing with complete strangers. Communication is key. No team = no win :)

To anyone that might have already assumed it, here is an official explanation on the forced 50%: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lgjEMgc96ik

Please note, that this is for a specific mmr range and does not really apply to exceptional players like immortal rank. In summary, the game will always try to keep you at 50% winrate by defining losing and winning teams. This is why often you have a losing or a winning streak 10-20 games in a row. 

Now I want everyone to think about why you play this game? Is it fun for you or do you actually want to gain rank. For me it was a long time about rank and I gained up to 5.2k mmr, often in packets like 400 mmr, but then losing 400 mmr straight away.

I have been playing Defense of the Ancients since its inception; just like it's mother, Aeon of Strife. There were only a handful of heroes for each side, names were different, there were abilities that no longer exist or moved from one hero to another. I continued to play dota and dota beta custom matches for the next 4 years as I climbed the WC3 TFT ranks into the top 200, always playing dota alongside my normal warcraft 3 matches. 

I was birthed into DOTA alongside a small group of others during Eul's creation and release of the game in 2003. I  suffered through the Guinsoo era, and thrived with the dawn of Icefrog. DOTA is the father of all MOBA games. There are others, but for over 15 years there is one constant that has kept DOTA surprisingly fresh, interesting, and challenging. Icefrog. The man is a balancing guru, expert, veteran, and genius.

As for the game that he has created, there is no other like it for those who are seeking a competitive and challenging experience. With over 100 heroes, each having 4 abilities or more to learn, the game has a STEEP learning curve, but boy is it rewarding. There are roles in DoTA like other moba games, but there is potential for certain heroes to step outside of that boundary and still be a significant force on the battlefield. This allows for more variety and diversity in game, sure there are meta heroes and picks but in DOTA, any team can win. 

If you want to have a frustratingly wonderful and rewarding experience gaming, play dota. The community can be toxic to those who dont try, dota is not forgiving. There is no surrender option, when you play a game of dota you are committing yourself to that game and your teammates, and many of those who play have the winners mentality. If you dont care about losing, maybe dota can help you understand that winning is always more fun. 

All in all, be prepared to spend a decent amount of time learning and understanding the complexities that a game like dota has to offer. At surface level, it may seem pretty shallow, but these waters are deep. There are many tactics that can be used that may seem miniscule but make a huge difference when playing the game. 

If you spend a lot of time playing MOBA games, I strongly feel that you should be playing dota. I have played every other MOBA that has ever come to be. All are mere candles in the light of DOTA; which comparatively, would be like a sun in the sky.

Been playing this game for a lot of years. Should have been a lot's of rank up if not for the toxic set of players here. This game used to be a lot of fun before, nowadays there are lot of people who purchase higher rank accounts and you don't have enough reports to report all these players, So you end up losing your MMR and Rank eventually. Battle pass ain't good as before. It's like too much money to get good costume sets / other stuffs in the game. Previously as a F2P you get a lot of these good stuffs by playing regularly. Nowadays that's also gone. The only thing you get as a F2P is to get to play with the majority of the toxic community. At some point you'll start wondering why the matchmaking is so stupid that they constantly give you such idiotic players and how come they're not even banned. And you won't have enough reports to report them all as well. But guaranteed playing with them to lower your rank - that's what the game offers. So you get a meltdown at some point and scold some of these players in game. Instead of them getting banned, you'll get communication ban (those toxic players reported you and you got banned for it XD) Crazy right? Their rules and system ain't so perfect. So even the good players eventually end up degrading to a level of toxic player. Unless the system has a strict ban on toxic players who throw games intentionally , who purchase higher rank accounts and ruin others MMR, it won't give you the fun you expect. Rather you'll get a lot of stress by forcibly playing matches thrown by these toxic players - Coz you can't quit in between. That will result in a report on you. Rather you have to painfully watch and play the game that these idiots throw by picking non roles, feeding intentionally, fake account - smurfs and newbies. That's a lot of pain and stress for the fun you expect from the game. Even though every game has it's own share of toxic players, I feel here in the ranked community of Dota 2 it's way more and intolerable. Hopefully the system improves in future to severe ban such accounts. So decide wisely before you dive into this game, if you can handle toxicity you'll be fine. Especially in ranked.

Weirdest fucking experience of my life.

There's a lot of things, (people included), that I truly hate about this game. It has deviated from the original WCIII custom mod experience in many ways, but holds true in just as many fundamental aspects. In my opinion, this is like the adult table at Thanksgiving dinner while LoL and other mobas are the kids table. The depth and complexity are not matched, and I appreciate that. If that offends you or your opinion maybe you should route some of that time spent personally attacking people and their thoughts into furthering your knowledge or preparing a thesis on how I'm wrong. If you're looking for a complex, engaged MOBA, this fits the bill. The skins are cosmetic only, they have free to play options for obtaining skins, and the community is full (albeit toxic in lower MMR). Which brings me to my final point, if you can't handle people talking in foreign languages telling you to choke on a puddle of pig vomit, and you don't have other people to queue with, this might not be a logical choice. If possible, avoid solo queue because, in my experience as of late, low MMR ranked solo queue is impossible to escape. Regardless of how well you do, you're still subjected to toxic players, abandoners, and people who grief/throw the game because  you aren't catering exactly to their playstyle. Not all players are compatible. It's a fact. This is a game where 5 man coordination is absolutely key to victory. Losing one or two of those players creates a cascade that ends in completely and utter destruction of your team, base, and morale. It reaches a point where it is futile to attempt redemption. However, like a drug addict carpet surfing for the fifth time today, I crawl back into the trenches because there's the hope somewhere that this will all end one day. If a game can make me want to play despite my recent, soul-crushing experiences, then there's something in there worthwhile.

TL;DR It's a complicated and challenging game, which can be rewarding when you achieve something and there's a sense of progress if you invest a lot of time. By far, the worst aspect is the community.


Positive:
- It's not League:
  * You can play every hero all the time
  * You can demo/test heroes 
  * You can observe any public game from within the client
  * Builtin voice chat (you don't have to be in a premade party)
- There's an internal league called "Battle Cup"
- Works on Linux
- Allows modding (game arcade)
- Lots of skins and visual enhancements to buy

Negative:
- Very toxic community (lots of screaming, insulting, giving up early, etc.)
  * As a team game, being forced to mute everbody makes it seem like you're playing against bots
- There are so many cheaters because of how the game is built (information about everybody and everything on the map is sent to the client)
- Normal game is veeery slow and people take it way too seriously
- Not friendly at all for beginners (you get flamed incessently for mistakes)
- Game arcade is only alternative but it's:
  * unmaintained
  * buggy
  * ranking system is very bad (game developers pay for their games to have a good rank/visibility)
- There's no clear way to get help

Probably the best MOBA but i wish they would stop dumbing it down in order to attract the LoL fan base... LoL has it's own magic and so does Dota2, there is no point in trying to change Dota in to LoL, because you can't. There is a reason why YouTube is full of videos titled "LoL player tries Dota2" and only a couple titled " Dota2 player tries LoL". 

Also, the devs don't care anymore about the stories behind the heroes, their interactions... And we, as a community, feel these changes and how our game becomes more and more just a cash cow. Still, at the moment, i recommend this.

This game is just a down hill spiral. First you think to yourself after watching a professional match "maybe I can get some quality teammates" , "maybe if I queue up right now I can play a game where I don't have someone go 3/15 in my mid lane and turn the enemies into a raid boss" , but by the time the queue pops, you've already remembered  the last time you told yourself that lie only now you have a false sense of determination which will slowly be whittled away by the below average IQ of the entire low-elo community match after match until you start to question if it's them or you who have the issues, at that point it's probably best to just retire to making sandwiches lest you risk a chat ban. That is until you have that all to familiar thought of winning.
Still hard for beginner, but it's still the best game after so many games I played
Community is terrible. Don't play unless you have 4 friends to play with consistently.

The '3k and below' experience :

Drafting phase, someone is highlighting a hero you don't play, so you ignore their suggestion and pick something you fancy.

The game start and they instantly start criticizing your pick in the allies voice chat. In the adverse team, some fanboy is spamming a famous team voiceline in the /all chat. One pauses, cuz why going to the WC before the game when you can make 9 other people wait.

Around min 0, your carry tries to sneak their jungle bounty rune and dies.

Min 6, the enemy mid player already ganked two times while your mid doesn't seem to give a shit. Your carry is making yolo moves and dying instead of focusing on their farm. They type ' gg I'm afk ' and go jungling,

Min 10, the safelane tower is dead, you are fighting with your strong core around the hardlane while your carry is recovering in the jungle. Someone in your team is pinging 'we need wards' as they died out of position in the river mid.

Min 15, your team finally managed to take the enemy top tower, you've got to mute 2 of your teammates and 1 enemy player that were pausing each time they made a kill.

Min 20, you smoke to the enemy jungle to place some wards, hoping the vision will make your carry comfortable enough to cross the river and farm there. Despite your efforts your carry won't leave the triangle. Your mid and p3 are also jungling in your side of the map. The other support is trying to make solo moves and get killed 4v1. "Space created" says their chat wheel. On a positive note, the enemy team also doesn't seem to have any intention to cross the river.

Min 25, nothing new under the sun. Is it actually night time in the game and your carry get kill in a 5 heroes smoke. Finally someone crossed the river.

Min 30, everyone is late on their items timings, your p3 rushed a radiance but have no armor/magic res against the other team. You are 1/7/13 with a force staff, that's not so bad.

Min 35, a weird teamfight is taking place around the rosh pit, the enemy mid died and instantly buy-back to die again a few secs later.

Min 40, both team took a tier 2 tower, you are currently making a siege under their t3 but no one have the guts to go on the high ground. The enemy team is complaining about their carry being an asshole in the /all chat. Eventually a teamfight happens and someone wins, the 2 people in the other team buy back and so everyone tacitly agrees on a jungling truce.
You start being a bit annoyed by the game and your attention drops, in so you die two times in a row trying to ward the exact same spot. One of your teammates chose this moment to reveal being a Slavic boi and start to angrily flame you. Sadly you don't understand anything but a 'cyka' or a 'blyat' from time to time.

45mins, one of the two sides eventually wins the game, but tbh this team doesn't deserve victory much more than the other. The winners drop some 'ez mid' in the /all chat.

Results : on each side 1 people got reported and 3 muted each others. You are happy that this mess of a game is over, and click on the green 'find match' button, hoping for the next one to be more interesting.

A long time ago, I started as a fresh bab to MOBAS in general and was introduced to Dota 2. I still play this with these friends, but I must note that there are far more entertaining games on the market. Heroes of the Storm, League of Legends, Smite, Battlerite, but none have the degree of polish and thought that is required to play a round of Dota. Dota is a game of perseverance, of learning, and of pain. After all this time, i'm by no means an expert, and with the massive roster at hand you can play for thousands of hours and still not reach the skill ceiling. Every character is unique, but has counter play. Not a single time has there been a moment where I called bs on a player pushing a button and blowing up my ancient. There were times I despaired, surely, but I knew that things could have gone differently in the draft phase, or the lane phase, or the team fight phase if the co-ordination and itemization of whichever side i'm on is performed adequately. Someone always invisible? Buy a dust to reveal him, or place a sentry. The enemy picked a backline bandit that can kill us all from a mile away? We should draft an engage or an assassin hero to eliminate his presence. The enemy likes to cast point and click stuns that disables for a millennia? I should buy a spell blocking item to save me from that CC! Every possible play can be negated, but it is up to you to understand and learn how each item/hero interacts to better perform. 

Quotes: "Time and time again, i've seen the fight between Radiant and Dire go thousands of different directions, and thankfully, every time, win or loss, i've learned something new." 

"After 700 hours I can say without a shadow of a doubt, that the soul and purpose of the game is to click on minions for 40 minutes and then you can finally be allowed to play."

"People who play Dota 2 treat normals games like LCS and have egos that tower over mountains. No-one is playing to have fun, they're playing to win."

Dota 2 is not a good game, but it is the best measure of how you can adapt and co-operate with random people you meet.
It is the best team on team action you can ever hope to participate in, and in an odd way it IS the best game Valve has ever made. 

I hate it. 

It isn't for the casual audience, and nor is it for the faint of will. It is a professional game that will beat you blue and bloody til you learn from your mistakes, and will make you not only hate the game, it will make you hate yourself. If you find yourself amongst friends who want to play it, go ahead. You will have plenty to enjoy, but you could much more easily find entertainment skipping stones on a pond, playing in the mud, or reading a book out loud. You could always have a blast as long as you are in good company.

Probably one of the most entertaining / challenging games I've ever played. It has its occasional bugs and downtime, but overall is an aesthetic masterpiece with constant updates and tweaks.

Despite the hours, and my love for this game, I struggle to actually recommend it to friends based on the toxicity of the community alone.

Whilst I've made some great friends in the game, and enjoy partying with them, a large portion of the community have little-to-no interpersonal skills and like to abuse each other constantly.

After the release of the TV show recently, I had thought that perhaps it was on it's way to a resurgence with a flow in of new players, although it seems to have gotten worse. Having to mute 1-2 players in most games, why would any newcomer stay for such an experience?

Sadly without any serious consequences from Valve, I fear this game will eventually become an aged e-sports title, with it's only fans being those that centre around it's online tournaments.

EDIT: For those who still want to play but have issues with the above, disable chat from people who arent friends/party members. This still doesn't change my review, as I cannot recommend this to new players, as they need to amass a friends list before this offers any reprieve.

The Anti-Defamation League has released a 2021 follow-up to its past studies on toxicity in online gaming, which tracks players‚Äô experiences in various prominent games. Studies on the subject began in 2019, with DOTA 2 being the worst-rated game in both the inaugural rating and the 2020 edition of the study.¬†

By all measures, DOTA 2 is more toxic than League of Legends by a significant margin.
Even though DOTA 2 isn‚Äôt the most toxic game anymore, it‚Äôs still statistically worse than a long list of competing titles. Only 65% of players from rival MOBA League of Legends reported harassment, compared with DOTA 2‚Äôs 78%.¬†
The ADL‚Äôs study also found DOTA 2 to be worse than most other top console and PC multiplayer titles, including PlayerUnknown‚Äôs Battlegrounds, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, and Fortnite.

Toxicity in DOTA 2 has become normal due to a number of different factors, most of which boil down to inaction from Valve in addressing problems.
Starting at the very top of DOTA 2 is the normalcy of bad behavior among DOTA 2 pros. Many professional players regularly stream themselves intentionally feeding, griefing, and generally behaving poorly.¬†
Racist language is also unfortunately common among DOTA 2 pros. Popular personalities including Anathan ‚Äúana‚Äù Pham and Hector ‚ÄúK1‚Äù Rodriguez have spouted blatant racism in-game without consequence. This has spilled over into actual tournaments, with players using racist language against Chinese opponents in-game and facing no repercussions from Valve.

This applies to esports organizations and tournament organizers as well. Grant ‚ÄúGranDGranT‚Äù Harris had a history of aggression towards women both physically and verbally, but was still a regular commentator at tournaments and was sponsored by Evil Geniuses for years. Henrik ‚ÄúAdmiralBulldog‚Äù Ahnberg has had a number of controversies surrounding his use of racist language and stereotypes on stream, but remains a part of Alliance and has worked as an analyst at multiple events.
Compare this with League of Legends, which regularly sees pro players fined and suspended for using racist language, and it‚Äôs easy to see why these issues might escalate over time in DOTA 2.

Given that it started life as a faithful recreation of the original Defence of the Ancients mod, you‚Äôd be forgiven for thinking of Dota 2 as the archetypical MOBA. Yet this isn‚Äôt the case: in practice, Dota 2‚Äôs purism sets it apart from the vast majority of games in this genre. What we think of as the MOBA really began with Heroes of Newerth and League of Legends‚Äîgames that took that roughshod family of WarCraft custom maps and professionalised them, commercialised them, found them a form that would enshrine the MOBA at the top of the gaming world for the better part of a decade.

I have played this game for 3215 hours. I have 999 wins in unranked matchmaking. I have not played this game since probably around 2018, I was drinking quite a bit and if matches were going bad I'd often do shots instead of finishing matches. I was in low-priority when I uninstalled the game, my review of this game will entirely depend on whether I am still in low-prio when I have finished re-installing it. I remember having some valuable items in-game so I will probably sell those ASAP. I'd be surprised if I was still in Low-Priority, I mean they've changed the game so much since then and now, who's to say that their actions weren't what triggered my bad behavior that incurred the slap on the wrist to begin with, that would be pretty arrogant on their part to automatically absolve themselves of culpability. We'll just have to see. I can safely say I did not receive this product for free as I bought a treasure within the game and everyone knows vanilla loadouts are for losers. 

UPDATE: Reinstalled the game and I am no longer in low-prio. Glad the devs had the humility to admit they erred to discipline me for being un-entertained by their entertainment product.

It feels distinctly as if all the sane people quit playing this corpse of a game a long time ago, all that's left are a nucleus of die-hard fans, pros and total psychopaths, with little to no middle ground. 

Meta is currently staler than last century's cheese (2 months since last patch, which in turn changed a couple values to some abilities, wow!); close to zero communication from the developers regarding future patches and changes, not even a hint of them trying to engage with the community for feedbacks and propositions. 

Only thing that's keeping the game borderline 'alive' is the pro scene, but anything below tier 1 is treated like garbage and downright disrespected by the company. Oh, you wanted to play some competitive dota and you are not a tier 1 team? Too bad, we are canceling big tournaments for which you've already invested time and effort and money just to qualify. Sucks to be you!

The game fails to attract new blood with a new player experience that's not just bad, not even terrible, hellish is the only adjective that even comes close to describing it accurately. Amidst all this, what does the small indie company do? That's right folks, more hats and battle passes and cosmetics locked behind a couple hundred quids paywall, for whale buyers to gorge upon! Because the cow has to be milked dry right until the last breath.

As a new player, this is one of the worst communities ever. I've asked for help in every single game I've played in, and not ONCE received a reply from my teammates. How am I supposed to get better at the game if the people I'm playing with won't help? 

The game itself is great - nice visuals, a huge roster of characters to choose from, 'simple' mechanics (although I'm still getting used to the massive item/upgrade list), but it's ruined by a massive learning curve and a community that just doesn't seem to care about new players. 

Such a shame.

EDIT: OK, so it appears that for some reason the default chat settings are set to 'friends only', which is why I wasn't getting any replies. I changed that and now I can hear everyone calling me a f****t, human garbage, trash, etc. At least we're talking now, I guess...?

Dota 2 is a real-time strategy computer multiplayer team game with elements of a computer role-playing game, the implementation of the famous DotA map for Warcraft III in a separate client.

The game is played by two teams of five people. One team is on the light side, the other is on the dark side. Each player controls one hero, each of which has special skills and abilities. The hero can gain experience to increase his level, earn gold, buy and collect items that strengthen him or give him additional abilities. Each player constantly receives a small amount of gold from their base, and also earns small portions of gold for killing enemy creatures and large portions for killing heroes. Teams are dispersed along the lines, where they fight against enemy heroes and units of creeps under the control of the computer, which appear at the bases of the teams every half a minute. The goal of the game is to destroy the main building in the enemy base.
